PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Regulations ( Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1982, No. 302, and made under the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979, be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. At a time when Turkey is going through a cosmetic exercise to claim that she is a democracy, has Australia allied herself with other United Nations countries to force Turkey to take its troops out of Cyprus and bring peace to that country, a move which could be equated with the role of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics beyond the Khyber Pass?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I would need to refer that matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a report from him on it. I will see that Senator Mulvihill is advised.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: In lieu of the traditional Christmas carols on 24 December, will listeners to the second network of the Australian Broadcasting Commission be treated to a parliamentary broadcast of the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently circulated to all honourable senators a list of the remaining business. I hope that with goodwill in this period we can get up some days before Christmas. I hope that it will be possible for the ABC to return to more joyous tunes than perhaps the discordant notes of the Senate. I ask for the full co-operation of all honourable senators in this regard.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. As the Minister is well aware, Parliament will be sitting next week. I have had many complaints about the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Commission has not been able to provide an adequate coverage of the test matches. Could the Minister make some representations to the Minister for Communications to make sure that during the time that Parliament is being broadcast by other stations the test cricket is given a reasonable coverage?

—The broadcasting of Parliament is determined by the appropriate statute. I am not sure that there is a capacity to alter that. The best solution would seem to me to be to get the parliamentary business completed expeditiously and for this Parliament then to retire so that we too can enjoy the cricket.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. What progress is the Government making in regard to the upgrading of our current Antarctic transport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government is determining the best means of replacing the present ships which resupply Australia's Antarctic stations and which provide a limited Antarctic marine science capability. Initial studies indicated that a single Australian-owned multi-purpose vessel with limited icebreaking capability was likely to be the most cost-effective option. Recent developments have resulted in the studies being widened in scope to include multi-vessel and ship and air options. A ship design consultant was engaged to assist in the development of vessel concepts. That task is now completed. The overall studies are nearing completion and a proposal will be put to the Government later this month. I assume that after the Government has had some time to consider that proposal the appropriate statement will be made by the Minister concerned.

—Mr President, my question is directed to you. Is it not a fact that clear instructions exist in the Australian Constitution for the conduct of the business of this Senate and that this can be changed only by a constitutional amendment? Does not section 23 of the Constitution clearly state : 'Questions arising in the Senate shall be determined by a majority of votes . . .'? Did not a vote on a motion in the Senate yesterday result in 28 in favour and 26 against but it was declared not to pass under the provisions of Standing Order 448?
—There was collusion between the Minister and Lewis.
—Order! Senator Chipp, rarely over your years in this Parliament have you made such an unparliamentary statement. That is a very serious reflection upon the Chair and I ask you--
—No, sir; Senator Lewis, not the Chair.

—Senator Chipp, to reflect on the Chair by saying that there was collusion between an honourable senator sitting in this chair and another honourable senator in this place is a very serious matter. I wish to expand on this a little further. I was hoping to have a chance to talk with you this morning, Senator, about the question that was raised last night with regard to the vote and the points raised by Senator Mason. A contingency motion was not moved in this place at the time it should have been moved. Having said that, let me give an assurance to all honourable senators that Senate practice has been that precedence will always be given to a Minister if he or she is on his or her feet, over even a leader of a party. The Minister gets precedence. That was what happened last night. But that does not preclude any other honourable senator also moving a motion at the same time. Senator Mason would have had every opportunity to move his motion last night.
—I was on my feet--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator! Let us handle this calmly. If Senator Mason or any other honourable senator claimed that he or she was not acknowledged from the Chair, as has happened so many times in this place, he or she could have made his or her position known by calling for the Chair to recognise him or her . Again, if Senator Mason felt that he had not been seen or had been purposely overlooked, which he was not, he could have raised a point of order. There are so many avenues whereby an honourable senator has the opportunity to move a motion in this place. Quite frankly, I think Senator Mason made a mistake by not rising and moving a contingency motion at the time. Once the normal debates under the Orders of the Day have started, it is too late for a contingency motion to be moved. Hence, no contingency motion having been moved in this place, the Senate then had to resort to a normal motion rather than to a contingency motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chipp, I have given an explanation to you. I regard what you have said as a very serious reflection upon an honourable senator in this place who was carrying out his duties in the chair, at the time, as an Acting Deputy President. I say to all honourable senators that I have the greatest respect for the honourable senator upon whom Senator Chipp has cast a serious reflection and for all other Acting Deputy Presidents who operate in the absence of either the Deputy President, Senator McClelland, or me from this chamber. I have never had any occasion to question either their integrity or their fair play in this place. I stand by that statement. I again ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly accept your invitation to withdraw, Mr President. I ask you to make inquiries about whether Senator Lewis had before him, at the time he did not call Senator Mason when he was on his feet, a piece of paper clearly stating that Senator Mason wanted to intervene at the placing of business. Senator Lewis did not call Senator Mason, notwithstanding the fact that Senator Mason was on his feet. All I ask is: Will you pursue your investigations along that line?

—Senator, you have not made an unconditional withdrawal, but I will return to that in a moment. In response to your question, irrespective of whether a piece of paper was on the desk in front of the Chair, it is the responsibility of honourable senators in this place to stand if they wish to receive the call; it is not for the Chair to give the call on the basis of a piece of paper. I remind all honourable senators in this place that the Standing Orders clearly state that the Chair will give the call to honourable senators who the Chair sees have risen in their places, and not from a speakers list. The speakers list is a guide. However, because of a domestic arrangement between the Whips the practice has been that the Chair does give the call from a speakers list. But I say again that the responsibility for getting the call rested directly with Senator Mason. Senator Chipp, I have given that further explanation because we are handling this matter in a very sensible way at this time. I again ask you to withdraw unconditionally.
—I thought I did.
—No, you added to it.
—I certainly do.
—Thank you.
—I absolutely, unconditionally and unequivocally withdraw any reflection I made on the Chair.
—Thank you.
—I now ask: Will you pursue your inquiries with Senator Lewis?
—Yes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Peter Baume

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator Chipp said that there had been collusion between a Minister and the Chair. There was no collusion.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask all honourable senators to bear in mind that the discussion that has taken place between Senator Chipp and me has been, I think, worth while in that we have clarified a situation. Let us keep this discussion low key. The Minister, Senator Baume, was also mentioned. I afford Senator Baume the same opportunity to rise in this place. I ask honourable senators please to contain themselves.

—The matter is perfectly simple, Mr President. Senator Chipp said that there had been collusion between the Minister and the Chair. That is untrue. There was no collusion. In any event, it is against the Standing Orders to make that kind of accusation against another senator and I ask that Senator Chipp withdraw that part of his statement which refers to me.
—Senator Chipp, you have been requested by the Chair to make a withdrawal.
—Mr President, I withdraw unconditionally and unequivocally for the Minister.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. Is it not a fact that clear instructions exist in the Australian Constitution for the conduct of the business of this Senate and that this can be changed only by a constitutional amendment which involves a referendum of the people, among other things? Does not section 23 of the Constitution clearly state: 'Questions arising in the Senate shall be determined by a majority of votes . . .'? Did not a vote on a motion in the Senate yesterday result in 28 in favour and 26 against but it was declared not to pass under the provisions of Standing Order 448? While the Senate may and can make Standing Orders for its own activities, can it legally make a Standing Order which is directly in contravention of the Constitution? Is it a fact that Standing Order 448 was not used in this place for many years for that reason? How can its use now be justified? Can you ask the Standing Orders Committee to consider this matter urgently and report back to the Senate, as I and other senators consider that our rights under the Constitution are grossly infringed by this Standing Order?

—I understand that this question was raised in the chamber some 10 years ago and was considered by the then Standing Orders Committee. However, I will be happy to place this question before the Standing Orders Committee again.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, relates to the proposed relocation of the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories in Adelaide. Can the Minister confirm that AMDEL is considering moving its operations to Technology Park, Adelaide, and that the South Australian Government and private industry have already come forward with their share of the finance needed to make this move? Is it a fact that the Commonwealth has been approached for money to assist the project-I understand that a sum in the vicinity of $300,000 is involved-but that to date it has not responded to the request? Does the Minister recognise that the move of AMDEL to Technology Park, Adelaide, would assist in the establishment of that high technology zone which, when fully developed, will greatly assist in the future development of the South Australian economy? If so, will the Minister undertake to examine the situation and make a decision urgently so that this move can take place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that AMDEL is considering moving its pilot plant from Thebarton to Technology Park, Adelaide. I am advised that on 2 August the South Australian Government proposed that the Commonwealth Government, private industry and the South Australian Government share the estimated cost, in the order of $1m, of AMDEL's relocation. My understanding is that private industry has not yet agreed to support the relocation of the pilot plant. The Commonwealth Government has the matter under consideration but has not yet reached a decision on it.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, refers to the remarks of the Minister for Health yesterday, in the course of which he accused me and others of scaring or frightening pensioners about the new form on the back of prescriptions. I ask the Minister whether his attention has been drawn to the activities of the Canberra-Monaro Pharmacists Association, which conducted trials in co-operation with pensioners' clubs in this district, such trials showing that the average time to complete the form was 10 minutes, that only one in four was able to complete it accurately and that the average number of errors was three and a half per form. The Association also pointed out that the form will be very hard to read when the prescriptions are filled out on the other side. Does the Minister intend to accuse the Canberra-Monaro Pharmacists Association of scare tactics and of frightening pensioners? Does he consider that the pensioners' clubs which took part in the test are also indulging in frightening the pensioners? Will he not consider the reasonable objections of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, of pharmacists in general, of pensioners' associations and of the Opposition and reconsider whether the use of this form should be continued?

—The problem faced by the Government is that it is providing a concessional prescription rate to certain people and that the system is open to abuse and fraud. A system must be found to obtain some kind of certification to ensure that the expenditure of public money is appropriate. What has been proposed is a system which, I believe, is simple enough. That system is the subject of Senator Grimes's question. I have not had drawn to my attention comments made yesterday by the Minister whom I represent in this place; nor am I aware of the findings of the local group to which the honourable senator referred. I believe that the Minister for Health is receiving whatever input is available about any administrative difficulties involved, but I come back to the point that there is a need to find a way to ensure that the concessional prescription rate is being used by those who are properly entitled to it. I have seen the forms that are required to be filled in and have looked at some of the forms in the books. They seem to me to be simple enough. If there are real difficulties I am sure that Mr Carlton will consider them. I know it is his view that completing the forms is not onerous. I repeat that there is a question of equity as to the rights of the community as a whole, as well as the equity of making sure the concessional benefit goes to those who are entitled to it. Mr Carlton has been able to introduce the concessional benefit to help pensioners, those on low incomes and others. It is a benefit which did not previously exist. The argument now is about the administrative arrangements which will go with this. I will refer Senator Grimes's question to Mr Carlton in case he wishes or needs to take any further action.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question which arises from the answer given by the Minister. He repeated the claim that the new pharmaceutical benefits system is open to fraud; hence the necessity for this form. Is it not a fact that the Commonwealth has supplied pharmaceutical benefits at this concessional rate, or at a zero rate, for pensioners and other beneficiaries since the early 1950s and that the present system, whereby the number is put on the form and the person has to sign that form, has existed for that time? What evidence can the Minister produce that that has led to fraud on a large scale? How many patients over the years have been prosecuted for fraud under that system and why will a simple system like that not operate effectively even under the new pharmaceutical benefits system?

—I am aware that Mr Carlton considered a system along the lines of the one suggested by Senator Grimes and that he considered the system proposed to be better. I will refer Senator Grimes's further questions to Mr Carlton.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. It is reported in today's Melbourne Age that the Government may impose export controls on aluminium. The article suggests that the decision will be in response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on the development of the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries. The report recommends:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . full export controls on aluminium metal be retained as an option should evidence of transfer pricing or other tax avoidance be forthcoming.
In the absence of that evidence, I ask the Minister whether he agrees that the Senate Committee recommended against export controls, as follows:
The Committee does not believe that export controls should be introduced at an early stage in the expansion of smelting in Australia.

Will the Minister further agree that export controls would be a severe imposition on an industry which is already suffering from the international recession and is having difficulty in competing with other producing countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is well aware of the Senate Committee's report and has it under study. It considers that the report contains some very valuable material, particularly relating to the export of commodities such as aluminium, bauxite and alumina. The Government's primary aim is to ensure that the people of Australia get the full market value for the product that they sell . Only if that is so can the real benefit that comes from a natural resource with the application of human labour and skills accrue to the people in terms of better education, housing, social welfare, et cetera. The Government has as a reserve power the ability to impose export controls. The Government is aware that it is possible for certain industries to use that device-particularly industries where both the buyer and the seller may have similar antecedents or origins. This happens very much in the aluminium industry. Suffice it to say that the Government is continuing to study the Senate Committee report. The Government believes that in all these matters it must keep the right to use expert controls if necessary. The Government would be willing to use those controls if necessary. In each case we look to see whether Australia is receiving the world price. That will be the test; it is the test applied to all our minerals. I will refer Senator Thomas's question to the Minister for Trade and Resources because I consider it an important one. I will ask the Minister to study it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Government expect company tax collections to increase in line with the expected increase in company profits as a result of the proposed wages freeze? Will the Government give an assurance that any such increase in company tax collections will be used specifically for additional capital works programs or directly to create more jobs in the public sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On the figures that the Treasurer gave yesterday about the present Budget year, 1982-83, I do not think there is any anticipation of increased company tax collections. The proposed wage pause, extending over two financial years, may show some improvement in company profits , either later this year or in the next financial year. If there are increased company tax collections, I assume that they will form part of the Government's general revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think it can be assumed from the figures given yesterday that it is any easy matter to balance the Government's expenditure and revenue in present economic circumstances. So at this stage I am not in any position to look at any hypothetical profit increases, and the company tax collected on them, and to hypothecate them for a particular capital works program. What the Government is endeavouring to do in its Budget in the present year and in the next year, which is also affected by the wage pause, is to see that there is emphasis on employment-creating projects and projects that will enable as large an employment figure as possible to be achieved. So I think that in those general terms I can say that the Government's objective is towards employment within whatever constraints it has on Budget outcome, and we will be directing our efforts towards that end.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. It refers to a statement in today's Australian in which the Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd, Mr Jim Leslie, repeats a call that he has made on many occasions for adequate capitalisation of that company. Is the Minister aware that Qantas, because it has inadequate working capital, has to borrow the required funds and that this is currently costing $54m a year in interest payments, which denies Qantas any chance of making a net profit despite its excellent and efficient management? Why does the Government not transfer the sum asked for, which is $ 75m, so that Qantas can compete fairly in what is a very tough market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am well aware of the financial situation of Qantas. It has been the subject of discussions between the Minister and me and our respective departments on a number of occasions. It is a well known fact that there is not a very large capital in the Qantas balance sheet. But to suggest that simply transferring from borrowed funds on which it pays interest to loans or grants from the Government would enable it to be more profitable in the present very difficult international airline market just evades the point that the profitability itself is difficult. It really matters little whether any profit that is derived is able to be called profit and paid to the Government as a dividend on the finances which are invested, or whether it is paid as interest on the loans. In terms of presentation it may be different, but what one would be looking for is profitability on funds employed, be they grants from the Government, capital invested by the Government or loans. I think the real problem with Qantas is in looking for profitability in a difficult airline market and gaining its share of a reducing world air travel market. Certainly many discussions are being undertaken with Qantas through Ministers. If there are any announcements to be made about restructuring Qantas , they will be made at the appropriate time by the Minister concerned.
—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister indicate how much of the funding that Qantas has to borrow on the open market comes from overseas sources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have those figures readily available . I will seek them for Senator MacGibbon.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support to the Senate Hansard of 26 October 1982 and to a motion moved by me relating to a reference to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of the Government aircraft industry at Fishermen's Bend and the Nomad project. I refer to the last paragraph of that motion, which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: That no retrenchment of employees should take place until both Houses of the Parliament have debated the Joint Committee's report on this reference.

Does the Minister recall that he, on behalf of the Government, moved an amendment to my motion to the effect that no compulsory retrenchments should take place and the Senate then voted unanimously in support of the motion after it had been amended by the Government? Is it not a fact that 38 employees of the Government Aircraft Factories have now been given notice of dismissal as from 22 December? Were all the employees at the factory told, subsequent to the Senate resolution, that the Government had considered the Senate resolution and that no retrenchments would take place until the inquiry of the Joint Committee had been completed? Did the employees of the Government Aircraft Factories act on that assumption in the context of an industrial relations dispute? If all these matters are so, does this not seriously affect the credibility not only of this Government but also of this Parliament that the resolution of the Senate was relied upon by the employees at that factory and dismissals have since taken place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do recall the motion that was passed by the Senate on 26 October and to which Senator Button refers. I would like just to outline the background to the discussion at that time. Last May the Government announced that the Nomad aircraft would be progressively phased out of production up to late 1984 by which date it was planned that 170 aircraft would be delivered. At the same time the Government announced that retrenchments would be involved at the Government Aircraft Factories at Fishermen's Bend but that staff levels at the Avalon plant would not be reduced. Consultation at that point proceeded between the factory management, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the staff association and union representatives. The responsible Minister personally participated in that consultation. The first notices of retrenchment were to have been issued in October but the process was suspended when the Senate motion was passed.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation was reconsidered subsequently in the light of the Senate resolution. Unfortunately since then, and of course as was known at the time, the market weakness and increasing costs, which were advised by the Government as major considerations in the decision last May to stop the Nomad program, still hold, and with even greater force than applied then. There are already people at the Government Aircraft Factories at Fishermen's Bend who cannot be usefully employed because of the falling work load there. Regrettably, therefore , there is no practical alternative to retrenchment. As I think was acknowledged by Senator Button, the last paragraph of the resolution passed at the time included a reference to compulsory retrenchment and, in fact, that particular wording was included, as I understand it, because of requests from the ACTU which had been fully consulted about the matter at that time.

Clearly the Government's decision is an economic one and clearly it is a question of meeting the market situation. There is a developing problem at GAF which has been well acknowledged during the Senate debate. There are prospects of developing alternatives by virtue of offset work which will flow from the F18 program as it gets under way, and that was freely acknowledged in this place during debate on the motion to which Senator Button referred. As to the propriety of the particular action undertaken by management, we have to recognise that we are in a time of very considerable difficulty. It has been found since the passage of that resolution that unfortunately no alternative work was available for those employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Because the Minister's answer was so inevitably involved, is it a fair summation of it to say that employees of the Commonwealth cannot rely on any undertakings given by this Government in relation to their employment?

—No, that is not a fair summation of the situation at all. There is a question of management decisions that have been taken in particular circumstances. The resolution, having been passed by the Senate, was indeed acknowledged by the Government and taken into account in its decision. The Government is responsible for its actions and will be judged as such.

—My question to the Minister for National Development and Energy is about the current strike on Bass Strait oil rigs. Is it not a fact that the people working on the Bass Strait oil rigs are probably among the highest paid workmen in Australia, working the least number of weeks per annum of any workmen in Australia? What will be the effect on our economy of this strike? Will there be a substantial loss of oil revenue to the Government? What efforts is the Government making to resolve this strike? Generally, what will be the effect on the Australian community if this strike continues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I mentioned in this place that the dispute in Bass Strait, which is at present a tug dispute, has caused a decline in production of Bass Strait crude of the order of 41 per cent. That in itself, of course, will cause a decline in revenue and will necessitate the purchase of overseas crude. It is a fact that, in general, the workers in the oil industry in Australia have been given very generous terms and conditions. It has been considered by other industries that they are pace setters in the upward surge of wages and conditions. The immediate situation is that Bass Strait production has fallen by some 43 per cent and three crude tankers, one product tanker and an overseas liquefied petroleum gas carrier are waiting to load at Westernport. That delay involves all the costs of demurrage and all the idleness that goes to increase costs.

ANSWER.PARA: I will give the honourable senator a rundown of what is happening around Australia. The Amoco Australia Ltd refinery in Brisbane is operating at a minimum throughput. The refinery will close down on Saturday if no crude is received. The Amanda Miller is waiting off Brisbane to discharge, and the position on gasoline is tight. Ampol Ltd in Brisbane is operating at a minimum throughput to conserve crude supplies. No shutdown is imminent. The Ampol Sarel is waiting off Brisbane to discharge her cargo. The product supply is adequate. The British Petroleum Co. of Australia refinery at Westernport will close down over the weekend because of a lack of ullage for gas oil. So the story goes. At the Caltex Oil (Australia) Pty Ltd refinery at Kurnell one crude distillation unit and platform have closed down and it has only four days crude remaining. The Petroleum Refineries of Australia refinery at Altona is expected to close down over the weekend due to a lack of ullage for fuel oil. At the moment Port Stanvac is unaffected. All these things have immediate and long term effects, particularly upon the image of Australia overseas.

The honourable senator cannot fail to have noticed that a number of prominent industrialists, both Australian and international, have remarked that Australia' s trade will be threatened very seriously in the short and long term because of our bad track record in industrial disputes. The particular dispute is before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission so I do not comment on it . I am advised that the Commission will hear the matter tomorrow. I comment merely upon the major points that Senator Lewis has raised. One of the important reforms that we must find for Australia if we are to emerge from this recession and take advantage of world recovery is a better and more civilised way of conducting our industrial affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to the Australian Teachers Federation's national survey of conditions in schools and, in particular, to that part of the survey dealing with migrant education? The survey maintains that the student- staff ratio for children from homes which do not have English as the main language spoken in the home is 138 students per specialised staff. The survey also maintains that whereas over 50 per cent of primary schools have students from homes in which English is not the main language spoken, only 11 per cent of all primary schools have English as a second language teachers. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to these facts ? If so, what action is the Minister currently undertaking to rectify this appalling situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the ATF survey. My Department may well be. I am aware that overall pupil-teacher ratios are improving across Australia in all sectors. Of course, in the secondary sector the government schools in Australia have the best pupil-teacher ratios of any schools. I am also aware that the English as a second language program which is funded by my Department across Australia-some of the funding goes into government schools-is being maintained and funded at a high level. In fact, we have improved in real terms our support for programs like this. In other words, our commitment to the training of people in English as a second language is strong. Our funding reflects that.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot say whether a particular calculation suggests that more teachers are needed in this area. I agree with Senator Macklin's sentiments that we need an adequate number of teachers to make this program work. But in view of the funding that we are providing and the commitment that has been undertaken, the fact that this funding is widespread throughout the educational system and the fact that pupil-teacher ratios are improving across Australia, I believe that we are starting from a good base. I will take under study the points raised by the honourable senator to see whether any response should be made to those particular observed phenomena.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Can I take it from the Minister 's reply that he will undertake to see whether the figures set out in the survey , in particular, in relation to primary schools are correct and then provide the Senate with that information?
—Yes.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether he is aware of the need for legislation in Tasmania for an Aboriginal land council and the return of some areas of land, including the Mutton Bird Islands, to the Aboriginal people? Does he know that draft legislation has been in existence for some time? Will the Minister take action to encourage the new Tasmanian Government to introduce Aboriginal land rights legislation and assure me that he will not let the State Liberal Government imitate the governments of Queensland and Western Australia on this issue?

—Senator Coates may not be aware of it but there was a long and difficult progress in the preparation of legislation in Tasmania under the former Labor Government. During my time as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I was involved in talking to members of the Aboriginal community. They were very concerned about the tardiness of the Labor Government in progressing the preparation and consideration of that legislation. It obviously provided some difficulties for the former Government of Tasmania in knowing how to draw the legislation and knowing what was an appropriate form of legislation for the needs of Tasmanian Aboriginal people. At about the time the Government changed I was urged to try to get further consideration from the then Minister. Clearly, the new Government will be taking on board the consideration of the legislation. I am sure that it will give it the same careful consideration as was being given by the former administration and that it will seek to strike the right balance of equity between all sections of the community. Some areas of land are of particular interest to Aboriginal people in Tasmania. I am sure that the present Government is as aware as the former Government was of this interest.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. What effect is the drought having on the quality and quantity of water in the River Murray which is available for irrigation? Is the position being continuously monitored by the Minister's Department? Will irrigation restrictions be necessary? If so, what form will they take? Is the quantity of water guaranteed to South Australia under the River Murray agreement at risk? In view of a series of articles which have appeared recently in the South Australian Press on the question of increasing salinity, does the Minister have contingency plans to ensure that citrus trees and grape vines are not lost as a result of high salinity during this summer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The drought, particularly as it affects the Murray- Darling system, is constantly under my attention. In fact, I receive reports virtually daily. The latest information I have received is that with the continuing dry conditions River Murray tributary inflows are continuing to recede and all storages are falling steadily as water is released to meet system requirements. The present situation with storage is that the Dartmouth Dam, which had filled to something like 70 per cent-this is the one remaining salvation for the Murray-is now down to 47 per cent of full storage capacity. Whilst that is still a significant amount, it is falling. The Hume Reservoir is down to 17 per cent. Senator Hill will know that water from the Dartmouth manages to keep this situation tolerable. Lake Victoria's storage, which is significant to South Australia, is down to 54 per cent. The Menindee Lake storage is down to 55 per cent. So the situation is serious.

ANSWER.PARA: Overall the reserve available to the River Murray Commission is now down to 35 per cent of the total active storage compared with 81 per cent at this time last year. That is very significant. It is likely that if the drought persists storages will be reduced to 10 per cent of total capacity by the end of the current irrigation season. Should the dry conditions continue with further reduction of tributary inflows there may be implications-I am not saying there will be-for the management of the remaining available water resources to meet both the South Australian entitlement, which has first priority and will get that first priority, and planned allocations for New South Wales and Victoria for this season. These matters are constantly under the survey of myself as Minister, my officers and the Snowy Mountains people.

Owing to a number of factors the salinity level in the River Murray has been conspicuously lower than in previous drought conditions. This is due primarily to the availability of the flush from the Dartmouth and other conditions along the river. I would be very happy to provide the Senate and honourable senators with frequent reports on this matter. It is a serious one. We will endeavour to ensure that the supply of water downstream, in both quantity and quality, is maintained to the capacity that we can do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it the case that in the year to October unemployment rose by 168, 000 which is equal to 500 more unemployed people every day? Did this rate increase in the month of October to equal 2,000 a day? Will today's figures on unemployment continue this trend? What impact will the expenditure of $300m have on this collapse in the job market when any wage freeze would further erode consumer spending power by many times this amount?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The most recent unemployment statistics have been given by the Treasurer. They show the increase on what was projected at the time of the Budget. The average unemployment beneficiaries figure is I think 525 ,000 for 1982-83. As far as the day by day statistics or the month by month statistics referred to by the honourable senator are concerned, I take it that he has done his arithmetic correctly. As far as the wage pause and the $300m which the Commonwealth Government will place into employment-related programs are concerned, there will be direct and indirect effects if programs such as welfare housing and so on have the usual spin-off in employment. I cannot put a particular figure on it. If we are looking at the direct and indirect effects I would imagine that they would be quite substantial.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that what was overlooked in the question is the effect of the wage levels in the private sector and the encouragement that can be given by a wage pause to those who may be in financial difficulties so that they can plan their next 12 months' profitability, capital requirements and so on, knowing that there will not be increasing demands for wage increases, improvements in conditions and the sorts of things that usually arise from industrial action. I cannot put figures on what will arise from the wage pause.
As we said yesterday, the $300m that will be available to the Commonwealth Government will be put immediately into employment-related programs and the funds from that--

TALK.START.PARA: —When?
— As soon as the--
—All of it, the $300m?

— As soon as the funds are called for. Next week an Appropriation Bill for $300m will be introduced. I hope it will have a speedy passage. The funds will then be available so that they can be called upon by the Commonwealth Government, the State governments or others who are taking part in the program for the purpose of the expenditure of this $300m.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he has seen the front page story of today's Australian which covers the announcement by Mr Sinclair of a policy statement basically designed to bring together, in one piece of paper, the Government's attitudes towards visits by nuclear ships. I ask the Leader of the Government: Does the Government of the United States of America approve of these new guidelines? Can he explain why the Labor Party is so opposed to visits by United States nuclear warships?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in the paper. Incidentally, it indicates that prior to the announcement by Mr Sinclair of the decision of the Government very detailed studies were made by expert scientists, including scientists from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, as to the nature of the vessels, safeguards and precautionary matters. The conclusions are based upon the most stringent safety measures. Quite clearly, if there is to be an ANZUS treaty then one of the terms of the ANZUS treaty has to be that there must be freedom of movement of the partners in a defence treaty as between the particular countries. If that were not so, the treaty, as Mr Hayden indicated before, would in fact not be viable. It is true that the Victorian Premier at one stage made it clear that he was opposed to the entry of any such vessels into Port Phillip Bay or any Victorian harbour. I think he has retreated from that position now on the grounds that he does not have the powers to stop them. I do not know whether he has changed his views in opposition to them.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday, in response to a question by, I think, Senator Martyr about the buildup of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics' navy in Cam Ranh Bay, Da Nang and elsewhere in Vietnam, I said that if we are to have some kind of a balance for peace in the Pacific and the Indian oceans, there must be the fullest co-operation between Australia and the United States of America. I think the announcement made by Mr Sinclair is of considerable significance. I am sure that the great majority of Australians would commend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The matter to which I refer is within the Prime Minister's responsibility for Public Service matters. Does the Commonwealth insist that certain of its professional employees are registered under some relevant State or Territory legislation? I refer, for example, to medical practitioners and dental officers. Does the Commonwealth not insist that psychologists whom it employs are registered under some State or Territory legislation? If so, how does it determine that those persons whom it employs as psychologists are properly qualified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Colston asks requires some details which are not known to me. I will refer it to the appropriate Minister and get the details for him.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support. In doing so, I point out that Australia purchases the bulk of its capital defence equipment overseas and naturally there is a high usage of spare parts. Will the Minister advise in this connection what arrangements are made for the purchase of these spare parts? What arrangements are made for consultation with Australian industry requiring the production of such spare parts before the acquisition of capital equipment? Is there a facility for small business to be consulted in such matters? Also, should not the procurement of high usage spares for Australian equipment be a mandatory requirement in any negotiations with overseas suppliers of capital equipment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke-Petersen draws our attention to a very important matter which the Government has constantly in mind in regard to defence purchases. In respect of major purchases, the acquisition contract commits the contractor to support its equipment with spare parts for its expected life. However, the Commonwealth always reserves the right to order spares from any supplier or manufacturer selected by the Commonwealth. A further safeguard normally built into contracts is a commitment from the contractor to grant to the Commonwealth a royalty free non-exclusive irrevocable licence to manufacture spare parts in Australia for Commonwealth purposes, should the contractor decide to disperse its own facilities for the manufacture of spare parts. Depending on the nature of the purchase, manufacturing data packs are at times secured as part of any acquisition. But local production of spare parts, being an important aspect of self-sufficiency in the maintenance of equipment in service, is always considered when an Australian industry participation plan is made with an overseas supplier.

ANSWER.PARA: A directory and a data base on local industry capability are maintained and the overseas supplier is encouraged to seek proposals from Australian firms. Small businesses with the relevant and appropriate quality assurance arrangements and capability to work to military specifications are included in this data base. Regional offices exist in all States and monitor the opportunities for small businesses from time to time. Alternatively, work is directed to small business through sub-contract orders from larger Australian defence oriented firms. The supplier is contractually committed to support the equipment for the life of the type. In respect of higher usage items, it is normal practice to develop special arrangements which may include manufacture in Australia to ensure supply and competitive pricing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to two questions I asked the Minister approximately 10 days ago, to which I have received no reply, about the chartering by the Royal Australian Navy of private planes at HMAS Albatross, Nowra. What is the relative cost of hiring these private planes as against using the Navy's own Tracker aircraft? Did the pilots of the private planes have security clearances? Were they given access to classified or secret information before carrying out their assignment on behalf of the Navy? When will I get an answer to the other questions I have asked on this matter as well as an attempted answer to this question?
—I will undertake to refer this later question to the Minister for Defence and also to seek further information as soon as possible on the first questions that he asked.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I preface my question by drawing the Senate's attention to an article headed 'Industrial truce for Christmas' which was front page news yesterday in the Australian newspaper. While we might pause and wonder about a situation in which no strike action makes headline news, I ask the Minister: Has his attention been drawn to the comments at a summit meeting of world industries that strikes are costing each Australian family $3,000 a year? Is the Minister aware that any company considering investing in Australian minerals must add 20 per cent to its costs to allow for losses incurred due to industrial disputes and that the strikes in the Gippsland oil and gas fields alone have cost State and Federal governments $560m in lost revenue? Does the Minister believe the cessation of strikes would do more to help the recovery of our economy and to create more employment than any other single issue, including a wage freeze?

—One thing there is not an argument about in this chamber is that Australia is going through some very difficult times. There are things that we can do which will influence that in a positive way. There are other things which are beyond our control. The Government has tried to tackle a range of matters which affect Australia, whether by trying to encourage international trade or, most recently, this week in its meeting with the Premiers, by trying to obtain their support for a wage pause. I suppose one of the unhappiest features of unnecessary strike action is that it is so obviously avoidable. The cost to the Australian economy, to the work force and, indeed, to us all is something of which I do not have a measure. I cannot say that the American estimates referred to by the honourable senator are correct. But what is beyond doubt is that they are an unnecessary cost to this community. I would have thought that, given the consensus on the difficulty of the times, there would be some moderation of the trade union movement's attitude towards strikes. Unfortunately, this week we have seen some very poor examples of activity which is clearly costing Australia dearly. I do not wish to say a great deal. Members of the Cabinet will be meeting with the Australian Council of Trade Unions shortly. I hope those talks will be permeated with a common desire to avoid unnecessary industrial disputes which are so costly to us all.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Evans asked me a question concerning directions which I gave in September 1981 to the Aboriginal Development Commission in connection with the acquisition of interests by the newly formed Anungu Pitjantjatjaruku following the passage of the Pitjantjatjara Land Rights Act in South Australia. I have been looking back through the documents although I am not sure we have them all. I can advise Senator Evans that I did not give any general direction under section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act and for that reason no tabling was made in the Parliament; it was not required. At the request of the Aboriginal Development Commission I did give a direction under section 8 (g) of the Act in order to provide enabling power for the Aboriginal Development Commission to undertake a function which it wished to undertake.

ANSWER.PARA: The background is in the context of the Pitjantjatjara Land Rights Bill. While the land was transferred to Anungu Pitjantjatjaruku the reversionary leasehold interests continued with leaseholders although the title to the land had passed to the Pitjantjatjara people. The powers of the Aboriginal Development Commission did not allow it at that time to try to purchase either certain improvements or leases as they became vacant; nor did they allow it to make an arrangement with the leaseholders to pay them for the loss of future enjoyment. The Aboriginal Development Commission took the decision that the acquisition of Granite Downs was a high priority. That decision by the ADC was confirmed in a letter dated 10 July 1980 from Mr Charles Perkins to my predecessor as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Chaney. Therefore, in fact, it was an ADC initiative that the acquisition of Granite Downs was important and it came from the Aboriginal people.

Subsequent consultation between the ADC and the Attorney-General's Department led that Department to suggest to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs that an extra power should be conferred on the ADC to allow payment to be made in relation to the transfer of Granite Downs. On 2 October 1981 the Aboriginal Development Commission issued a Press release announcing the conclusion of the arrangements. It indicated that the ADC was pleased to be involved and was pleased with the arrangements. I believe that answers the most substantial point in Senator Evans's question. I am sure he will let me know if there are other matters he wants answered.
