PROCTEXT.PARA: Report on Grants Approval for 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We have before us a report on the grants approved for 1983 under the Australian Research Grants Scheme. It illustrates yet again that we have in Australia a very extensive research foundation in all areas of scientific and humanitarian endeavour in our universities. When one reads the variety of the schemes that have been funded for the coming year, one is impressed by the extent of the detailed research that is being undertaken.

I wish to raise a point in relation to funding which I have raised on many occasions and which I will probably be forced to raise in the future. The historical context has always been that the vast bulk of funds for basic research has come from governments. If one notes the titles set out in the report it becomes apparent that most of the research contemplated falls in that category. The funding available to universities from private industry has not been great, but an examination of current trends reveals that it is growing in a number of areas and for a number of reasons.

In keeping with trends in other countries, many private firms are now seeking in respect of a number of important areas to support research, undertaken by universities, that they believe will be beneficial in the short and long terms in relation to the particular products that they produce or areas of activity in which they are engaged. The major area in which such participation began some years ago, was that of agricultural science. Expenditure in that area has been rapidly overtaken by expenditures in what became the glamour industries of the day, for instance, the computer industry. Probably in recent times the growth area, in the United States in particular, in regard to the linkage between tertiary institutions and industry, has been that of biotechnology. This involves ethical questions in relation to research, an area in which we will have to tread very warily. In the United States many researchers in tertiary institutions have themselves established private companies whose sole output is certain biological techniques for use by various industries. It does not take much imagination to appreciate the problems that can very easily arise if a professor who is engaged in a particular line of research has his post-graduate students assist him in an area of activity which coincides with the work that he is doing in his private company. While one should not immediately point to a conflict of interest where one finds that happening--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not just in connection with biotechnology; it is a general problem.

—The problem is general but has become much more acute in regard to biotechnology because of the ease with which a person with specialised knowledge is able to sell that knowledge rather than a product. Thus, basically, what is involved is the sale of knowledge. Previously that has not offered a sufficiently high financial return to make it worth while for many professors to undertake more than consultation, which has always been a factor in university life. However, the technical problems involved in consulting have been resolved. What I am referring to is totally different. I refer to the involvement of post- graduate students who are the responsibility of a staff member of a university and the question of what they ought to be doing with their time if they are engaged upon research which is of financial benefit to the staff member in his own private company. The United States universities, particularly the main ones, have adopted a variety of rules governing this area, and the proceedings of the various staff association meetings and conferences held within the past year that I have been able to read would suggest that it is not a problem which is easily solved.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, Australia has the chance to overcome much of that problem if we move relatively rapidly and seek some intervening method of allowing private enterprise to channel its funds to universities through a public foundation of some kind or another. A private enterprise is perfectly entitled when it seeks to give funds to universities to have those funds tied to particular research outcomes. There is not much point in a particular private company funding across the board. Indeed, I think it would find it very hard to justify that to its shareholders. Therefore, most private companies would seek to look at a particular item or area of research, or a particular line that a researcher is taking and which looks fruitful in terms of that company's product or line of business. I believe that if we had a research foundation through which this money could be channelled we could then fairly easily establish arm's length arrangements with the researcher and the private funder to avoid many of the acute problems that have occurred in the United States and in other countries that have had, as a history of research funding, research funding which comes particularly from private enterprise. That, and because of its historical development, is why it has been felt so acutely in the United States. Australia has never had that historical development and I believe we could now move and the Government could now move towards looking at this issue in a fairly urgent manner so as to avoid the possible occurrence of the major ethical problems that have occurred overseas.

I believe from discussions with many researchers in Australia that they would welcome a raising of this issue to a much higher profile than it currently has, and not leaving it to individual universities but possibly seeking from the Vice -Chancellors Committee the setting up of a sub-committee with the Government whereby this issue may be aired and some type of procedure set down across the board that would be of benefit to researchers because they then would be clear as to the guidelines which would be available in the future.

The other item that I am concerned about and which I have raised with the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) by way of a question to which the Minister is seeking a response from his Department-since I asked it only last week I believe he has not been able to acquire that information-is the recurring brain drain from this country that we have had from time to time. We had it in relation to the computer industry and now we have it in relation to biotechnology. I believe that this problem needs to be looked at in a most urgent fashion because head hunters particularly from European countries are appearing at our universities looking for our best talent in those areas. We must not allow the people with these talents to go, certainly not for the sake of a small research grant which would keep them here.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In a sense, this is a routine report of the Department. I want to mention two issues which arise from the report. The first is the amount of Government grant for the support of public broadcasting stations in Australia, which is currently $138,000. In addition to that sum, the Government makes money available to public broadcasters which provide ethnic affairs programs, under the appropriate department appropriations. That is an additional amount which is almost a fee for service in respect of those programs which are provided. I want to stress the importance of the developments which have occurred in public broadcasting, with now some 60 radio stations operating in Australia. That is important, and it has been the result of a bipartisan policy. Many of those stations are operating on shoestring budgets, having great difficulties in keeping afloat. It is necessary that our public broadcasting system now be put on a rational financial basis.

The Opposition's view about this matter is that the public broadcasting system should be set up on the basis of a capital grant by government provided to a foundation, the income from which would be used to provide recurrent expenses for public broadcasting stations. That has two benefits. First, it provides secure income in addition to the other incomes from subscriptions, radiothons and so on which public broadcasters have as sources of income; it also assures the independence and integrity of the public broadcasting system, which is now an important assest which is being wasted because of inadequate recurrent funding.

The second point I make is revealed in the report. It is simply that there is a very serious problem of developing communication services because of lack of planning in relation to licences and the backlogs which have occurred in the planning of new radio and television licences. Earlier this year I asked a question of the then Minister, Mr Sinclair, as to what was the delay in planning for development of new services. The answer I got was that it was 10 years. I understand that since then the estimate has been reduced to seven or eight years . The delay is still ridiculous in terms of new services. The Department just does not appear to have the resources, either intellectual or financial, to cope with this problem at present. It will be a problem which emerges again very strongly when the Senate, as I anticipate, next week, passes legislation providing for supplementary licences in regional areas of Australia, many of which are likely to be given to existing regional radio and television operators . There is no future in the Senate passing that legislation if the backlog of planning is 10 years behind. If we pass that legislation next week, it will be years before any effect flows from its passage if this matter is not dealt with as quickly as possible. Otherwise, I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of Aussat Pty Ltd is important. Aussat is the company which the Government established to manage and develop the Australian domestic satellite. I remind the Senate of the timetable for the development of the satellite. In October 1979 a decision was reached to proceed with the satellite. A number of subsequent decisions have been made and the satellite system is to be operational by mid-1985. To do all this the Government formed a company in which it owns all the shares. But the Government has announced that 49 per cent will be vested in private ownership. Unhappily, the directors of the satellite company come from all major media groups and regional television interests and, happily, from the Isolated Children's Parents Association. Unhappily, I record the fact that neither the Australian Telecommunications Commission nor the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which are both projected to be major users of the satellite, are represented on the board of that body.

The Government recently floated the idea of allowing 51 per cent private ownership of the satellite. It has done this because it is having difficulty attracting capital for the satellite project. It is not a very good investment or a very advisable investment in the first stage of the satellite development. There is a certain reluctance to invest in it, or anything else, at the moment.

But I want to make quite clear the Opposition's view that it is important that the majority shareholding of the satellite and majority control on the board of the satellite be vested in the Government. It is simply a sound principle of common carrier telecommunications systems that they should be controlled by government. It is a sound principle in two ways. Firstly, governments or government bodies have the capacity to develop new technologies in a way which is equal as between citizens and as between business users. That is very important. If one business user has control of a communications system other business users are prejudiced as a result of that control by one competitor. It is important to ensure fairness between citizens and between businesses in the common carrier telecommunications systems.

That is the first reason why this question of ownership of the satellite is important-the distribution, as it were, of new technology on an equal basis. A number of other reasons, including the protection of individual privacy, are also related to that issue. The other principle which is involved is that of separating the hardware from the software, as it were. It is an important principle that private enterprise or a diverse range of sources should as far as possible be involved in developing programs, software and so on, but that the hardware should be in the hands of a neutral authority in order to ensure the best operation of the system as a whole for the benefit of the community.

A number of things related to the satellite have not been sorted out by the Government. A number of issues remain important ones for decision. The first is the question of ownership, about which I have just expressed some views. The second point is that currently there is no planning for a proper relationship betwen the satellite system and the terrestrial system of communications in Australia. That is to say, in a sense, each is developing without any regard to the resources involved in the other. Australia has billions of dollars invested in a terrestrial communications system. We are now investing millions of dollars in a satellite communications system. They both provide the same service: The terrestrial system provides it across the ground, as it were; the satellite provides it by transmitting a signal from the ground to the satellite and back to earth. There is a very real need for co-ordination and for proper relationships to be established between the development of the satellite and the terrestrial system of communications which already exists. If a proper relationship is established, the people will obtain the best service from the communications system as a whole.

A third matter for decision in relation to the satellite is the question of alternative proposals now being canvassed for commercial television networks to use the high powered transponders throughout Australia. This involves important issues, not just in terms of a difference between the Government and the Opposition, but also within various constituents of the Government parties. If there is a three network capacity to develop, for example, television programs and to transmit them across Australia, the development of local services which are desirable in the interests of particular local communities can be excluded, at least in part. For example, I was in Western Australia last week and found considerable concern about the possibility of the three major networks having the capacity to use the satellite on the high powered transponders to, as it were, blanket Western Australia with eastern State network programs. The same sort of thing can, in a sense, happen in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Weren't assurances given that that would not be permitted to happen?

—No. The Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) has recently said that he is reconsidering that matter. Assurances were given at an earlier stage but the matter is now being reconsidered. It has implications for places like Western Australia. The Western Australian view is that that State should have a footprint from the satellite and that that would be controlled by Western Australian television interests. There is something to be said for that view. In part it might be regarded as a parochial view, but there is also an important aspect of localism in it which should be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: Having previously made a decision but then having been agitated by Kerry Packer , or someone else who is influential with the Liberal Party, to provide this capacity on the satellite for the three television networks, the Minister has been forced into changing that decision. All the power brokers of the communications industry are at work in relation to that matter. I take the view that the transponders should not be available to the three major networks in the way in which they desire because in my view that will exclude not only the capacity, in the long term, of regional television stations to operate and of localism to be present in Austrlian programming, but also it will exclude the capacity to develop new services in the outback of Australia which meet the peculiar requirements of people living in those areas. The technology is available to do that now by using the satellite, but it would not be a relevant technology if the transponders were made available exclusively to the big networks.

The fourth important decision relating to the satellite is how it is to be used in the development of telephony services. Honourable senators will remember that when the satellite was first mooted it was the thing to talk about its importance to outback communities. That has declined somewhat as a priority in more recent years. I think it is very important that proper use be made of the satellite in the provision of telephone services to outback users. There is currently a fight between the Department of Communications and Telecom Australia about how that will happen and that issue has to be resolved.

Finally, there is the very important question of access to the satellite for small users; not the big companies but those who, whether they be educational bodies, medical services or Aboriginal communities seeking additional broadcasting services-there are a number of relatively small groups-can gain great benefit from it. I suspect that the interests of those groups have not been looked after as well as they should have. Those are the issues arising from the satellite development at this stage which provide for concern and consideration by this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to make one or two comments on the annual report of Aussat Pty Ltd and endorse what Senator Button has said about the need to provide access to smaller television operators who are performing a very useful service throughout the more remote parts of Australia, away from the metropolitan areas. I believe it is a most important point. I endorse what he said and hope that the Government and the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) will take note of it and ensure that these operators are provided with access to the satellite.

SPEECH.PARA: I also believe that the parochial matter to which Senator Button referred-that is, the provision of local news services in country areas-is most important. At the moment in South Australia, for example, at Leigh Creek and Streaky Bay the television service is provided by satellite. The people in those areas are forced to view New South Wales news services rather than their local South Australian country news service. Local news is very important to the people who are interested in their area and this point should be taken note of. I understand that ultimately, when our satellite is in position, Leigh Creek and Streaky Bay will be able to receive a different sort of news service, a combination perhaps of South Australian and Northern Territory news. I ask the Government to have regard to the comments that have been made by Senator Button, which I support.
Question received in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a routine report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, but it raises two general problems to which I want to refer. Firstly, it discusses the criticisms that have been made of the Broadcasting Tribunal's report on cable television. I want to reiterate the undesirability of Australia developing cable television systems at this stage. I want to say why.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or even RSTV.

—Possibly, as the honourable senator says, even radiated subscription television. There is a separate case for that. I will deal first with the cable issue. There is in certain circles great enthusiasm for cable television. It is a sort of Dr Spock thing. If any new piece of technology exists, the children should have it. One must make value judgments about whether that is desirable. My value judgement is that it is not desirable or in the interests of this country. I want to stress the reasons for that. It is very costly to install cable television in Australia. It will cost billions of dollars. It is sometimes said: 'It is private enterprise which would develop it, so who are governments to say how they should spend their money?' There are a number of other issues in respect of which governments must make value judgments .

SPEECH.PARA: I believe there has been no proper consideration of the economic consequences of the installation of cable television, particularly on existing television stations. There has been no proper consideration of the effects of the introduction of cable television on the Australian television production industry. We have by and large developed a system of television in Australia which is far from perfect and, in my view, highly inadequate. Yet by world standards it is not a bad system. Most major cities are provided with three or four major television outlets. There is some degree of choice. Certain bipartisan rules have been established. Those rules are that television stations should be viable and, being viable, should provide a range of programs, particularly in the area of Australian content. The levels of Australian content have improved.

If we introduce cable television into Australia under the guidelines provided by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-in its report it referred to cable television as the era of abundance of choice-the first thing that will happen is that those channels which are additionally available as a result of cable systems will be programmed almost exclusively from the United States and they will be programmed cheaply. The effect of that is that if there are no Australian content rules for cable television the other television networks in Australia could say: 'Why do we have to produce Australian programs when the cable people can buy them so cheaply from the United States?' Cable television is a piece of classical technological mythology which is not appropriate to this country.

Senator Harradine raised by way of interjection the question of radiated subscription television services. This is another issue but in a sense it runs into the same argument, perhaps in a lesser way, that if radiated subscription television services are developed in Australia with no Australian or local content requirement they will affect very much the standard of programming which we already get on the existing television channels. This is a matter about which we ought to beware. We should not look at these questions of cable television and RSTV in isolation.

The Government gave the Broadcasting Tribunal very narrow terms of reference. Important terms of reference which should be given are: What new broadcasting services do we want, not just in terms of the availability of new technology but also in terms of the provisions of services and social criteria which we have established in this country on an almost bipartisan basis; and, how do we deliver these services that we want, whether by way of cable television, UHF, satellite or whatever? There is no resolution of those questions. There has to be before we proceed to spend vast sums of money in this area. This Government listens too much to interest groups and writes terms of reference in response to interest groups. Then when it gets the answers it is suddenly confronted with the real decisions that have to be made in the interests of the community.

The second point I would make is that there is a desperate need to spell out the broad policies governing Australian broadcasting services. No goals have been established in broadcasting in this country by this Government and it is a disaster. It is a disaster to the industry and a disaster to the standards of service which are available because it affects them in a detrimental way.

Some of those guidelines must relate to the issues I have addressed. The economic requirement of preserving in Australia an indigenous communications industry providing a high level of its own programming involves a degree of protectionism which is vastly different from the protectionism which we talk about in relation to the car manufacturing industry. I do not want to go on record about that, but let me say that I am in favour of protectionism in the broadcasting industry for the simple reason that a broadcasting system provides the major means of communication and provision of national identity in a country such as this. If a broadcasting system is cluttered with foreign programs to the exclusion of Australian programs something is lost in the social and cultural life of this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the car industry.

—I resist replying to any interjections, Mr Acting Deputy President. Questions of Australian or local content, for example, were thrown out of the window in the cable report. I shudder to use the words 'local content ' when they relate to broadcasting because they are also used in terms of another industry. Many of these matters were not adequately addressed in terms of community needs and social concern. Otherwise, I commend the report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I think that some very hard thinking has to be done about the issues which are inherent in broadcasting policy in Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later, unless anyone wishes to speak at this moment. Senator Harradine desires to speak at a later time. This is why I seek leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report contains some matters which I believe ought to be noted by the Senate . It does raise some concerns about the administration of the scheme and the funding of the total scheme. It raises some concerns about shortcomings in the arrangements inherent in the scheme whereby the Ministerial Council of the Federal Minister and the six State Ministers is responsible for the provision of funds. It is a matter which was referred to by Senate Estimates Committee A in its report to this chamber a couple of months ago. I do not want to discuss those matters in detail today although I believe that they ought to be considered by the Senate in due course.

I note that Senator Walsh rose at the same time as I did and that he apparently wishes to speak on this matter. If so, I simply ask whether he will seek leave to continue his remarks so that at a later stage I can seek leave to speak again . It seems to me that that is the most appropriate arrangement to follow, if I understand Senator Walsh correctly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans would normally speak on this report on behalf of the Opposition. In his absence, I would like to make a few comments. The report maintains the high standards set in previous reports. In particular, it gives a clear, comprehensive account of the first year of operation of the Takeovers and Securities Industry Codes. It notes that during the year the National Companies and Securities Commission was notified of 164 proposals for takeovers and that 400 foreign investment proposals were referred to it by the Foreign Investment Review Board. It is noted-I think it is a very important figure-at page 11 of the report that the Commission estimates that a total of 564,000 companies are registered under the Australian companies legislation, only 986 of which are companies listed on the various stock exchanges.

SPEECH.PARA: It is noted, interestingly I think, that the National Companies and Securities Commission has prepared or is preparing a discussion paper on the subject of financial disclosure requirements which ought to be available next month. On the question of the very large number of companies which are registered, one would have to be extremely naive to believe that there was any commercial justification for more than half a million companies in this country. Many of these companies-not all of them, by any means-as my colleague, Ralph Jacobi has frequently noted in the House of Representatives, are tools used by corporate crooks and spivs rather than legitimate institutional arrangements for the conduct of business.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage of them is now at the bottom-of-the-harbour?

—About one per cent according to the latest estimates of the Commissioner of Taxation. That is a very important point made by Senator Rae. The ease with which companies can be established in Australia with a shareholder 's liability of only $2 is something which facilitates corporate crime in its various forms rather than the conduct of legitimate and productive business. When the comparable report was tabled last year, attention was drawn to the inclusion of policy statements in these annual reports-a practice which has been continued this year and which is welcomed by the Opposition. Chapter 3 of the report deals with the funding of the Commission. When referring to the procedures which have been adopted in the past, the Commission comments that the procedures:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . provide no opportunity, before the amounts of funding are settled and appropriation processes commence,
for the proposed level of funding to be reported to and reviewed collectively by the Ministerial Council;
for the Ministerial Council to have consultations with or receive submissions from the Commission; or
for the Commission's views to be obtained for inclusion in a disagreed bids submission.
The Commission concludes-this was confirmed by Mr Schoer, the Executive Director of the Commission, before Senate Estimates Committee A last September-that in the year ending 30 June 1982:

. . . the Commission's receipt of funds from all parties was haphazard and unpredictable-thus diminishing the Commission's opportunity of obtaining supplementary income from the rigorous management of cash on a daily basis and causing delays in payments to creditors.

The Australian Financial Review of 17 September reported on the discussion of matter at the Estimates committees. I understand that the Ministerial Council meeting in November settled on new funding arrangements. This question of funding and lack of clear accountability to any parliament highlights the problems of what is euphemistically described as co-operative federalism and could in this instance I think be more accurately described as a refusal by or a reluctance of the Federal Government to accept its responsibilities as a national government. It was a function of the decision taken at Maroochydore almost four years ago to settle on what is essentially a lowest common denominator approach to the regulation of companies, stock exchanges and the securities industry, the lowest common denominator approach being the weakest legislation for which unanimous agreement can be obtained from all the State governments.

Although I certainly make no claims to being an authority on this subject, I was a member of the Senate committee which in 1975 inquired into the then National Companies and Securities Industry Bill which was before the Parliament. For many days we heard contrary opinions from learned Queen's Counsel on whether the Commonwealth had the power effectively to legislate in this area in a pre- emptive way. If lawyers were permitted to argue about that subject ad infinitum I have no doubt that they would. It seemed to me, as a layman, to be perfectly clear that the correct and responsible decision for a Commonwealth government to take was to legislate and then to let the courts finally establish whether the Commonwealth had the constitutional power to do so. The matter will never be resolved by talk fests between lawyers but only by, firstly, legislative action in this Commonwealth Parliament and, secondly, judicial action in the courts if and when that becomes necessary.

The November meeting of the Ministerial Council is reported as having approved 'a fairly substantial increase on the initial 1982-83 funding of $3.1m'. The Commission states that its staffing 'was a source of continuing concern thoughout the year'. The report indicates that a staff ceiling has now been set at 65 for this year, but without an assurance that funds would be granted. However, it was reported, following the Ministerial Council meeting in November, that the Ministerial Council had approved a staff level of 62 for this year, which implicitly, of course, carries the obligation to provide adequate funds for that level. It appears that this relatively new commission is doing a satisfactory job, with the one caveat which I lodged before, given the constraints imposed upon it-that is, the essential lowest common denominator approach to this question-which the Commonwealth has adopted. I seek leave to continue my remarks later, Mr Acting Deputy President.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak briefly on this matter on this occasion. I hope that we will have a fuller debate on this very important report at a later date. The Administrative Review Council and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have been important innovations in reviewing administrative decisions in this country, not only providing people with a means of appealing against those decisions but also , as a result of their actions, providing now and I hope in the future a more consistent process of administrative decision making so that people can have some sense of certainty in their dealings with the bureaucracy and with the Government in particular. I think a very good example of this is in fact what has happened in social security appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As the Review Council said, when speaking about the nature of appeals in the social security area:

The most striking feature of the statistics is that the workload, which is principally comprised of invalid pensions cases, come mainly from Victoria and Queensland. The explanation lies in the proportion of cases passing through the Department's appeal procedures, including SSAT--
That is, the social security appeals tribunals-

review, which are fully or partly conceded by the Department. Until the last quarter of 1981, that proportion was lowest in Victoria, Queensland and Tasmania . In the last quarter of 1981, the proportion of appeals allowed in whole or in part in Victoria increased markedly.

This, of course, was a result of the very fact that people could go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; but it was also a result of decisions which were made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the case of invalid pensions . It was expected that when the social security appeals provision was established in the tribunals unemployment benefit cases, single parent pension cases, particularly involving disputes over what was or was not a bona fide domestic relationship, would in fact fill most of the cases which appeared before the Tribunal. In fact, invalid pension cases have done so and they have done so in a most uneven way. I make the point that this demonstrates that what the Opposition has been saying in the last couple of years and what all welfare organisations, such as the Australian Council of Social Service have been saying in the last two years, is a fact. We said that all was not well in the administration of invalid pensions in this country, that in fact there was a great unevenness in the way that people were treated-there still is. We said that there was not only an unevenness between individuals but also an unevenness in the administration and interpretation of the legislation and guidelines between States. That unevenness was such that in Victoria and Queensland, where complaints were very frequent and where the administration was very harsh, a large number of appeals appeared.

If we are to have a national security system and if we are to have it administered from this Parliament we should have consistency throughout the country so that everyone can be treated in the same manner. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Review Council in this document have demonstrated that that just has not happened in the past, that some officers and some delegates of the Director-General of Social Services, in the States of Victoria and Queensland in particular, have been extremely harsh in their administration of this Act. At last we can get some consistency of guidelines through the decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I am sure this occurs in other areas but social security happens to be my area of interest. I hope that this indication that all is not well will be taken to heart by the Government and by the senior echelons of the bureaucracy in dealing with these sensitive areas. I hope that when we have had time to peruse this important report we will have a fuller and more sensible debate on the subject. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome the appearance of the report from the Australian Film and Television School. I suppose the first thing to say about it-perhaps Senator Peter Rae will have noticed this, too-is that the report is on time. It is the 1981-82 annual report and its appearance is welcomed. I should say, too, that the Chairman of the School, Mr Ferguson, and the council ought to be congratulated on the preparation of the report. There is no doubt that the Australian Film and Television School is serving a very useful purpose in developing the talents of young Australians for work in all aspects of the film industry and the television industry in this country. Indeed, in recent years, the School has extended its activities to provide radio training. There can be no doubt either that the learning experiences offered at the School are appropriate and relevant to the industries for which they are preparing these people.

The history of the success of graduates of the School is really quite outstanding. I draw the Senate's attention to some well known names in the film industry. If we look at the awards and recognitions granted in the last year to graduates from the interim training scheme of 1973-74 we see such outstanding names as Gillian Armstrong, Christopher Noonan, Phillip Noyce, James Ricketson, Graham Shirley, David Stocker, and later on Martha Ansara, Ned Lander, Gillian Coote, Ken Kelso and so on. So we are very pleased with the way in which students at the Australian Film and Television School have been able to develop their abilities and make outstanding contributions to the Australian film industry.

The general employment record of graduates of the School has been outstanding up till now but I wish to say more about that at a later stage. The other matters in the report that I want to commend the School on concern the extension of its open program. This means that not only are people living in Sydney in proximity to the Australian Film and Television School involved in the School, but also people throughout Australia interested in developing skills in this area are able to take advantage of the resources of the School through the open program. That is to be commended. I hope that that program will expand even further in forthcoming years.

I am particularly pleased also to see that the School has entered into the area of training for radio and, in particular, has been training some Aboriginal people to work in the area of radio. The success of Aboriginal radio is fairly recent but quite outstanding. I refer particularly to the success of CAMA, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association, which now operates radio programming throughout a very large area of Central Australia in a number of Aboriginal languages and has provided training and employment opportunities in this very crucial communications area for people who previously were totally disadvantaged in the area of communications. CAMA is not the only organisation involved in Aboriginal broadcasting. Since its success there have been other developments in other parts of Australia. I am pleased to see the Australian Film and Television School now co-operating with this development in this crucial area of Aboriginal life and providing further training facilities.

The School, since it started training full time graduates in 1975, has an outstanding record. It has expanded and adjusted its programs to take account of a wide variety of needs in this area throughout Australia. However, what is of great concern to the Opposition and, I think, to everybody working in the Australian film and television industry is the future for future students and graduates from this School. In the last few months I have raised many times in this place the crisis that the Australian film industry is facing. I have pointed out to the Senate and to the Treasurer, Mr Howard-my representations have been supported by unions covering the entertainment industries, by producers' associations, and by delegations from the film industry to Canberra- that two major factors over which the Government has control have undermined the Australian film industry to the point where it is really on the verge of collapse. Those two factors are matters concerning available tax concessions to attract private investment in films.

The first very damaging operation within Australia affecting our Australian industry is the use being made by certain film production companies of section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act which enables the promotors of this scheme to offer a 375 per cent tax concession for investment in foreign films. Specifically, such investment has been in American films. That concession, offering 375 per cent on any money invested, is much more generous than the concession scheme set up by the Government ostensibly to assist the local industry. The Government's scheme operating under Section 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act offers 150 per cent tax concession. This, in itself, is quite a generous concession but obviously it is unable to compete with the 375 per cent concession being offered by the operators of schemes such as United American and Australasian Film Productions.

The other very objectionable aspect of the section 51 (1) scheme is that there is no requirement for the investment to be in Australian films. The Government's own scheme, the section 10BA scheme, requires that any films that are to get the benefit of this provision must be certified as Australian by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. That process is a quite lengthy one-a quite cumbersome one in fact. Then, at the end stage of production, that certifcate of eligibility for the scheme must be endorsed by the Australian Taxation Office. Of course, the Australian Labor Party supports the fact that the concession should be limited to Australian films. It is very clear that the Australian film industry does need assistance of this kind and does need a particular attraction to get a proper amount of private investment into the local industry. We object- the whole of the Australian industry objects-to the fact that the UAA type of scheme, the section 51 (1) scheme, does not require that investment be in Australian films. Indeed, to date, it has not. We have had this syphoning off of investment money that ought to have been available to go into the Australian industry. It has gone into American films. The Australian Government has been most negligent in coming to terms with this.

The matter has been raised on numerous occasions throughout the year. Only yesterday my colleague in the other place, Mr Barry Jones, asked the Treasurer, Mr Howard, what his response would be to the representations concerning the use of section 51 (1) by the industry and other matters raised with him. His reply indicated that he has been paying very little attention at all to this urgent matter. His initial reply was that he had not received a report from the working party looking into the matter of tax concessions in the Australian film industry . He later came back and corrected that information. In fact, the working party had reported some time ago and Mr Howard is waiting on a comment from the Taxation Office. The fact that Mr Howard was unable to give accurate information the first time the question was asked is indicative of the low priority that the Government is giving to this crucial matter.

The other serious problem for the film industry concerns the operation of the Government's own scheme. In that case the difficulty is that, in order for investors to get the benefits of the taxation concession in the year in which they make the investment-obviously this is what investors want to do-the film has to be conceived, developed, made and be out producing revenue within a 12- month cycle. When the Government introduced this provision I warned that it would have a very deleterious effect on the operation of the industry, that it would cause bunching of production in one part of the year and serious unemployment in the rest of the year. This has happened and this is also one of the reasons why in this year so far only six feature films are scheduled for production compared with the 30 which were made last year. At least two of the six films currently scheduled are under threat unless Mr Howard is able to make a statement clarifying the attitude of the Government towards concessions in the film industry, ruling out section 51 (1) and in particular allowing time for the completion of films under the Government's own scheme to be extended to 24 months. If Mr Howard does not make in the next few days a statement to that effect I am afraid the graduates of the Film and Television School, of which we are all justifiably proud, will be facing a long and bleak period of unemployment because the Australian film industry will have no future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report put down by the Administrator of Norfolk Island, Mr Trebilco, reveals some difficulties. I believe that concern ought to be expressed in the Senate about what is happening on Norfolk Island. I think there is a clear case of there being something rotten on Norfolk Island. Despite the fact that Norfolk Island is a delightful place, there appears to be a number of considerable difficulties in public administration and in the ability of the island to continue to attract tourism. Consequently, I think it is essential to make some comment in respect of this report.

I do not want to get involved in attacking the current Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh), embattled as he is as a result of the infamous decision made by this weak-kneed Government in respect of South West Tasmania. At least Mr McVeigh put forward to the Cabinet the correct decision that this Government ought to have taken in respect of South West Tasmania. However, he was overridden by the obvious troglodytes who dominate the present Fraser Administration. My criticisms would be somewhat muted by such an embattled Minister. The previous Minister, Mr Wilson, is equally embattled in respect of the administration of Aboriginal affairs. However, I believe he has some responsibilities in respect of this report even though he has moved on to a different portfolio. Aboriginal communities in Australia are demanding his resignation and expressing their lack of confidence in his administration of Aboriginal affairs. One can only say that as a result of the constant shifting of ministerial responsibilities by the Fraser Government and by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in particular there is political instability on Norfolk Island.

This situation has been particularly emphasised since the 1982 elections on the island. The chief administrating officer resigned after disagreement with the Legislative Assembly. He was then dismissed by the Assembly, reinstated and then pensioned off by the current Minister, Mr McVeigh. That is a pretty unsatisfactory state of affairs. Obviously these sorts of difficulties and this sort of instability have resulted in a period of uncertainty and confusion on the island. The inhabitants-the islanders; the people who in fact in every sense of the word are the owners of the island-have petitioned for new elections. The new electoral system to be used will be, strangely enough, a modified Hare- Clarke proportional representation system under which the residents will use crosses instead of numbers with a view, I presume, of getting a better result and a better form of self-government. It is interesting that this Government, and particularly those National Party members of it who had so much critical comment to make about my proposals for a new form of proportional representation in the House of Representatives, should in fact be maintaining those very principles in respect of Norfolk Island.

Of course, special tax exemptions are given to residents and companies wholly owned and controlled by residents who earn income on the island. I will not go into what I said several months ago about the infamous and nefarious activities of one of the members of the Assembly, Mr Terence Brown, other than to say that he is still on the island and obviously using the weaknesses in our tax legislation to help himself to larger slices of income and evading his tax responsibilities.

I think it is also worth referring to the fact that one of the judges of the Norfolk Island Supreme Court is none other than another person whom some people might regard as infamous. However, I like to steer clear of personalities. That person is Mr Justice Dunphy, who I think has been referred to in the other place as a 76-year-old judge who refuses to retire and continues to receive full pay. I am informed that most of his staff are members of his own family. It would seem to me that the presence of such a person to administer justice in the affairs of Norfolk Island would contribute towards some concern and uncertainty on the island.

The tourist industry has been regarded as the mainstay of the Norfolk Island economy. That industry has declined considerably. Of course, there will be dire consequences if that trend continues. Clearly there is something wrong when this is happening to an industry on such a beautiful island which has been a very popular place with tourists. The number of Australian visitors to the island in the last year has declined by 16.18 per cent. New Zealanders have stopped going there to the extent of 30 per cent. I remember seeing a large number of American visitors when I was on the island some years ago. The number of overseas tourists has decreased by 53 per cent. There has been an overall drop of 23.67 per cent in tourism. That represents something like 5,500 people. That, of course, must be a reflection of the way in which the island is perceived and the administration operates. The decline in tourism has dire consequences on the island's resources and well-being. This problem needs to be addressed. It seems to me that the Government should assist the local administration to rectify this decline.

The value of goods sold on the island has also declined considerably in the past year. Of course, Norfolk Island is not now a duty free port. Not only has the Australian economy declined as a result of the inept policies being pursued by the Fraser Government but also this decline is having an effect on a place that has all the delights that anyone could want. Everything about this Government smacks of decline, deficiency and ineffectiveness in respect of its responsibilities in the public and private sectors.

One of the major setbacks to the tourist industry on Norfolk Island was the requirement, which I find hard to understand, that all Australian visitors must have a passport identity. Norfolk Island is part of our Commonwealth but Australian citizens who want to travel there on holidays must go through the process of getting either a passport or some form of citizen identity. That seems to me to be somewhat ludicrous and without justification, yet that procedure has been introduced in recent times. Instead of having free movement we have now had this impediment introduced.

Another factor, one in which I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, will be interested, involves the conservation of Norfolk Island's flora and fauna species, which are now in a very critical state. Only 18 to 28 of the Norfolk Island green parrots are thought to remain. In recent times there has been a decline in their numbers. Also, of the two very rare types of trees that exist on the island I am told that only four specimens remain of one and 30 of another . Therefore one can only say that the whole way in which the administration of Norfolk Island operates is in a very unsatisfactory state. Responsibility for that must clearly be placed at the door of the Fraser Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERVISING SCIENTIST FOR THE ALLIGATOR RIVER REGION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is quite an important report. As the Senate is aware, the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the environment has a continuing responsibility to exercise oversight of all matters relating to pollution. Accordingly, the Committee has visited the Kakadu National Park area on four occasions. The first was before mining commenced, the second was after it had begun and the third was after processing had commenced. The Committee also visited the area subsequently . It is very important that this sort of surveillance should continue. It is some time since we visited the area, but I believe it will be necessary for the Committee to examine the report in depth and undoubtedly, as a result, it will wish to revisit the area to investigate aspects that have been brought out.
I note that on page 12 of the report, on the subject of the infringement of environmental requirements, the following statement appears:

Under Clause 5 of both the Ranger and Nabarlek Environmental Requirements, the companies are required to ensure that all staff and persons for whom they are responsible observe the provisions of the Environmental Requirements. The companies have agreed to report infringements immediately to the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy and forward copies of such reports to the Supervising Scientist and the Northern Land Council. 'Nil returns' are furnished for those months during which no incidents occurred. No serious infringements were reported during the year, though two incidents-the overflow of the plant runoff pond at Nabarlek, and the 'islands' incident at Ranger-gave rise to some media attention when they became known. Infringements of the Environmental Requirements that were reported by the companies, or came to the notice of the Supervising Scientist, are listed in Appendix 10. Significant infringements and deficiencies are discussed in the appropriate contexts in Chapter 4.

Chapter 4 refers to the two incidents mentioned, the first is the Nabarlek 'Prop ' incident-the release off-site of plant run-off water of March, 1981, which was not reported until July of that year. The second is the Ranger 'islands' incident of November 1981, in which small areas of tailings in the dam were not covered by water. Details of the incidents are also given at a later stage in the report. Mr Acting Deputy President, since you are a member of the Committee, I am sure that you share the view that the Committee should examine the report in detail. Undoubtedly it will arrange to travel to the area again to ensure that the work of the Supervising Scientist is being noted by the companies concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
In doing so, I say that the Opposition welcomes the appearance of the annual report of the Australian War Memorial for 1980-81.

TALK.START.PARA: —But this one is late.

—It is late, as Senator Peter Rae points out. However, I have not risen at this stage of the presentation of papers to complain about its lateness . Rather, my intention is to note that it is the last report that will appear under the directorship of Mr Noel Flanagan, who has been the Director of the Australian War Memorial for many years. Mr Flanagan has announced his retirement , which is to take place this month. I could not let pass this opportunity to place on record the appreciation of the Australian Labor Party of the magnificent way in which Mr Flanagan has carried out his duties at the War Memorial. In the seven years for which I have been a member of the Senate I have been fortunate to have had frequent opportunities to meet Mr Flanagan at the War Memorial on occasions of significance and have always been most impressed with the developments that he has nurtured there.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to mention a few of the developments that have taken place in the War Memorial in recent years, developments that I have found to be very much to the benefit of the museum and, of course, to the Australian public to whom the museum belongs. In very recent years, and most recently in the last Budget, there has been a significant increase in Federal funding for the War Memorial. That increase has been totally justified and the Director, Mr Flanagan, must be acknowledged as having been very effective and successful in gaining it at a time when, generally speaking, public expenditure is being reduced.

One of the very important things that has happened in recent years at the War Memorial has been the development of proper conservation and curatorial programs . As all Australians will know, the War Memorial represents the most extensive museum in Australia. It has the most extensive holdings of paintings and historical objects that record and document our participation in major wars. However, until fairly recently, many of the holdings, many of the acquisitions of the War Memorial were in danger of rotting away in the absence of a proper conservation program. Funds to employ conservators were not available and no proper training facilities were offering for people who wished to work in the conservation and curatorial areas in Australia. All of these deficiencies have been rectified in the last few years under the directorship of Noel Flanagan. One outstanding achievement of not only Noel Flanagan, but also others who were interested, was the establishment at the Canberra College of Advanced Education of a conservators course, the first of its kind in Australia. The course offers training at the highest level for people who wish to gain qualifications to work in conservation and curatorial areas at our museums. Graduates from the course have been appearing and have been working in the War Memorial and other national and State museums. I understand that their work is of a very high standard. So it is very important that this training course has been established. Of course, the War Memorial will not be the only beneficiary. The Australian National Gallery and State galleries throughout the country will benefit also.

There has also been in the last few years a very significant upgrading of the qualifications of staff generally. Again in the conservation and curatorial area , funding has been obtained so that people of the highest qualifications can be not only employed but also maintained in that employment. There was a period when the Memorial was able to employ but would then lose them because it could not pay them at a proper level. I believe that that situation has now been rectified.

I would also like to commend Mr Flanagan and the War Memorial on some of the innovations that have been introduced in recent years and which have brought the community even closer to this important national resource. An example of the kind of innovatory program run within the museum was the performance of an Anzac Day memorial. It was a performing arts production entitled 'The Broken Years', which was held during the week of the Anzac Day commemorations. It involved a number of local performing arts groups, including the new professional Canberra theatre company-Theatre ACT-the Woden Valley Children's Choir, the very well known and well liked Duntroon band and other community organisations. It was an outstanding performance and I believe it was a very innovative and exciting use of the internal space of the War Memorial. It was highly acceptable to the community and I hope to see more such developments in forthcoming years. I must also commend the Memorial on the recent exhibition of paintings by Sir Arthur Streeton, who was not only one of the finest impressionist painters Australia has produced but also an official war painter for the 1914-18 War. The exhibition of his paintings from that period, painted mainly in France, was a most impressive and outstanding one. Again, its scope reflects a new approach to the staging of exhibitions within the Australian War Memorial. For these and many other reasons we can all feel very pleased with developments in the Australian War Memorial in recent years. Of course, the effectiveness of those developments is due very largely to the outgoing Director, Mr Noel Flanagan, to whom, as I have said on behalf of the entire Opposition, I offer my congratulations for a job very well done and my best wishes to him and his family for his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly to the report of the Australian War Memorial because it is an institution of unique significance to Australian life, as the preamble to the report says. It is certainly the most successful institution of its type, be it art gallery or other public facility of this nature, in the whole of Australia. Its success is demonstrated by the fact that it attracts over 750,000 visitors a year and it is estimated that, of those, 100,000 are from overseas. I have spoken to some of those visitors who have gone to the War Memorial over the years and they are all fulsome in their praise of it. Well they might be, because it is an outstanding collection and there is nothing quite like it in any other country. Of course, it is a great social asset to Australia, with the re-awakening of Australian nationalism in the last decade and a sense of achievement for what we have done. The War Memorial plays a very important part in our social history.

SPEECH.PARA: The big difficulty that the Memorial has suffered over the years is the perpetual one of money. When it came to handing out money the War Memorial certainly was not one of the most favoured institutions in the Commonwealth. As Senator Ryan has said, the twin problems that face it are those of documentation of a vast collection and the curatorial ones of preservation, which are immense. It is important that these tasks be coped with because the collection is irreplaceable. We cannot simply go to the market and buy replacements for what we have. It is interesting that the collection is valued at at least $100m. I do not know how something like that for which a market does not exist is valued but nevertheless it is a great investment that the Australian community has.

I am pleased to support the Government in regard to what it has given the Memorial in the last 12 months. It has undertaken to support the Memorial to the tune of $11m in total. The appropriation for this year has gone to $5.5m from an amount of $2.5m last year, which is a move in the right direction. I am happy that the Government has seen its way clear to do this. Putting it in perspective , though, although $5.5m is nearly twice the amount that was given to the Memorial the year before, it is nothing when we look at, for example, the amount allocated the Australian National Gallery which was opened by the Queen a month or two ago. The accounts for the National Gallery show that in the 10 years between 1971 and 1981 the Gallery for acquisitions alone received in excess of $ 32m. The appropriation for the War Memorial was nowhere near that; it would not have been more than 60 per cent of that amount. The whole of the War Memorial has to be run and acquisitions have to be made out of a budget which pales into insignificance by comparison to that of the National Gallery. I am not being critical of the art gallery; I enjoy art and I have been in most of the major galleries of the world many times, with the exception of the Prado in Madrid. I do think that because of the uniqueness of the Australian War Memorial it deserves a higher level of funding than it has enjoyed up till now.

Finally, I too would like to pay tribute to the work of Mr Noel Flanagan who has been an outstanding Director. He has also been at a human level a most helpful guide and mentor to me on the visits I have had and I wish him well in his retirement and thank him sincerely for what he has done for the Australian nation in the years he has been Director of the Australian War Memorial.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -This is the first report of the Australian War Memorial submitted under the Australian War Memorial Act which came into force in 1980. It has been pointed out that the report is late but that is probably because of the new procedures necessary. I want to raise the matter of the development not only of our major war memorial situated in Canberra but also other war memorials throughout Australia. Sufficient time has passed since the Vietnam war to raise the question of whether or not Australia ought to be looking, as the United States of America has done, to erect a specific memorial to the Vietnam war. It is doubtless understood by all honourable senators that that war probably caused the greatest rift in the population at large of any war fought by this nation. It was one which I opposed and which I think a lot of other honourable senators would have opposed, although many others supported it. Regardless of that, the people who fought in that war at the behest of the country and of the government of the time carried out their duties in a manner which did great credit to our armed forces, and the country as a whole has an obligation to each succeeding group of combatants in whatever wars the country is called upon to fight to remember the sacrifices that people make from time to time for the continuance of this country and for the continuance of this chamber . I believe it would now be possible to obtain from the community a consensus that we ought to look at something beyond the rather small memorial that exists in Canberra. Probably nobody in the Senate realises that there is a memorial to the Vietnam war. It is not the significant type of memorial that we should have to commemorate that engagement.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak somewhat diffidently on this because I do know that it is a matter which still causes much concern within the community. Many people believe that memorials may be seen as glorification of war. I have never seen them that way and I hope that the majority of the community does not see them as a glorification of war, but rather as an acknowledgment of the sacrifices that have been undertaken on behalf of everybody in the country. The form that such a memorial might take ought probably best be left to developing discussions. I do not believe that it is always appropriate to raise a large monolith or building of whatever kind as a memorial. Indeed, in relation to this particular war, that may be inappropriate That matter might best be left to a developing discussion in the community, if this idea is one that is able to be entertained at this time.
