PROCTEXT.PARA: Interim Report of Australian Delegation to 28th Conference

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of Senator Jessop , I present an interim report by the Commonwealth of Australia Branch Delegation on the 28th Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference held in the Bahamas in October 1982. I seek leave to make a statement in connection with the report and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
INTERIM REPORT ON THE 28TH CPA CONFERENCE, THE BAHAMAS, OCTOBER 1982

The Conference was well attended by some 285 delegates, secretaries and observers. It was well organised and administered by the Bahamas Branch of the CPA, supported by the Headquarters Secrtariat. The Conference proper was preceded by a Conference of the Small Nations of the Commonwealth where the main issues discussed were their economic viability, their defence and security and their adaptation of the Westminster parliamentary system in conformity with their traditional customs and diverse cultures. This gave the Commonwealth of Australia Branch delegation the opportunity to canvass certain Branch proposals concerning the organisation and administration of the Association and its future activities with the Australian State delegation, the Australasian and Pacific Regional delegations and with other influential member Branches such as the United Kingdom and the Federations of the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth delegation noted a certain sameness in the Conference agenda over the last few years which seemed to restrict the scope of debate on important international issues of common concern upon which an organisation of 125 parliaments, cast mainly in the democratic mould and representing about a quarter of the world's population, could have made a greater impact had the agenda been less inhibiting. The delegation felt that there was a need to broaden the scope of the Conference agenda.
Branch delegates took part in the debates on all agenda items. There was some lively, informative, useful and controversial discussion.

In the session on ''World Peace and Development'' delegates argued the merits of unilateral disarmament as opposed to the maintenance of deterrent forces, world government in preference to regional arrangements and free trade against economic equalisation. Some said that disarmament would not only reduce tensions but it would also provide the global economy with the financial resources to close the gap between the rich and the poor. Others insisted that military strength was the only deterrent to aggression. Others took a middle road and called for economic realignment consistent with a defensive military posture and in this case they argued a moderating role for the Commonwealth.

In discussion on ''The Security and Future of the Small Countries of the Commonwealth'' there emerged a concept of a Commonwealth defence force noting that while the Law of the Sea Convention provided smaller states with new resources to develop they lack the military capacity to enforce sovereignty.

In discussion of ''Approaches to Unemployment'' there was widespread support for policies designed to stimulate job creation but there was such a divergent range of job creation policies ranging from a free market economy to subsidised labour intensive programmes to the removal of protectionist trade barriers which appeared to spread the economic problems of the developed world to the under- developed world, that no real consensus emerged. There was, however, a proposal for the establishment of a Commonwealth Development Bank to give the less developed states an alternative source of development aid to the high interest loans of the current money market.

In consideration of the ''Freedom of the Individual and Human Rights'' there was widespread support for the CPA to take a more active role in campaigning against the violations of human rights and a call for the CPA to advocate a Commonwealth Human Rights Charter.
The discussion on ''Alternative Energy Resources'' took a well trodden path but it was generally agreed that there was a need for an information exchange to avoid duplication of effort.

Opinion was divided on the means of controlling the population explosion. Some argued that political leaders and parliaments and governments should not settle for an advisory role but had to take an active lead by supporting birth control programmes with legislation. There was general support for a suggestion that the CPA should organise a conference of women to discuss population control. There was also the suggestion that men should not confuse procreation with masculinity , but there seemed to be a general view that in the educational process on birth control women would have more success than men.

On ''Parliament and the Scrutiny of Public Finance'' there was a call for more aggressive scrutiny of public spending and an extension of it into previously unmonitored areas to halt the trend to government taxation without adequate parliamentary review. There were pointers towards the need to assess government borrowing practices and spending by government-owned and subsidised industries. There was a call for Public Accounts and Expenditure committees to split their review into two stages, a political examination of policies and ministerial performance, and a non-political review of managerial performance by departmental heads.

There was an obvious split between the Westminster style parliaments and the one party parliaments on ''The Role of an Opposition in a Parliamentary System'' . The African exponent of the one party state insisted that the electorate was given the widest choice possible when as many as twenty candidates were endorsed for each seat and that the backbenchers in the parliament were a real and effective Opposition.

In discussion on 'Parliament and the Executive' there was a view that in many cases the Executive had taken control of the legislative arm of government although some members also lamented the fact that a well entrenched bureaucracy had actually wrested government from the elected Executive. There was a general view that an expanded and strengthened parliamentary committee system would be an effective mechanism for improving parliamentary scrutiny of the Executive but it was also conceded that if parliaments did not reassert their authority they would become irrelevant and the Executive would cease to be responsible to the public will.

That is perhaps an over-concise reporting of the Conference proceedings but that is not the main reason for this Interim Report. The Branch delegation was charged by the Annual General Meeting of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch to raise certain matters of policy, administration (including financial practices and estimates,), organisation, activity, and representation on the governing organs of the Association in the General Assembly and were briefed accordingly. The delegation did not succeed in resolving all these matters to the satisfaction of the Branch but this Interim Report is intended to show how far along the road they got.

The Commonwealth of Australia Branch proposals called for a substantive debate on CPA resolutions as consensus emerged from the Conference, an explanation of the criteria determining representation at Plenary Conferences, the circulation of the draft Executive Committee report together with forward estimates well in advance of the Conference and two meetings of the General Assembly at each Plenary Conference. They also recommended procedures for elections of officers and particularly the office of Chairman of the Executive Committee and they put forward a case for increased representation on the Executive Committee by the United Kingdom and the Federal Branches of the Commonwealth, and finally, observing the escalating costs of Plenary Conferences, they canvassed the idea of hosting these conferences on a regional basis believing that such an arrangement would make for orderly planning and would broaden the scope of parliamentary exchange. The proposals were discussed at ad hoc meetings with the States' delegates and with the Australasian and Pacific Region's delegates, with the United Kingdom Branch and with the other Federal Branches of the Association . New Zealand excepted, the proposals received the unanimous support of the Australasian and Pacific Regional Branches with the proviso that any new arrangement did not impinge upon their autonomy or disadvantage their prospects of representation on the Executive Committee. They were fully supported by Nigeria, Kenya and Tanzania and received qualified support from the United Kingdom, India and Malaysia. On the basis of this degree of support the delegation circulated a paper outlining the proposals to all branches represented at the Conference. It is believed that this paper prompted the Executive Committee to recommend the setting up of a Study Group to consider the CPA and the future. The delegation supported the Executive Committee's recommendation for a Study Group but moved an amendment in specific terms indicating its composition, its terms of reference and its working timetable. This amendment was accepted and a Study Group is to be set up within ninety days , that is by 30 January, it will accept Branch submissions up to 30 April, it will meet in June 1983 and its recommendations are to be circulated to all Branches ninety days before the next meeting of the General Assembly. Its terms of reference encompass all the Commonwealth of Australia Branch proposals.

Mr President, I believe that Australia was well represented by those delegates who attended this conference. Further, the work carried on by the delegation secretary, Mr Blake, and Mr Ferguson of the CPA was invaluable and they deserve our thanks.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Interim Report of the Australian Delegation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present an interim report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions from September to November 1982. I seek leave to make a statement in connection with the report and to incorporate that statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
AUSTRALIA AND THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENTARY INSTITUTIONS

The first ever Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions has just returned and it is our wish to make a brief statement by way of summary of the Report which will be presented during the Autumn Session of Parliament.
The Delegation consisted of Senator Peter Rae (Leader), Senator A. J. Mulvihill , the Honourable W. L Morrison, MP. and Mr J. R. Porter, MP.

For the past thirty years Europe has, following the devastation of two world wars, become intent upon creating a new, united group of nations. This was not only the product of that devastation, but also a reaction to the very clearly perceived threat of being the front-line in East-West relations-of having the Iron Curtain for a border.

Perhaps understandably, in the light of history, and of the past thirty years of looking at a front line in military and strategic terms, they have tended to be inward-looking, and little concerned about global perspectives.

The population encompassed by the twenty-one nations of the Council of Europe is 380 million people. The European Community comprises ten nations (perhaps soon to be twelve) with a population of 270 million. The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation involves more than 619 million people in the 16 nations.

The Delegation believes that although Australia supported the creation of the new European Community, there was at the same time a realisation and acceptance that the creation of that Community would carry with it the need for Australia to find new economic, trade, and defence relationships. We believe that the phase of Australia finding new economic, trade, and defence relationships was a transient situation. That re-direction has been achieved. The development of the European Community involved Australia in the virtual total loss of our traditional markets for our agricultural products and in the establishment of new relationships in the over-all balance of power. Australia was forced to, and did, find a new relationship in that part of the world in which we as a continent are geographically placed. The consequence has been a total change in Australia's attitude to a wide variety of matters, including its immigration policy and the structure of its population, as well as the other matters referred to above. In all, it is our view that Australia has benefited greatly from that necessity.

In summary, for nearly twenty years Europe has concentrated on its own development as a Community of Nations, and has tended to be inward-looking while Australia has, of necessity, tended to concentrate its efforts elsewhere. However, in this context, Australia has, we believe, completed the phase, and may now look to applying some reasonable degree of effort to the re-building of a mutual understanding with Continental Europe and with the United Kingdom. Of course, we are not suggesting that this should be in any way to the detriment of the further building of our economic, trade and cultural relationships with the Pacific Community and our other newly developed trading partners, such as the Middle East.

The Delegation believes that without in any way derogating from the development of our important relationships within our region, the time has come to build a new relationship with Europe. We do not pretend that Europe finds Australia to be a nation of great concern to them. Australia tends to be regarded as ''the lucky country'', with vast resources, a stable political situation, a reliable democracy, and a country about which they do not have to concern themselves.
The mere fact that many of their policies have had extremely destructive effects on Australia has not so much been ignored as unrecognised, particularly in the Parliamentary arena.
The creation of the elected European Parliament, which is in its third year of full operation has, we believe, changed the potential quite dramatically.

For many years, the European Community was operated by an Executive without the checks and balances of an effective parliamentary institution. We believe that the European Parliament has made major strides in its short period of evolution and development, and that it will play a major part in the future of Europe and its relationship with the larger world.

The Council of Europe, that is the twenty-one pluralist parliamentary democracies of Europe, continues to play a major role in a significant number of areas, including human rights, the development of international accord and co- operation through the development of conventions, the exchange of knowledge and technology through its expert committees. To all of these, Australian participation has now been invited.

The North Atlantic Parliamentary Assembly, comprising representatives drawn from the sixteen member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, appears now to have accepted that it would be desirable to adopt a global perspective. Again Australia has been invited to participate. Bearing in mind that we are inextricably tied to the ANZUS Treaty involving NATO's most dominant member, the United States, and through Five-Power and other longstanding and traditional relationships with the United Kingdom, we have a very real interest in encouraging a better appreciation of NATO's global perspectives, particularly so far as the Indian and Pacific Oceans are concerned.

The Delegation had the opportunity for discussion, both in Brussels and in Strasbourg, with the European Commission, the Executive of the European Communities. Those discussions were quite extensive, and we believe, most interesting, revealing and rewarding.

The Delegation also enjoyed the opportunity for discussions at the OECD headquarters in Paris, as well as participating in the annual OECD Debate, sponsored by the Council of Europe, and to which the non-European members of the OECD are invited.

The Delegation spent altogether two months in consultation with European Parliamentary, Executive and other institutions. We were able to make an assessment of the state of knowledge, interest, and appreciation of Europe/ Australia relationships.

We concluded that we should adopt as a start point a statement made during one of the very early briefing sessions-''Australia's real problem is that we don't impinge very much on European consciousness''. We believe that this is not insignificantly Australia's fault.

Notwithstanding the fact that we have had the appointment of a Minister for Special Trade Representations for a period of several years, and not inconsiderable diplomatic effort, the tendency has been for government-to- government discussions, position taking, and relatively little by way of mutual understanding on the broader basis-certainly little parliamentary or public understanding of the bigger issues of trade, defence, resources and the like. To change this will require a continuation of persistent effort through all channels.

There is a significant, if as yet undeveloped, interest in Europe in the development of better understanding and this can be particularly enhanced by the use of the opportunities provided through the Parliamentary Institutions to which we have referred.
Each has offered to have a special seminar, colloquy, or other form of exchange and development on information and ideas related to Europe/Australia.

The European Parliament has established a Delegation (committee) for Australia- New Zealand relations while both the Council of Europe and the North Atlantic Parliamentary Assembly have offered to set aside a day for the discussion of an agreed agenda relating to our mutual interests.

We are firmly of the view that Australia's interests would be best served by taking advantage of the awakening interest in Europe in the affairs of the Pacific region. We noted that one delightful European leader said, ''The Mediterranean is the sea of the past-the Atlantic is the sea of the present-the Pacific is the sea of the future''. We, Australia, are in a particularly fortunate position to play a role as the go-between for both Europe and the Pacific. We must not miss that opportunity.

We are firmly of the view that we should follow up the ground which has been laid by earlier delegations to the Council of Europe, and take advantage of what has been developed during the course of this Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions. We can and should develope a firm line of inter- parliamentary communication with each of these institutions.

The Delegation was most appreciative of the attitude and encouragement offered by the President and Secretary-General of the Council of Europe, as well as the various Committee Chairmen and others in leading positions in that Parliamentary Institution. The President, senior staff, and many others of the European Parliament, including particularly the Chairman of the Delegation on Australia/ New Zealand relations, were positive in their attitudes to Australian participation. We also found a clear and firm attitude from the newly-elected President of the North Atlantic Parliamentary Assembly, the Senior Vice- President, and the Secretary-General and others who encouraged future Australian participation.
It is clear that the opportunity exists for Australia to overcome the disadvantages referred to earlier in this statement.

From a cost-benefit point of view, we believe that whilst we must recognise the cost in the broader sense, both to individual members and the Parliamentary Budget and in personal terms to the individual members in being away from Australia for a relatively lengthy period, the potential benefits certainly outweigh the costs.

We have established the details of an agreement for the necessary mechanisms for continuous contact and communication between the Australian Parliament and these extremely important parliamentary institutions. However, we believe that for the mechanisms to be effective on an on-going, throughout-the-year basis, then these mechanisms must be supported by Australian Parliamentary attendance and participation during the October/November period of the European Parliamentary Institutions. We would see the necessity for attendance at the Council of Europe, the European Parliament, and the North Atlantic Parliamentary Assembly Sessions during those months as a tremendous opportunity for Australia as well as the establishment of an Australian Parliamentary presence in Europe. To each of these Parliamentary Sessions we are invited to participate on a very full basis.
We should accept these invitations.

A delegation of four, being comprised of equal numbers from each of the Australian Houses, and of Governments and Opposition Members is, we believe, the ideal. This enables individual participation in the various committees which are such a major feature of the operation of these Parliamentary Institutions. A smaller delegation means that a large part of the opportunity is wasted. The bipartisan composition of the delegation ensures that Australians can attend the meetings of the political groups in each of these institutions.

We found this a particularly valuable aspect of the Delegation's work and would wish to express our appreciation of the readiness of those Parliamentary groups to accept our presence and participation. This aspect is of particular importance, as no non-Parliamentary observer could ever hope to be accepted into that form of participation. As in any other Parliament, so much of what really matters happens in the Party (or political group) or meetings in Parliamentary Committee. The plenary tends to be the public reaction to, and explanation of, the product of that process. To both we were given access.
We wish to stress this point most firmly, and to emphasise our appreciation of the trust and warmth of the involvement which was developed.

Members of the Delegation were, as appropriate, invited to, and attended, meetings of the Conservative (European Democrat) and Socialist groups, the Christian Democrats, and other groupings of like-minded parties.

One further point of importance to stress is that of the proposed Strasbourg Conference. In early October 1983, the Council of Europe propose to sponsor a Conference of the pluralist Parliamentary democracies of Europe and the OECD nations.

Australia has been invited to participate and has informed the Council of Europe that, as a result of an election held earlier this year, the Hon. W. L. Morrison and Mr J. R. Porter will be the parliamentary liaison officers.

Not only has there been an indication already given by the Speaker of the Australian House of Representatives that Australia will participate, there is a firm belief on the part of the Delegation resulting from the further discussions held in Strasbourg, that the proposed Conference will provide an important opportunity for the development of democracy in the world. We applaud the Speaker's decision. It is both in our particular interest, also our duty to play a part in the extension of the concept and practices involved in providing that system of human freedom.

As a special conference in which Australia has such a clear interest, we believe that Australia should show its support, and should facilitate its interests by sending a delegation of six to that Conference.

As the Strasbourg Conference will follow immediately after the OECD Debate sponsored by the Council of Europe, we recommend that the Delegation of six should be comprised of the four members of the Australian Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions, together with two extra members who would attend the OECD Debate and the Strasbourg Conference.
We note again that the Australian Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions would include the two liaison officers referred to above, and two other elected delegates.

We recommend that for ongoing purposes, there should be formed within the Australian Parliament an Australia/Europe Parliamentary Group, similar to the Australia/Japan, Australia/Korea, Australia/Indonesia, Parliamentary Groups, with a function for ongoing liaison with the European Parliamentary Institutions . We recommend that the Delegation should be drawn from Members of that Group with two members of the Group being elected for the duration of an Australian Parliament to fulfil the role of permanent liaison officers. They should be members of each delegation for that period.

We recommend that for the first period, the two permanent liaison officers should be from one each of the Government and Opposition members from the House of Representatives, and for the next period, a Government and Opposition Senator .

We believe that an effective Australian delegation must contain a number of members (we suggest two out of four) who know both the procedure and the individual people, involved in the European Parliamentary Institutions. No delegation should fail to comprise two permanent liaison members elected for the duration of an Australian Parliament, as well as two others who may or may not have any prior association with the purpose of the delegation. Obviously, the greater the degree of association and experience, then the greater the potential effectiveness of the delegation.

In summary, this Delegation is happy to report that the European Parliamentary Institutions will be reviewing the Common Agricultural Policy, and its effects in the creation of subsidised surpluses together with and the question of unfair trading practices by the sale (or dumping) of those surpluses on world markets. It is through these methods that changes in European attitudes and policies will be achieved. It may well be that there will also need to be some changes in Australia's attitudes and policies. Whichever, a better understanding on a very much broader basis and to our mutual advantage will, we believe, be achievable. Numerous other matters were discussed and agreement reached, including a review of Europe's attitude to the Law of the Sea Convention.

The Delegation also wishes to record its appreciation of the strong support and encouragement which it received from the Australian Ambassadors to Brussels, Paris, and the OECD, as well as the High Commissioner in London, and their staff . All wholeheartedly supported the work of the Delegation in developing an inter -Parliamentary liaison and a useful working relationship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the 200th and 203rd reports of the Committee, together with appendices to the 203rd report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.
The 200th report is the annual report for 1981-82 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. I seek leave to have a statement concerning that report incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The 200th report is the annual report for 1981-82 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. It contains a review of the inquiries conducted by the Committee during the year and issues arising from our investigations and other matters which the Committee regards as significant in its development.

Throughout 1981-82 the Committee has continued to maintain an extensive program of inquiries and research. It tabled eleven reports on significant public sector management issues such as the administration of petroleum royalties and excise, the operation of the government aircraft factories, the effectiveness of the coal export duty and the conservation and curatorial functions of the Australian War Memorial. Additionally, it has tabled discussion papers on the collection and dissemination of statistics and the form and standard of financial statements for Commonwealth undertakings.

The Committee also hosted its third parliamentary seminar on management and parliamentary accountability of the public sector during the year. This seminar gave senior public servants and executives from the private sector the opportunity to participate in a range of workshops, the results of which were of great value to the Committee in its inquiry into the selection and development of senior managers in the public sector.

This year is the thirtieth anniversary of the re-establishment of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and I believe that it is appropriate that its two hundredth report should be tabled at this time. The success of the Committee has been built on the solid foundation laid over the past three decades by successive chairmen, members of the Committee and staff as well as by its official observers and advisers, all of whom have contributed to the building of an institution which is regarded within the Commonwealth as being a significant mechanism for effective parliamentary review.

With the growing complexities of government, and the intractable problems facing all parliaments in the management of the nation's affairs, it is now becoming a matter of vital concern that parliamentarians should be given the opportunity to be kept informed of the mechanisms by which the efficiency and effectiveness in the development and conduct of government programs can be assured, the public service, which is by nature conservative, needs to be tested by the parliament to ensure that a more efficient and effective system of administration is developed and maintained.

The Committee wishes to record its appreciation to its secretary, its advisors, seconded and permanent staff for their excellent work throughout the year. In addition the Committee wishes to thank officers from the Department of Finance, the Public Service Board and the Auditor-General's Office who have continued to provide high quality professional advice and assistance as observers for all our inquiries.

We are also appreciative of the work done by the Principal Parliamentary Reporter and his staff for their valuable assistance and other officers of the parliamentary departments who have supported the Committee in its activities.
I commend the report to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 203rd report is a progress report. It has been prepared by the Committee at the request of the Minister for Health (Mr Calton)-the request was made last September-to enable him to examine various options on the basis of the Committee's inquiry into the effectiveness of existing legislation and procedures for dealing with abuse of the medical benefits system. This report contains 45 recommendations, even though it is only a progress report. The recommendations are directed at streamlining and strengthening both administrative procedures and existing legislation. In the course of the inquiry to date, the Committee has received considerable evidence on the abuse by some doctors of the health insurance arrangements. To put it mildly, we have been shocked by the lengths to which some members of this highly respected profession have gone to find ways of profiting from the system.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be recalled that the inquiry was undertaken as a result of the estimate by the Department of Health that at least $100m per annum is being lost in medical fraud and overservicing. While there remains some doubt about the precise figure, on the basis of the evidence before the Committee we believe that the annual amount is certainly no less than $100m and could well be much higher. I must emphasise at this point that the Committee believes that a substantial majority of doctors are not engaged in either fraud or conscious overservicing; nevertheless, there are members of the medical profession who are defrauding the Australian community or consciously providing excessive services on a large scale as a means of supplementing their incomes.

The medical profession occupies a position of great significance in our society , not only with respect to maintaining the health of the community but also because its members occupy the unique position of having access on the basis of trust to more than $1.5 billion annually, which money comes from taxpayers and health fund contributors. Regrettably, some members have abused that trust, and thus have compromised the high standing of their profession and their professional colleagues. Whatever steps the Government decides to take to strengthen the monitoring and enforcement procedures, it remains the responsibility of the medical profession to help to re-establish the high standards of conduct which the community expects of all its members.

The Committee has found the overall administrative response to fraud and overservicing most unsatisfactory. Despite the estimate of the Department of Health that more than 2,000 doctors may be engaging in large scale fraud or overservicing, very few have been penalised. In almost seven years between July 1975 and March this year, there were only 48 successful prosecutions for medical fraud, and only 61 doctors suspected of overservicing were brought before medical services committees of inquiry. There are a number of factors contributing to this situation, including shortcomings in existing legislation, and long delays in the handling of cases by the Australian Federal Police and the Crown Solicitor's offices. However, a great deal of the responsibility must rest with the Department of Health. The Committee has found its response to abuse of the medical benefits system grossly inadequate. Despite ample evidence since at least 1975 that fraud and overservicing were occurring on a large scale , too little was done and always too late to stem the loss effectively.

This report mentions a number of areas in which the Department's performance was unsatisfactory, including its failure to issue adequate guidelines to its State offices, with the result that they have adopted quite differing approaches to a common problem and have at times failed to investigate doctors even when there was strong evidence of fraud. The recommendations in the progress report-I reiterate that it is a progress report-focus on changes to the administrative procedures for the handling of cases of suspected fraud or overservicing.

We propose as a short term measure, because of the backlog in medical fraud cases requiring investigation and prosecution, the immediate establishment of a special national task force of experienced health, police and legal personnel to reduce the number of outstanding cases. Among the proposed permanent changes that we have recommended are the following: Changes to bulk billing arrangements to reduce the scope for fraud; improvements in the Department of Health computerised detection system and extra staff for that area; the establishment of integrated investigation sections within the Department of Health, to cover both fraud and serious overservicing cases; appointment of medical investigators within those sections to handle apparent cases of serious overservicing; abolition of the present medical services committee of inquiry, and establishment of medical benefits tribunals, which would include medical specialists; Commonwealth-State agreement on uniform medical registration legislation and automatic deregistration of doctors convicted of fraud; and automatic disqualification for medical benefits purposes where doctors are found to have provided excessive services on a large scale.

I recommend that all members of the Senate read the report in detail to find the further recommendations and the other areas of deficiency which the Committee has discovered. Because the subject is both controversial and complex, this inquiry has been a major undertaking by the Committee. We have so far held 48 hearings and meetings on the inquiry, and taken over 5,000 pages of transcript, in addition to a significant number of written submissions. The effort to produce this progress report in a short time has placed great pressure on the members of the Committee and on our support personnel. I wish to place on record my appreciation to the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), and to my fellow members, Senators Lajovic and Watson, and the honourable members for Barton (Mr Bradfield), Holt (Mr Duffy), Canberra (Mrs Kelly), Tangney (Mr Shack), Northern Territory (Mr Tambling) and Burke (Dr Theophanous). I also wish to express my appreciation to members of the task force which included officers of the Committee's secretariat and a range of expert advisers. I add to this statement by saying that the number of hours of dedicated effort which the officers put into this progress report has enabled it to be tabled today.

The report raises a number of fundamental issues of public administration and policy which extend well beyond the specific area of medical fraud and overservicing. These include ministerial responsibility and the briefing provided to successive Ministers by the Department of Health, the general relationship between central and State offices of departments and the adequacy of the legal system to deal with white collar crime. We therefore hope that the report will have an audience beyond the Parliament and others concerned with health insurance arrangements.

Finally I emphasise that we have not finished the inquiry. There remain a number of major aspects of medical fraud and overservicing which are not covered in this progress report. I shall read the list of those because it is important to know the extent to which we intend to investigate the problem. The Committee will be examining further a number of areas for its final report on this inquiry . Major areas include patient fraud; fraud associated with hospitals; fraud and overservicing associated with prescription of pharmaceuticals; fraud and overservicing associated with pathology; unnecessary surgery; possible strengthening of the legislation with respect to medical fraud; possible measures to reduce the growth in the number of doctors; peer review mechanisms and the development of guidelines for the use of specific medical procedures; modification to medical benefit systems to reduce incentives for overservicing; the revision of medical benefit schedules; and, finally, medical education. So the Committee has a substantial way to go before its final report is placed before the Parliament.

Although improvements in administrative procedures are urgently needed and are recommended in the report, the inescapable fact remains that no administrative or legal system in this area can be completely effective without the co- operation of the medical profession, the members of which should act with integrity and should willingly accept a role along with government to ensure that the people of Australia have access to adequate standards of health care at a cost which the community is willing and able to afford. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges has just presented the 200th and 203rd reports of the Public Accounts Committee. The 203rd report 'Medical Fraud and Overservicing-A Progress Report' is a report of the utmost significance and it is not without controversy. Senator Georges was very generous in his praise towards members of the secretariat and the Committee for the hard work that went into its preparation. I would like to take two minutes to express my appreciation to the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, Senator Georges. His experience, his judgment and his insight were valuable. The report ranges across a wide number of departments including the Department of Health, the Australian Federal Police and others. DEBATE.TITLE: BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX ADMINISTRATION BILL 1982BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX BILL 1982ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS (JUDICIAL REVIEW) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday I was speaking on the very narrow point of the real cost of wages and the real cost of employing people in Australia. I made the point that the true cost of employing labour in Australia is not often perceived. The real cost is very high-probably the highest in the world. I related this to the Government's then proposed pay pause which has now become reality. This gives us a bit of breathing space to look at what is happening. It is a very real point. Undeniably there is some fat to be trimmed off some wages and salaries that are paid in this country. We live in competition with other countries and have to compete on the open market. We cannot hide behind protectionism all the way. In supporting my case, I illustrated the conditions which apply for the combined mining unions and I made the point that they are an extreme case. But this is relevant because there is always a flow on from what one union obtains to what ultimately becomes available to all of them. It is just not true to look at average weekly earnings . One has to look behind the scenes to find out what is happening. These hidden benefits in Australia, as I said before, are the highest in the world and they are at least a 50 per cent on-cost to the weekly pay that a worker receives in many industries. Take, for example, paying an increment for a holiday loading. I can remember that when that came in. I thought it was an absolutely illogical move. I could not believe anyone would be paid more to go on holiday than to work and I still have that air of incredulousness about it ten years after it was brought in. I was interested to hear an American observe the other day with astonishment: 'You pay them more to go on holidays than to work'. That is my view entirely.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequence of this add-on costs is that we are pricing ourselves out of a market. That comes about in two ways. Firstly, we have strikes, which are often related to these additional benefits, in companies that are profitable and can afford to appease the unions in the short term; and secondly, we have to compete with nations, particularly those of the Asian-Pacific rim and our costs of production are too high. I was rather interested to see in the newspaper yesterday an account by one of the Esso financial managers on the effect of industrial disputes in Australia. He made the point that last year strikes cost each Australian family $3,000. He broke that figure up and mentioned that the Bass Strait disputes, which have been largely about the sorts of benefits I have been talking about, account for nearly $1,500 of that, if my memory serves me correctly. He also showed the loss of revenue to the Government in the form of taxation. We spent a rather hectic time in the last two weeks debating a retrospective tax Bill which will bring in at best between $200m and $300m; yet the amount lost through strikes in the Gippsland oil basin is a multiple of that . That is a national loss, because it has to be made up in other forms of taxation.

We have to compete with the nations in the Asian-Pacific region. There is no way we can protect Australian industry. There is no way we can protect our national wealth by higher and higher protection-tariffs and quotas. We simply have to compete. We are a healthy and an educated work force but we cannot compete if we are not prepared to work or if we want to pay ourselves too much. When I visited Taiwan once I heard the Finance Minister address a gatheing of overseas people. One of the visitors asked: 'What sort of welfare program do you have here, Mr Minister?'. The Minister looked at him and said: 'We believe the best welfare program we can give our citizens is to give them jobs.' That is not a bad philosophy. The path we are following will denude Australian industry of jobs simply because the industries cannot be profitable. The best way to trim these excess payments back is, of course, by competition in the market-place to allow a market for labour to be developed so that those who want to work can work on terms agreed between them and their employers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the occasion of the first reading of the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Bill 1982 and associated Bills to raise an issue which was initially raised by Senator Lewis, my colleague from Victoria, in Question Time on Tuesday, 7 December, when he asked a question about the journalist Claudia Wright. I remind the Senate of the terminology in which the question was phrased. He referred to her as a correspondent of the New Statesman and said that she was married to her second husband. I do not know what the relevance of that latter fact is.
—Her name is Wright. She is now Mrs Helmer.

—Many female journalists in 1982 use their own names. If the honourable senator is not up with that, he ought to be. He referred to her second husband, Melbourne-born Harvard PhD Dr John Helmer. He then asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is this Claudia Wright the person who launched, as recently as 13 November on Australian Broadcasting Commission radio from Washington, a violent attack on President Reagan and his Administration, accusing them of lying, cheating, lusting and of liquidating their personal opponents?
Is this the same Claudia Wright who is the supporter and apologist for the murderous Colonel Gaddafi and his Libyan hit squads who were mentioned in the newspapers today?

Is this Claudia Wright the person who has deliberately put at risk the lives of Western intelligence officers by naming them in the United States and is now prohibited from naming them there? Is she coming to Australia in order to name them whilst she is here? Can the Minister confirm or deny the rumour that this person is about to return to Australia and is to be given the opportunity by some Mebourne radio station to spew her lies and racist hatred on the Melbourne people.

I interpolate that a point of order was taken at that time about the use of Question Time to make cowardly attacks on individuals. The President properly ruled that it was undesirable that the Senate be used as a forum for that sort of activity, but of course he made the very important distinction that honourable senators can call Claudia Wright or anybody else in the community-we all know this and rely on it a bit, I suppose-a liar or a spewer of venomous statements and so on; yet we cannot say that about each other. We belong to a protected species in that respect. That is one of the great hypocrisies of parliamentary Standing Orders.

I hold no brief for any of the views of Claudia Wright. Although I am sure I would share many views with her, there are other views of hers which I would not agree with at all. That is not, of course, what I regard as being an issue in the manner in which the Senate Question Time was used by my fellow Victorian senator. Let me make some brief acknowledgment, however, of the particular smears and innuendoes which were contained in the question. First of all, it is suggested that Claudia Wright is an apologist for the murderous hit squads of Colonel Gaddafi. Claudia Wright has in fact publicly condemned the activities of those hit squads, so-called. Secondly, it is alleged that Claudia Wright published the names of Western intelligence officers in the United States. The question goes on:
. . . is now prohibited from naming them there.

Claudia Wright has never published the names of any Western intelligence agents in the United States. On one occasion she referred to a book which was written, I think, by a man called Agnew, a former agent of the United States Central Intelligence Agency, in which he named certain CIA agents. She referred to that book some time after it was published. She referred to the naming by that man of people involved in the CIA. The implication of the questions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I get it clear? Are you saying that she has never named one in the United States; she has named CIA agents in other countries but not in the United States? Is that what you are saying?

—No. Let me make it quite clear. She has referred to a book which named CIA agents in Morocco, if the honourable senator wants to be precise. The expression 'publish' means, on my understanding, published for the first time. As I understand it, she would not dispute the fact that she has referred to publications which have named for the first time Western intelligence agents. It is not true to say that she is now prohibited from naming them in the United States even if she wanted to, but that is another point. Legislation was introduced in the United States this year-the Intelligence Agents Protection Bill-which covers a wide range of activity. It was not introduced with Claudia Wright in mind, as I understand it, but as a result of a number of publications made by ex-CIA agents. That is a matter which in a sense I have already adverted to.

SPEECH.PARA: Claudia Wright, whatever one thinks of her views, is, in respect of a variety of publications throughout the world, a distinguished journalist. I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement of the professional activities of this Australian journalist. Before doing so, I refer to the fact, as did Senator Lewis, that she is the Washington correspondent of the London New Statesman, and the Paris weekly Temoignage Chretien. She is a regular contributor to the New York Times, the Los Angeles Times, the Atlanta Constitution, the Miami Herald, the Pacific News Service and News Day. In addition, she broadcasts on the British Broadcasting corporation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Irish Radio and Television corporation and the Pacifica Radio Network. I want to make it quite clear that in addition she is, of course, a commentator on Middle East affairs in respect of which some of her views would not be acceptable to me, but in my view she is quite entitled to state them. It is very interesting to note that she has published, in conjunction with the Carnegie Institute, statements on foreign policy. Her work is published in International Security, a journal published by the Kennedy School of Government and Harvard University; International Affairs, which is a publication of Chatham House, London, and the Royal Institute of International Affairs; and in the Politique Internationale of Paris.

In April 1982 Claudia Wright was invited by the United States House of Representatives committee on Africa to give testimony on American foreign policy in the Middle East, including Libya. In October she participated in an international conference funded by the Rockefeller Foundation in Italy on the political future of Africa. She has also been appointed a Fellow of the Woodrow Wilson International Centre for scholars of the Smithsonian Institution, Washington. She was a participant with senior American officials in the Johnson foundation's conference series on American foreign policy. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that document which I have described in some detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Could I see it first?
—We will defer the matter for a moment. Senator Button, please carry on with your speech.
—I allege that Senator Lewis's allegations about Claudia Wright are based on a scurrilous little news-sheet published in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. It is in my view extremely unfortunate--
—Would you take my assurance, if you are talking about the Toorak Times, that I have not read it in the last three months?

—The allegations were made in July, so we are safe in making that suggestion against Senator Lewis. A number of suggestions were made in Senator Lewis's question. Briefly, they were these: That Claudia Wright is an apologist for Colonel Gaddafi; she has put at risk the lives of allied intelligence officers, and so on. All of these allegations are somewhat hysterical and would not be made outside the Parliament against a journalist and, of course, should not be made inside or outside the Parliament against a journalist in support of suppression of freedom of opinion. What I find extraordinary about Senator Lewis 's allegations is that he suggests that Claudia Wright said all of these things in the United States; yet the United States Government continues to employ her in various capacities and to fund her activities in various capacities in times of--
—The Government employs her?

—Yes. It invites her to participate in seminars on United States foreign policy and things of that kind. All of the newspapers to which I referred, including the New York Times and Los Angeles Post are distinguished newspapers in the United States which have made their judgment about her and publish her work. As I said, I do not want to say that I agree with everything she says. What I do say is that I affirm her right to say it. The United States, for all the criticisms we may have of it, as a major democracy in the Western world, accords to a journalist such as Claudia Wright that freedom of speech. I have had a few arguments with her and I can tell honourable senators that she is quite capable of looking after herself. But the United States accords those freedoms to her. Her work is published in that country. She is involved in public controversy about many issues in the United States. It is very sad that when she comes back to Australia the standards of democratic freedom and participation in debates which are recognised by all of the United States newspapers and the British and French newspapers to which I referred, and the BBC and other organisations, are sought to be denied her here by this sort of scurrilous atack from Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.PARA: There should not be in this chamber, in relation to freedom of expression and opinion of views which the honourable senator happens to disagree with, a different standard from that which pertains in the United States and is recognised by all the newspapers and journals to which I referred. As I say, Claudia Wright is quite capable of looking after herself. If Senator Lewis solicits an invitation to appear on her program he will find that out for himself. I am sure that facility would be made available to him to say some of these things in public. This journalist has an extraordinary curriculum vitae in terms of her contributions to various communications outlets. The standards of this Senate should not be debased by these sorts of hysterical and cowardly attacks against such a person which would not be tolerated in the terms in which they were made in the United States or by the proprietors of the various journals to which I have referred. I raise this matter because I think it is important that this Senate does not disintegrate into a forum for McCarthyism recycled. We should debate the issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the attacks by Senator Walsh on Western Australians? That is McCarthyism, too.
—I understand the point, and Senator Baume has made those allegations. I make them now in relation to this matter. Senator Baume is really saying that it is all--
—I think I am agreeing with you.

—Yes. As I said at the beginning, I hold no necessary brief for any of Claudia Wright's views, although I agree with her about many matters. But I raise the issue because I think it is important that the Senate is not debased by having lower standards than those which pertain in Western democracies generally. If this happens, it will be bad for this society as a whole.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button earlier sought permission to have a document incorporated in Hansard. Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MS CLAUDIA WRIGHT
Statement of professional activities of the Australian journalist, Claudia Wright.
She is currently the Washington correspondent of the London New Statesman, the Paris Weekly Temoignage Chretien.
She is a regular contributor to the New York Times, Los Angeles Times, Atlanta Constitution, Miami Herald, Pacific News Service and News Day.
Broadcasts on the BBC, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Irish Radio and Television, Pacific Radio Network in the United States and radio stations in several American cities.

Since leaving Australia in 1976, Ms Wright has established a considerable reputation as a commentator on the Middle East. Her work has been published in such journals as Foreign Affairs, published by the US Council on Foreign Relations of New York Foreign Policy, published in conjunction with the Carnegie Endowment on World Peace of Washington; International Security, published by the Kennedy School of Government and Harvard University; International Affairs, published by Chatham House and the Royal Institute of International Affairs of London; and Politique Internationale of Paris.
In April 1982, she was invited by the US House of Representatives sub committee on Africa to give testomy on American policy in the Middle East, including Libya .
In October she was invited to participate in a conference in Italy on the political future of Africa. The conference was arranged by the United Nations, supported by the Rockefeller Foundation.

Earlier this year she was appointed a Fellow of the Woodrow Wilson International Centre for scholars of the Smithsonian Institution, Washington and was a participant with senior American officials in the Johnson Foundation's conference series on American foreign policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to respond to the remarks made by Senator Button which has been given me by the first reading of the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Bill 1982 and associated Bills, although I know that the Government is anxious to proceed with its business. Senator Button was kind enough to let me know that he intended to respond to my question, so I had the opportunity of coming into the chamber and listening to what he had to say. I must say that I have been concerned by the misuse of this Senate in order to decry people and to allege matters against them. I have spoken strongly against it. I have also been opposed to intolerance shown in this Senate. I recall that last week when Senator Walters tried to put a different point of view to this Senate in relation to South West Tasmania she was howled down by those people who would hold themselves up as civil libertarians. The intolerance shown to Senator Walters on that occasion drew me into the debate.
—To defend her.

—Yes, to defend her and to defend her right to speak. I would defend people's rights to free speech. Notwithstanding what Senator Button has had to say, I do not endeavour to have Claudia Wright refused permission to speak in some way or other in public forums in Australia or on the radio or to publish articles in newspapers. But I believe that it is necessary for the people who take an interest in these matters to be alerted to the people who are speaking to them. It seemed to me necessary to bring to the attention of those who were prepared to listen to or read what I had to say what I believe are some of her characteristics which ought to be known to the people of Australia and which probably would not be known because she publishes in places around the world other than Australia. Senator Button listed her qualifications. She has certainly come a long way since she was the social editor of the Melbourne Herald. It is interesting to wonder how she has come a long way and how it is that she is such an expert on Libyan affairs. It is that connection which causes me great concern. The people of Australia have recently had the opportunity of hearing-those who were there-and of reading-those who read the Australian-what Sir Larry Lamb said in the Arthur Normal Smith Memorial Lecture in journalism. I quote from some of the sections of his speech which are relevant to this matter. Sir Larry Lamb said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are, of course, those who believe that the biggest threat to Press freedom comes not from outside, but from within.
There is no doubt that the most dangerous voice in politics today is the voice of the lunatic fringe of the Left-the ones who are dedicated to the destruction of society.
And since the first rule in the anarchists' handbooks is to infiltrate the media, there is no doubt that the Press has rather more than its share of them.
They exert and, I fear, will continue to exert, an influence out of all proportion to their numerical strength.
For that, we who occupy positions of power in the industry-
He is talking about proprietors of the industry-

have only ourselves to blame, for they are dedicated, tireless and without scruple in their determination to destroy, and we are part of the apathetic society. We are not only tolerant, which may be be commendable, but complacent, indolent, and all too often voiceless in defence of our ideas and ideals.
The wreckers, here in Australia, may be few . . . But they are there, and they are active.
Sir Larry Lamb went on to point out that he was not talking about people who stood for elected positions. He said:
I speak rather of those who wish to tear down our society and destroy our institutions without the remotest idea of what is to replace them.
There are such people. We ignore them at our peril.

I draw attention to the fact that a Melbourne radio station has a very large advertisement in today's Melbourne Age talking about 'the mouth that roars- Claudia Wright', and advertising her attendance on a particular radio station, I think, some time next week. In any event, I say to the proprietors of that radio station that they ought to read very carefully what Sir Larry Lamb had to say in that speech. I compare that speech with an article which appeared in Quadrant of April 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —A reliable journal.

—As Senator Button says, it is a reliable journal and it ought to be read more often by people who have the protection of Australia and Australian freedoms at heart. It was that article which alerted me to Claudia Wright-not the article which Senator Button talked about which appeared in that scrurrilous Melbourne newspaper. I quote from a section of Quadrant of April 1982 about Claudia Wright which referred to an article that that she had written on 20 March. Quadrant states:

SPEECH.PARA: In this same article (March 20) she repeatedly uses such terms as ''quislings'' , ''terror'', ''collaborator'' and ''purge'' to describe, and demean, almost every aspect of Reagan's administration, terms noticeably absent from the coverage of her favourite Arab countries (i.e. Libya and Iraq). Everyone, it seems, in the Reagan administration is a crook. If they are rich they are successful crooks, if not, unsuccessful ones.

Our great Australian Broadcasting Commission radio gave this person the opportunity to speak on two occasions. It was not satisfied with one occasion. On 13 November 1982 on a program called Saturday Guest she attacked the Reagan Administration and President Reagan using such terms as 'the job of President attracts a special kind of sadist'. That is just one quote from a speech which was broadcast in Australia by ABC radio. The following week, on 20 November 1982 , again on Saturday Guest, she attacked Margaret Thatcher. That week the program was supposed to be about women in politics but, for some reason or other, Margaret Thatcher does not appeal to her and she attacked her. She alleged that Margaret Thatcher was no longer female; that she was only female in sex.

It has been revealed to us that the KGB objective throughout the Western world is misinformation. We heard a lot about misinformation during the war when we had Lord Haw Haw representing the Germans, and Tokyo Rose representing the Japanese. But during the Korean war there developed a particular type of ' journalist-political agent'. I refer to one person by the name of Wilfred Burchett. I quote from an article in the Los Angeles Times written by one Tom Lambert and published on 26 February 1967. The article states:
The political or diplomatic journalist has long been a fixture in the newspaper world, the man whose subject is diplomacy, the relations, interplay and exchanges between nations.
That is right and proper. The article continues:

But with the inception of communism, and its deliberate subjection of journalism to ideology, a new type of reporter came into being in modern history -the journalist political agent. As such, Burchett is one of the most valuable in the Communist world. His contacts and abilities also make him one of the most suspect, perhaps one of the most dangerous. Burchett's eminence in his field is manifest in various ways, in both the Communist and free worlds . . .

I refer to Claudia Wright's detailed knowledge of Libyan affairs. It is interesting to consider how she is using this detailed knowledge in her publications. I refer to some publications which I have gathered from the Parliamentary Library. I have an article on Greece dated 27 February 1981 in which she referred to Greece as being 'another United States bomb site'. I have an extract from the New Statesman of 13 March 1981 entitled 'The new White House warmongers' in which again she attacked President Reagan as she is doing continually. She referred to him and his security staff as a 'bloodthirsty crew' . The article states:
Recently, Reagan has tried the ploy with which Adolf Hitler achieved some success in Germany.

These sorts of allegations continually come through in her pubications. It may very well be that newspapers are just as greedy as anyone else in industry, commerce, private or, indeed, public enterprise. Maybe they cannot resist publishing these things because they believe newspaper circulations will be increased.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should they resist?

—Senator Button asked: Should they resist? I do not care whether they resist or not. The point is that the people of Australia ought to know the sorts of publications that this woman has been making up until now. Decisions about what the New Statesman ought to publish are matters for the proprietors and the editor of the New Statesman. I refer to an article of 4 January 1980 entitled ' ''Crooked business as usual'' is the route to success in Washington'. Again, that was another violent attack on President Reagan and his colleagues. Another article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Who then can say whether Mr Connally is an old-fashioned and unclever crook favoured by the luck of having had unbelievable accomplices? Or an ideological simpleton who has mouthed his sponsors' slogans for so long that his public positions anticipate the rewards long before they are delivered, if they are delivered at all?

Another article under the heading 'Germany' has a further heading of 'The Middle East adventure'. It is dated 18 July 1980. This article is clearly an attempt to drive a wedge between the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies. She talks about the Germans being the lackeys of the Americans. She states:
On Middle Eastern issues the gap between American and German policy is far greater . . . than in any other area of collaboration.
She goes on and talks about officials to whom she alleges she has spoken and says that the Camp David framework will not work. That is clearly an attempt to drive a wedge.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of wedge? Is it large or small, Senator?

—It is a wedge between the West German Government and the United States Government. One other point is the question of whether she has named people. Let me refer to an article dated 1 January 1982 under the heading ' Reagan's new sweetheart'. I will quote from this article which, unfortunately, is already public. I will put it in the Hansard record. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Norman Descouteaux, CIA chief in Algiers, was exposed by the Algerian authorities and expelled. Covert Action Information Bulletin in Washington has identified three senior agents in Morocco. The latest, Joseph Pettinelli, arrived last February. David Wilson and Arthur Nimer Jr were spotted in Casablanca and Rabat two years ago; . . . In Morocco last March Jonas Savimbi of Unita had talks with General Walters, Lannon Walker and two CIA men from Rabat.

I believe that I have quite clearly made the points which I tried to make at Question Time. I am not endeavouring to have this woman's freedom of speech limited, I am simply asking that the people of Australia be alerted to the type of person she is so that they are aware of what her prejudices are when she broadcasts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity during this first reading debate on the bank Bills to make some comments about a report on child migrant education that was tabled last week but which was not included for debate. More specifically, I want to talk about a particular language problem. The report on child migrant education states:

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth funding of research studies in child migrant education has mainly been provided under programs of the Education Research and Development Committee (ERDC), which has been administered by a secretariate provided by the Commonwealth Department of Education. As a consequence of the Government's decision to abolish the ERDC-
That was one of the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions-
a major source of funds and initiative for research studies in child migrant education no longer exists.

There is no doubt about the widespread interest and concern in Australia today about all aspects of language and its usage. This has been borne out by the excellent response to the current reference of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts into the question of a national language policy in Australia. The needs of those whose mother tongue is other than English-migrants and Aborigines-are gradually being acknowledged. Language difference in this country is seen as a language deficit according to Ms Eva Fesl, who is Director of the Aboriginal Research Centre at Monash University. Too many children in this category go through the school system understanding only a fraction of what was sought to be taught.

Recent work in Melbourne showed that of one group of migrant children-most went through the system in primary school understanding only a quarter of the curriculum. Their difficulties within an insensitive system have frequently led to frustration, behavioural problems and an early rejection of schooling, as victims of a deficient system. Those children whose mother tongue is English are frequently missing out on the enrichment of their experience which the learning of a second language can contribute. Australian society is poorer generally because we lack appreciation of other cultures and retreat into the insularity and intolerance which our monolingual education has engendered.

There are some valuable initiatives currently seeking to overcome such historical disadvantages. At the North Ainslie Primary School here in the Australian Capital Territory, since 1978 the curriculum has included a Greek language program for children, parents and teachers, which has cost no more annually than the salary of one specialist teacher. This program is currently under threat of having its funding withdrawn or reduced by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a misunderstanding, Senator. I'll have to brief you.

—If Senator Baume will let me continue, I will point out that this innovative program, now in its fifth year, is one which involves the whole school, embracing as it does each child from the time of entry into kindergarten and before. The reasons for starting this program were social and educational. A significant number of Greek children were already at the school and were having language difficulties as well as experiencing problems of acceptance. Some children with a gift for languages were being denied an opportunity of becoming proficient in two languages. It was suspected that the self-image and self- esteem of children from different backgrounds could be raised considerably and this has been the case. The appreciation of Greek culture, rich in its traditions of literature, song, dance and cuisine, has provided a springboard for the study of other cultures.

SPEECH.PARA: This longitudinal program, including as it does each new intake into the school at kindergarten level, is creating a wealth of data for study by linguists, educators and government planning bodies and all for the price of one primary school teacher. I must admit, that teacher is required to be a very special person: In addition to being a linguist that person must be a diplomat and an expert teacher. It has also been suggested that above all it is necessary to have a native speaker-that is, one who has received virtually all initial schooling in the foreign language. Australian children of migrants or migrants who came to Australia before completion of secondary school generally do not have a firm enough grasp of their native language to provide high quality instruction in it. Also, their pronunciation is liable to be corrupt.

At the North Ainslie Primary School we have living, breathing evidence of the positive outcome of foreign language study in a primary school. The understanding of the principal of the school and the staff of the school is that in 1983 current funding will be cut to 50 per cent and in 1984 funding will cease altogether. A Schools Authority evaluation in 1980 found: That this program appears to be achieving very positive results with very limited resources; that there was a general improvement in reading ability, especially for the non-English speaking students, few of whom then required remedial teaching in reading; that there was evidence to suggest that the reading skills of all children had improved since the introduction of the Greek program.

The local community itself has been invited to comment on the contribution which is being made by the program. Their comments are very similar to those that have been collected from the parents at the North Ainslie Primary School who are overwhelmingly in favour of the program being continued. Important benefits mentioned by the parents were the increased self-confidence and pride that they now see in their children. One parent commented: 'Most children take pleasure in knowing something that their parents don't know, and my own kindergarten son feels obliged to teach me Greek'.

Continued provision of an out-of-formula teacher, which is advocated by the school, is essential. There is no possibility, apparently, of the sort of flexibility within the school curriculum that would provide for this extra teacher because the school is not in a growth area. Its current enrolment is 330 ; the numbers are not dropping but they are not increasing either. The appointment of a within-formula replacement teacher solely on aptitude in Greek could be self-defeating and would be at the expense of the rounded education program at present available within the school. Another suggestion, that one floating relief teacher with responsibility for the program would be adequate to continue the program, would be risky as a decline in the school numbers could cause a decline in the availability of hours. The principal believes that the slow death of a deteriorating program will occur unless the school can be assured of funding of an out-of-formula teacher. The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority specifically noted this necessity in its evaluation of four Australian Capital Territory primary schools with out-of-formula bilingual teachers. This evaluation was conducted in 1980, and this is what was said:
It was recommended that a special component be built into the staffing formula of those four pilot schools to allow one extra second language teacher from the start of 1981.

The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was invited to see this program in action. We had great pleasure in accepting the invitation and watching three classes during one morning a couple of weeks ago. We were able to see how, from the very beginning of school, children are given this opportunity to acquire another language, to acquire understanding of another culture and in fact to have their education enriched in very many ways. On the day we attended the next year's intake of kindergarten pupils was visiting the school and was mingling with the kindergarten pupils, who sang their songs and demonstrated their grip of the vocabulary and their great joy in the program in which they were involved. The multicultural strand of the program involves every child in the school. Intense study of Greek has been undertaken by the kindergarten children of 1978 and subsequent years and has now moved through to year 4. In the very early years there are three sessions a week in Greek. As they get older they have five sessions a week. Children from Greek speaking homes and monolingual children from kindergarten through to grade six, who have demonstrated a special language aptitude, are involved in intensive study of Greek. Some of these children have since graduated to high school. I believe that the Watson High School is one of those secondary schools in the Australian Capital Territory at which they are able, or were able, to continue their Greek studies. Implementation of the program has involved the development of teaching strategies, skills, materials, approaches, and a new curriculum. As I said before, all of this is done at the cost of one salary.

Future plans include the teaching of Greek as a written language. This has commenced in years 3 and 4 and these children are now capable of writing small stories, taking dictation and conversing in Greek. The study of grammar is being undertaken. Familiarity with the Greek alphabet, I might add, starts from the very early years. New developments which are being planned include the extension of the program into the senior school and developing literacy in the Greek language. The participation of the Arts and Liaison Committee of the North Ainslie School Board, comprised of board, parents and citizens and teacher members, has actively promoted the multicultural strand of the Greek program. Over the years classes have been held in handcrafts and cooking, and social evenings have been conducted. In 1982 interested parents attended Greek classes during school hours. They are being offered one hour's tuition per week and it had been planned to encourage and further extend this new language learning development in forthcoming years.

With the strong likelihood of the program being cut back to a half of a teacher next year and the funding being cut out altogether in 1984, the school community is anticipating that it will immediately have to discriminate. Up until this time all children have been able to learn Greek. In 1983 only some children will be able to do so, and those who will lose will be those who have become accustomed to losing. Losing seems to be their lot in life.
