If the Government is sincere about multicultural education, if it is prepared to follow the dicta put down by the previous Minister for Education, Senator Sir John Carrick, three years ago, that additional language teachers would be provided to allow these schools which are dedicated to the notion of giving children a second language, the opportunity may then be extended. Whatever the future may hold, whether the program continues or dies, in the words of the principal of the school:
Hundreds of children at this school have benefited enormously from their involvement in the learning of another language and the loss of our fine Greek program fills me with deep sorrow.

A number of reasons exist why this program should at least be allowed to continue at its present level until it has time to complete its function as a pilot study. That would allow the children currently involved in the program to continue through to the end of their primary school years. The program has been carefully developed. The cost to the nation and to the education system generally is minimal, this at a time when research generally into these particular language questions is falling, by default, onto the shoulders of people such as those at the North Ainslie School who have given an enormous amount of their own time and effort to make the program a success. Quite apart from everything else, there has been enrichment of the whole community life of the area. The children at school have this immense opportunity to acquire a second language, to acquire a greatly expanded approach to their environment and to the cultures of other people. The stimulus to their education has been marked . All of the teachers are very enthusiastic about the program and comment about the improvement in a wide range of skills, not just language skills, as a result of the extra stimulus that this program has provided. Above all, I believe that the expansion in community tolerance and understanding is invaluable. It simply cannot be quantified. I would urge the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) to give serious consideration to making it possible for the program to continue at its present level, at least until it is able to be continued as a complete study, over the span of primary school years for the 1978 pioneers of the program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of the first reading of the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Bill 1982, Bank Accounts Debits Tax Bill 1982 and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1982 to raise a matter which is of concern to the Australian Democrats, one which has been the topic of some discussion in this place on a number of occasions. Continuous assertions have been made about the voting record of the Australian Democrats in an attempt to try to diminish our independence in this place. For example, the Liberal Party used false statistics in the 1980 election campaign to attack our Senate candidates. One of the latest incorrect assertions was made by Senator Sir John Carrick on 26 October 1982 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if one wants to know how the Democrats will vote, they will vote as the limpet fish of the Labor Party.
He continued:
What I am saying is that on almost all matters of any significance in the Senate the Democrats can be relied upon to vote with the Labor Party . . .

These statements are totally incorrect. Senator Sir John Carrick has based his comments on a Liberal Party document which, quoting figures relating to divisions only, comes to the conclusion that the Democrats had voted with the Australian Labor Party three-quarters of the time. This is totally incorrect. There is, as anybody in this place knows, a very large distinction between votes and divisions.

I have written to the President (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) seeking his guidance on this matter and he has replied to me. In his reply he has said that he has no objection to my quoting from his letter. In it he said:
As you are aware, not all decisions of the Senate are taken by a vote, and comparatively few votes are determined by division.

In other words, to take divisions alone, as the Liberals do, and then to say that they represent all voting behaviour in the Senate, is grossly misleading. The ratio between votes and divisions is a very large one. From 15 August 1978 to 18 September 1980 there were 8,152 decisions taken by the Senate and there were only 247 divisions; that is, 8,152 to 247. The President, in his letter to me, said:

In January 1981, in response to an inquiry from Senator Mason, the then Clerk of the Senate provided some figures which indicate that only a small minority of decisions taken by the Senate were decided by division.
He went on:
It is obvious, however, that the number of decisions will always be very much greater than the number of recorded divisions.

No figures on the number of decisions in the current sittings of the Senate have been compiled. Since there is an enormous amount of work involved in the compilation of those figures I did not feel justified in seeking again from the Clerk of the Senate that such an activity ought to be undertaken. In relation to the proportion between decisions of the Senate and divisions called in this place and recorded in Hansard, the President noted:
. . . it is likely that, if figures were compiled for the present session, they would indicate a similar ratio between decisions and divisions.

In other words, divisions represent about 3 per cent of the number of decisions taken by this Senate. Yet anyone seeking to find how a senator votes can refer only to the divisions. They are the only records. According to the President, it is not possible to ascertain which way any senator voted on a decision that does not go to a division unless, only one senator expresses an opposing point of view and seeks to have that recorded in the Journals of this place. It should be noted that divisions under the Standing Orders can be called only by a minority, that is, they can be called only by the group against whom the decision is given by the person in the chair. Thus, when the Australian Democrats vote with the Government and constitute a majority, the Australian Democrats are unable, under the Standing Orders, to request a division and have their votes recorded in the Journals of this place. We believe it is grossly unfair and, indeed, improper for honourable senators who outside this place then totally misrepresent the actions of the senators in going about their business. Indeed, I believe it runs very close to a breach of the privilege of this House.

Because the Australian Democrats entered the Senate in 1977 and held the balance in 1981 it is nonsense, completely misleading and untrue to say that the Democrats have voted with the Australian Labor Party more than with the Liberal Party and National Party. That is unascertainable by any honourable senator. To so assert is indeed to seek deliberately to impede the activity of senators in carrying out their duties. I have raised this matter because I am extremely concerned. Indeed, if this were to occur again and if letters were to be written such as have been written, I would seek to bring that before the Senate as a matter of privilege so that misleading statements being made in other places can be brought before this chamber and the Senate can review them and see whether or not there has been an attempt by honourable senators to bring pressure to bear on other honourable senators as to how they should vote.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX ADMINISTRATION BILL 1982
The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the decision by the government to impose a new tax on debits to cheque accounts kept with banks in Australia.

This new tax should be recognised as being consistent with the government's policy of seeking to place greater reliance on indirect taxes in order that some relief can be given in the income tax field.

Indeed, this and the other budget measures by which a modest broadening of the indirect tax base has been achieved contributed significantly to our ability to responsibly make a substantial reduction in the personal income tax burden as proposed in the budget.
I turn now to the practical details of the new tax.
Subject to specified exemptions, the tax will apply to all debits made to a bank account on which cheques may be drawn.

Debits resulting from cheques drawn on an account, as well as other debits made to an account, such as for periodical transfer payments and for the charging of interest and bank fees, will be subject to the tax.

Debits to current accounts held with trading banks will be the primary subject of the tax, although it will also apply to debits to accounts with cheque drawing facilities with other banks such as savings banks, special purpose banks , and certain accounts with the Reserve Bank of Australia.
The liability to pay tax imposed on a debit made to a cheque account will, except in special cases identified in the Bill, fall on the bank in the first instance.
Banks with which cheque accounts are kept will be required to furnish to the Commissioner of Taxation monthly returns of taxable debits and to pay the tax imposed on those debits.
Payment of the tax will be required of the bank within 14 days after the end of the month to which the return and tax relate.
Although the banks will be primarily responsible for payment of the tax, the scheme of the tax is that the incidence of it will effectively fall on bank customers rather than on the banks.

The bill therefore proposes that the banks be given a statutory right to recover from their customers the tax payable on debits made to customers' accounts. This may be direct charge at the time of the debit entry or by some other periodical charge arrangement.
Exemption from the tax will be provided for a range of institutions and some persons.

These include public benevolent and religious bodies, hospitals, schools, government departments and instrumentalities, other than for government business undertakings, foreign diplomatic and consular personnel and international organizations for which Australia traditionally grants tax exemptions of this kind in recognition of our treaty obligations.
A person or body entitled to exemption from the tax will be able to apply to the Commissioner of Taxation for a certificate of exemption.
Banks will be freed from liability to pay tax in respect of debits to any account for which a certificate of exemption is in force.
Certain other classes of debits will also be exempt from the tax irrespective of whether a certificate or exemption is in force in respect of the account concerned.
These are debits made to an account to recover from the bank's customer the tax payable by the bank, debits made to reverse a prior credit entry and any debits which are subsequently reversed.
Where a bank has paid tax in relation to an entry but is unable to recover from its customer, the bank will be entitled to claim from the Commissioner of Taxation a refund of that tax.
A large portion of the bill is concerned with the machinery provisions of the kind commonly found in taxation acts which are necessary for the efficient administration and collection of a tax.

Honourable senators will note that the new tax will not apply to instruments known as bank cheques, since the scheme of the tax is that it will apply only to debits to customers accounts. Bank cheques are a convenient formal payment instrument for people in the community who do not maintain cheque accounts.
I also point out that exemption from the tax is to be provided for debits made to an account held by other banks with the Reserve Bank of Australia or with any other bank.

This exemption is intended to ensure that, as far as possible, the tax will fall on customers of banks and not on the banks themselves. This will ensure that the tax can only effectively fall once on particular transactions.
In drawing attention to these 2 features of the bill I sound a warning to any who might attempt to exploit them as a means of avoiding the tax.
Let me say, Mr President, that the government will not stand for any abuse of these exemptions and any move in that direction could well result in their withdrawal.

The bill as a whole, along with its associated bills, is explained in an explantory memorandum being made available to honourable senators and I think that I need say no more at this introductory stage.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX BILL 1982
This Bill formally imposes tax on debits to cheque accounts with banks and sets out the amount of tax payable by reference to the amount of a particular debit.
Originally the Government indicated in the Budget that the tax would apply from 1 January 1983.

Since then it has been put to the Government that there would be serious difficulties for some of the banks, on which primary responsibility for payment of the tax is to fall, in having in place by that date the necessary systems to cope with their administrative functions in relation to the tax.
The writing and testing of the necessary computer programs is, of course, a major task.
In addition, some banks have been under particular strain in relation to recent bank mergers and also because of the proposed imposition of state taxes.
The Government accepts that there may be a valid case for allowing more time for banks to prepare for the commencement of the tax.
It has therefore decided that the tax should now commence to apply from a date to be fixed by proclamation.
The government will, of course, in its discussions with the banks seek the earliest possible date for the commencement of the tax, consistent with practical convenience.
I turn now to the practical aspects of this Bill.
The tax to be imposed by this Bill will be in the range from 10 cents for debits of less than $100 up to $1.00 for debits of $5,000 or more.
The tax will generally be payable by the bank with which the account is held, subject to a right of recovery by the bank from its customer.
This Bill also imposes tax that, in special circumstances, will be payable by the customer of a bank.

This would be the case, for example, where a person who is a resident of Australia shifts his banking business to an overseas bank for the purpose of avoiding the tax in respect of an Australian account.
Tax would in that case be imposed on and payable by that person in respect of debits made to the overseas account.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS (JUDICIAL REVIEW) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This third Bill in the package associated with the new tax on bank account debits proposes an amendment, consequential upon the 2 Bills I have already introduced, to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.
Decisions under certain Acts are precluded from review through the system of review provided for by that Act.

Decisions connected with the new bank account debits tax are also to be excluded from the purview of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, consistent with the position that prevails in relation to decisions under various other Commonwealth taxation laws.

However, a bank or other person liable to pay an amount of bank account debits tax and who is dissatisfied with a prescribed decision or assessment by the Commissioner in relation to the tax will have available full rights of objection and appeal to a Taxation Board of Review or a Supreme Court and ultimately, if the matter warrants it, to the Federal and High Courts.

Other taxation laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation that provide similar rights to contest liability, as I say, are also excluded from review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.
I also commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.
(Quorum formed).

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1982 has the support of the Australian Labor Party. In other words, we do not intend to oppose the Bill. However, we intend to move an amendment and I believe that the Australian Democrats also propose to move an amendment which is acceptable to the Opposition. There will be an unusually large number of speakers in this debate. I understand that the Government was interested in expediting the program but there is to be more than the average number of speakers. For the consideration of the Senate we will make some comments and criticisms regarding the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Our criticisms and comments revolve around some key points. These are the inadequate funding which the Government has given for road development programs since it came to office in 1975; the unreasonable and political pressures that the Government is placing on the State governments and to that extent, on local government; and more importantly perhaps, the addition of yet another tax burden on the ordinary Australian because the funding of this Bill will considerably increase the costs of most goods produced and distributed in Australia. This flies in the face of the Government's so-called anti-inflationary policy. Another Bill which seeks to increase the costs of petroleum products and petrol in particular is to be regretted. We have a great deal of misgivings about this Bill in terms of what it is claimed is the strategy of the Fraser Government. We also question the political use to which funds will be put by the Government, particularly by the National Party senators who have attempted to introduce the principle of pork-barrelling and so on in respect of the way in which these funds are to be used. Of course, we also have some misgivings about the blatant misuse of the Bicentennial Authority which has been used for the purpose of justifying this added tax upon every Australian who uses a mode of transport.

The Bill before us seeks to establish the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund to receive funds raised by a special surcharge on motor spirit and diesel excise for the purpose of upgrading Australia's road system by 1988, which is the bicentennial year. I think it has to be said that the Government has failed miserably to arouse any enthusiasm among average Australians about the bicentennial year, which is now less than six years off. Yet, that event, which marks 200 years of white rule in this country, is being used as the pretext for upgrading our road system via the new tax. Of course as I said, this proposal flies in the face of the Government's anti-inflation policies because it is in fact highly inflationary. One, therefore, has the right and the obligation to criticise that aspect of the legislation.

The new tax is expected to yield a net $2.5 billion from the motorist over the next six years. The surcharge on motor spirit and diesel fuel will be 1c a litre as from last Budget night until 30 June, and then from 1 July next year it will be 2c a litre until 31 December 1988. But that, of course, does not take away the opportunity for another Liberal government-God forbid we should have another one like the Fraser Administration-to raise that surcharge subsequent to the passage of this legislation. The funds so collected are to be allocated to national highways including developmental roads, urban and arterial roads and local roads. But part of the urban arterial funding may be spent on urban public transport capital projects.

Of course, the Senate's attention ought to be drawn to the fact that some 40 years ago a conservative government introduced legislation to establish a fuel tax, the sole purpose of which was to build roads. The greatest percentage of the huge sum of money that has been collected over subsequent years has been going not to road construction but in fact to Commonwealth revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has gone to general revenue.

—As Senator Robertson correctly points out, it has gone to general revenue. However, we are given the justification for an additional fuel tax which, according to this Bill, will be especially set aside for the purpose of road building. This legislation gives to the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt), who is probably the chief pork-barreler in the Government, the sole power to allocate national highway funds. That is not a very satisfactory situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Urban arterial, rural arterial and local road funds are to be allocated on the basis of relativities contained in the Road Grants Act 1981-the Senate dealt with that legislation last year-and set out in the schedules attached to this Bill. The conditions that are applicable to the States and the Northern Territory before receiving these funds are that the Commonwealth Government will have to give approval for each of the projects covered under the program and that the States and the Northern Territory must maintain their real level of funding from their own resources. Here we have a situation where the Commonwealth is saying to the States: 'Well, we will allocate you these funds but you must also allocate an equal proportion of your last year's funding for road purposes if you want to qualify'. That seems to be the very antithesis of what the Government says about Commonwealth-State relations. How many times over the last few years have we heard Senator Sir John Carrick speak about 'co- operative federalism'? This is dictation from Canberra by a government which claims to stand for the principles of States rights and which was so critical of the Whitlam Government when we sought to establish some form of priority in respect of the sorts of roads and other public facilities and services that should be provided on the basis of equality and reaching a common standard. Yet this very government which rode to power on the alleged differences between the States and the Commonwealth, pledging its support for and faith in the principle of States rights, in fact is now imposing directions upon the State governments.

The Opposition takes the view that the injection of funds into road construction that will result from the Bill is certainly most welcome. That is why we are not opposing the legislation. As has been indicated, of course, we have much criticism to make of the Bill because the Bill is one of the best admissions one could have by this Government-by the Fraser Government, by the Frasers and the Howards-of its disastrous road policies since it came to office seven years ago in 1975. No doubt this Government is under siege and threat. It is now attempting to use the bicentennial concept for the purpose of trying to build up our important public road transport system. But instead of money for this purpose coming out of funds collected by way of a fuel tax that was established many years ago, we are confronted with an inflationary tax.

The Government will have two road programs when this legislation is passed-the program set up under the Road Grants Act and the proposed Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. Rather than improve the former, the Government has come up with a new scheme. It is another one of the gimmicks for which the Fraser Administration is so notorious. It is hoping to avoid reference to the disaster of its management of road grants legislation in past years. It does not matter which State or local government association or organisation throughout the Commonwealth of Australia one wishes to point to-every State and every local government body is dissatisfied with the Commonwealth's contribution to road funding. One has only to read what has been said by State road construction Ministers or representatives of local government associations in the various States speaking on behalf of local government bodies to appreciate that the Government is on the nose as far as its road construction responsibilities are concerned. Instead of meeting its obligations under the old fuel tax, it comes forth with this new project. Of course, we are entitled to say that the Government seeks to use an occasion and an additional tax to meet what should be its obligations.

I would like to refresh the memory of honourable senators in respect of this Government's record. The Government has had a very poor and inadequate record in respect of road grants since it came to office. In every single Budget year there has been a reduction in road funding to the States and local government. In the first Budget the funding was reduced by 8.2 per cent. In the following years it was reduced by 2.2 per cent, one per cent and 7.1 per cent. Last year it was reduced by 3.7 per cent. That means that in real terms $517m less has been available for road construction in Australia during the period of this Government. In my State of New South Wales the loss involved was $92m.

There has been much talk of job creation and unemployment. Surely, if the Government were really interested in creating jobs it could do so in this area, rather than come up with such gimmicks as a wage pause or wage freeze. Surely not only employment but also cost efficiency is involved. If you have an inefficient transport system, as is acknowledged by this legislation, additional costs must be built into retail and distributing charges which, in Australia, are enormous and growing as a result of the deficiencies of this Government. The Government is bent upon pursuing its own philosophical approach that if a dollar is spent in this field rather than in the private sector somehow or other the society will disintegrate.

We are talking not only about an actual reduction in funding allocations for road construction but also about a most incredible increase in road construction costs. In the last two years such costs have risen 31.2 per cent, yet this Government talks about a wage freeze, a wage pause. The workers are to carry the burden of the economic crisis arising from the problems of capital in the world and the inept and inefficient government of Mr Fraser and Mr Howard in Australia in particular. There is no price control on road construction costs. There has not been in the last two years an increase of 31 per cent or anywhere near that figure in main roads departments' works staff, but there certainly has been an increase of that level in road construction costs. That simply highlights the present situation, one in which we might as well have a guestimate-that is all one can hope to do in view of the nature of the Government's Estimates-that some $1,000m less has been spent on roads during this Government's term of office.

We have hardly passed the Estimates for 1982-83 in the Senate yet the deficit has gone up from $1.5 billion to $4 billion, more than it ever was under the Whitlam Government. Yet Government supporters have the audacity to defend it and to criticise Labor for the situation then, which merely reflected the economic position worldwide in the latter part of 1973 and 1974. Labor was then forced to defend everything as a result of the obstructionist position taken by the tories in the Australian Senate.

These cuts in road funding have occurred during a period of soaring road building costs. One need not guess at the figures. The recently released Bureau of Transport Economics report on road construction price indexes indicated that in one year, 1979-80, such costs went up by 15.9 per cent and, in 1980-81, by 15 .3 per cent. Surely we are on common ground in stating that the effect of this, combined with the Government's policy of reducing road funding, has been staggering and obvious for any driver to see. Therefore, the funds provided by this Bill will only just make up for the seven years of the Fraser Government's complete and utter neglect and unconcern for the state of road construction in Australia.

Now the Government seeks to solve the problem in one blow by adding another financial impost to the burden carried by the public. It will mean slugging the Australian public generally, the business sector and the transport industry, to the extent of $2.5 billion. If the Government had been really concerned about maintaining road grants it would have amended the actual States Grants (Roads) Act so that a fair share of motorists' taxes would be returned to the States for road works. It would not then have been necessary in this legislation to impose a new tax on motorists, who yet again are being asked to carry the Government. The Government not only has increased the price of petrol by imposing excise taxes which have risen alarmingly and have brought in millions of dollars for every Budget, but also now seeks to impose an additional tax. If one were to work out the Government's share of the increased cost of petrol in Australia it would be seen as taking into its own coffers about one-third of the price paid by the motorists.

The Bill attaches a number of conditions to the receipt of Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program funds. One is that the States maintain their own real level of road funding. That has no regard for the particular circumstances in which States find themselves as a result of the squeeze on health funding and the reduction of general revenue and special purpose grants. Similarly, housing funding has been reduced and additional tasks allocated to the States. This has happened at a time when the States are trying to take up the slack which has resulted from the almost total collapse of the private sector. I repeat, we live in a period in which the private sector is almost collapsing.

Recently, I spoke to a former member of my staff who is taking his doctorate in economics at Cambridge University and who is currently visiting Australia. He described England as an industrial wasteland. We are fast approaching that position in our own country, as a result particularly of the policies being pursued by Mr Fraser and Mr Howard, yet the States are expected to make funds available for public works programs. Road construction is an important decentralised form of employment activity which plays a vital role in local and rural centres as we try to update our arterial road system. Despite this, in the last seven years the Government has seen fit to reduce road funding.

Therefore, we are faced with a hypocritical proposition by a Government which itself has reduced the level of funding by $517m since 1975-76. Even worse, if some of the States cannot in the years ahead raise the additional money to maintain a real level of funding they will suffer a 100 per cent penalty. The amount by which they default will be withdrawn from them under this program. Thus, if in a particular State there is a problem associated with power, hospitalisation or education, necessitating a rearrangement of the State's Budget, the Government will impose a 100 per cent penalty so far as withdrawals from the fund are concerned.

Therefore, while we are not opposing the Bill, because it is at least doing something to overcome the road construction problem and provide employment opportunities, we are thoroughly justified in criticising the Government's approach. The States are now spending a record share of total funds on roads in order to compensate for the reduction in the Commonwealth's real road funding since 1975-76. At that time the Commonwealth funded 37.6 per cent of total real road funding. By 1979-80 that figure had fallen to 30 per cent. In order to compensate, the States' share rose from 30.5 per cent in 1975-76 to 39 per cent in 1979-80, an increase of almost one-third. So the States' share has increased while the Commonwealth's share has fallen by 20 per cent.

Now the Commonwealth wants to dictate to the States that they should maintain a real level of funding based on their peak expenditure levels of last year. That is an imposition upon, a dictation to, the States. In addition, ratepayers across Australia have been slugged with higher rates to help local government make up for deficiencies in funding by the Commonwealth Government. This legislation is thus designed to force up State licence fees and taxes upon motorists and road users. Unless the States take that unpopular step they will forfeit these funds; so it is heavy-handed, hypocritical and removes, right up to the year 1988, the discretion of the States with regard to a large part of their Budgets. In New South Wales in 1981 motor vehicle registration charges rose by 30 per cent. This year they rose by a further 13.6 per cent. This is a result of the Federal Government's policies. It is an effect of the so-called new federalism about which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) used to talk. We never hear that term used now by either the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick-I do not think he has used it in this place for the last year or so. All we used to hear was that record being played over and over again. The Federal Government is palming off its responsibilities to the States and refuses to provide further financial assistance.

In a further intrusion into the powers and rights of the States and local government, this Bill will also give the Minister for Transport and Construction the sole power to determine which national road projects are carried out under the Fund. This will leave the Fund open to discrimination and pork barrelling. Unfortunately, the Australian Bicentennial Authority has been dragged into this messy procedure. The Authority, which is supposed to be a non-political, non- partisan and unifying body, has been brought in to endorse the Fund. The Authority has been asked to excuse and soften the introduction of a new tax on the people of Australia and the Government should be condemned for dragging down in this way an authority which should be above party politics. The Opposition is therefore concerned about the Bill. It should not be used to cover up the neglect by the Fraser Government of Australia's road programs over the last seven years.

We are particularly concerned about the inadequate provision of funds for local roads. As our proposed amendment seeks to show, local government has been treated as a poor relation, by the Government in this legislation. The scheme will do precious little for local government because almost all the funds available will be taken away by the rise in petrol and diesel costs and by the removal of the exemption from excise duty on diesel fuel used off public roads. Naturally the Australian Council of Local Government Associations has objected to that. So, in overall terms, local government will be barely any better off as a result of this legislation, due to increased costs and the way in which the funding will be organised. I understand from preliminary estimates that in net terms local government will receive less than a two per cent real increase in road funds in 1982-83 and about a four per cent real increase in 1983-84, but it will suffer about an eight per cent decrease in real terms in the following year -this at a time when inflation is in double figures. Therefore, I move the Opposition amendment, which seeks to overcome that problem:
At end of motion, add, but the Senate-

(a) recognises the special roads needs of the various regions of Australia and deplores the failure of the Government to make provision in the Bill for an equitable allocation of national roads funds between the States and the Northern Territory; and
(b) condemns the government for its discriminatory decision to allocate an inadequate level of funds to local government bodies for local roads.

I believe that in the preparation of this legislation the Government failed completely to take into consideration its responsibilities in respect of environmental impact legislation. I have been provided with a list of the proposed construction of roads in Queensland. Judging by that list, there is no doubt that this Government has failed to understand its responsibilities in respect of its own legislation-legislation which was introduced by the Australian Government in 1973-74 and which requires an environmental impact statement for all public construction works. I am led to believe that, in some of the regions of Queensland where it is proposed to construct roads as part of the arterial system, the Government has failed to have any regard at all for the environment. These proposed roads in Queensland will go through rain forests and important coastal areas and will have a very important effect upon the local environment. My colleagues in the Australian Democrats propose to move an amendment to take this into consideration. It is clear that when this Bill was drawn up the Federal Government failed to comply with the provisions of its own legislation and the States, themselves, have not given due consideration to the need to carry out such construction works at a minimum cost to the environment.

We have had big struggles in this country about protecting our rain forests and other environmental treasures. In fact, we argue about them consistently in this place. We tend to forget that all actions by public authorities can, if they are not properly controlled and developed, have a detrimental effect on the local environment. To that extent, I believe that there is a very important need for the Australian Government to insist, when allocating funds to the States under this legislation, that there shall be due regard to protecting the local environment. It may well be that in some instances it will be impossible to avoid an impact on the local environment, but as far as is practicable there ought to be a public inquiry or at least an inquiry carried out by the appropriate national or State authority to ensure that there is minimum damage to the local environment. That is the purpose of Dr Cass's environmental legislation, which received the approval of the Parliament and which the Commonwealth is now obliged to see applied. To the extent that the Democrats' proposed amendment will seek to establish some principles in respect of that, the Australian Labor Party is prepared to accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity once again to enter a debate on road development funds and the allocation of those funds between the respective States. I say at the outset that the Government's move in establishing the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund should be commended by all Australians. It is further proof of this Government's recognition of the importance of road transport to the national and regional economies in a way that is both imaginitive and appropriate. It will form the basis of a significant contribution to Australia's bicentenary celebrations in 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the auspices of this Trust Fund an additional $2,500m in road development funds is expected to become available by 1988. Together with the road grants already set aside following the Government's announcement in June of 1980, totalling $3,650m in the five financial years ending 30 June 1985, the funds generated by this Trust Fund will contribute towards meeting the objectives which the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) outlined in the House of Representatives in his second reading speech on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill. Foremost amongst these objectives is the completion of the national highway system, which is to be sealed and made virtually flood free by 1988. In my view, that in itself is a commendable task.

At 30 June this year some 11 per cent or 1,700 kilometres of Australia's national highway network of 16,100 kilometres remained unsealed. The unsealed sections, located primarily in Western Australia, South Australia and Queensland , are frequently parts of major commercial and passenger links, such as between Port Hedland and Mount Newman in Western Australia and between Townsville and Rockhampton in Queensland. The upgrading of those roads to a dust free condition is therefore a major importance to the tourist industry as well as to the regional industries of the areas concerned. Many of Australia's sealed national highways also require upgrading and this requirement will be met as well by the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. It is a fact that Australia, perhaps more than any other developed nation, relies upon road transport. A total of 80 per cent of domestic freight is carried and nearly 90 per cent of passenger kilometres are travelled on the Australian road network, which in all stretches over 860,000 kilometres. In very many senses, they are the arteries of this nation.

Moreover, it is important to note that the Fund which this legislation establishes and the programs which will proceed from it cover not only national highways; specific urban and rural arterial road projects will be funded and, where the States choose, assistance will also be provided for urban public transport projects. Local authorities may also nominate for the inclusion of local roadworks in the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. It is, as I said earlier, an imaginative program which holds out the prospect of long- lasting benefits for Australia beyond the bicentennial year in which the surcharge by which the Fund raises money will be terminated.

The program very appropriately channels money raised by a levy on motor spirit, at the rate of 1c a litre from Budget night to 30 June next year, and then at the rate of 2c a litre thereafter until the scheme terminates, from the motorist to road development work throughout Australia. It will, as I understand it, provide employment for 8,000 persons directly in the road construction industry and will generate about 20,000 jobs, directly or indirectly, throughout the duration of the program. In that sense, this initiative is a significant contribution to the economy while it is under way and, of course, it will provide lasting benefits when the work is completed and the objects of the program have, by that time, been met.

Moreover, it is important to understand at this point that the funds that will become available through the program are no mere cosmetic gesture. In this financial year, the first year in which the Fund will operate and during which time it is really establishing itself, it will make about $180m available for roads. That, together with the $734m already committed under the Roads Grants Act, means that this year a total of $914m will be made available for roads in Australia. That represents an increase of about 33 per cent over the funds available in 1980-81. It is expected that in 1983-84 a total of $1,208m will be available from these two sources, or a further 32 per cent increase over the amount to be spent in this financial year. In the first two years of the program the amount spent on roads will have almost doubled. Even when allowance is made for inflation, it is clear that significant real increases have been made in this area. I would think that there would be little argument that this is warranted when the importance of the road system in Australia is taken into account, as it quite properly should be.

Yet, as a senator from Western Australia, I must say that the same doubts about the outcome of this legislation arise as when the Road Grants Bill was debated in this place last May. Looking at the national road allocations this year, we find that Western Australia will receive 10.6 per cent of the road funds, yet that State contains 29 per cent of the national highway system. In terms of the increase in road funding for States over the previous financial year, we find that New South Wales will receive a 32 per cent increase-the same as Western Australia-while Queensland will receive a 34 per cent increase. In my view, that does not reflect the relative needs of those three States. With roughly one- third of Australia's land mass, Western Australia contains about 3 kilometres in 10 of its national highways, and yet it receives $1 in $10 of Commonwealth expenditure on national highways.

A joint Commonwealth task force indicates that it would take 44 years-in other words, to the year 2026-to bring national highways to what is defined as intermediate highway standards in Western Australia. For New South Wales to achieve the same result it is estimated that it would take 24 years, and for Queensland it would take 33 years. I made that point during the debate on the Road Grants Bill and I reiterate it today. In terms of funding for national highways under the road grants formula, Western Australia receives 10.49 per cent of the total allocation. I maintain that that is inadequate as a share of road funds, and I maintain that the 10.57 per cent of overall funds for national highway roads allocated to Western Australia remains inadequate to develop and maintain national highways in Western Australia at an acceptable standard.

I therefore express the hope that those allocations, which are described as ' indicative statistics only' by the Department of Transport and Construction, and 'to be discussed with the relevant State governments', will be subject to substantial revision in due course. However, I must say that if the trend in the allocation of road funds over the last decade or more is continued, I do not hold out much hope that Western Australia will receive the consideration that it quite properly deserves.

Turning to the total allocations which the States will receive, not only for national highways, which will account for 40 per cent of Australia's Bicentennial Road Development Program funds, but for arterial roads and for local roads as well, in 1982-83 we find that Western Australia's share is anticipated to be $112.3m. I might point out that I say 'anticipated' because, like the funds for national roads, the totals are subject to some discussion with the State governments. However, given that these figures are anticipated, honourable senators should note that a similar discrepancy arises in the case of Western Australia's allocation of its share of all roads in this country.

Nearly 20 per cent of Australia's total public road network is in Western Australia, yet its total allocation from all sources-that is, from the Roads Grants Act allocations and from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund-amounts to 12.3 per cent of all funds allocated. In 1983-84, when this legislation provides for a change in the proportions between national highways and other roads in the program, with national highways then taking 42 per cent of the total funds allocated from the program instead of the 40 per cent set down for this year, Western Australia's share does not change. For the next financial year it still gets 12.3 per cent of the available funds. Perhaps Western Australians ought to be grateful for that, because since 1968-69 every time there has been a change in the proportion of Commonwealth funds being allocated to that State, that change has invariably been for the worse. I have a table which illustrates this point and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
