TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I think that the point is clear for those who care to read the penetrating observation which has been tabled. In 1968-69 Western Australia received 17.9 per cent of the Commonwealth road funds. By 1972-73 the proportion was 15.74 per cent. In this financial year it is expected to be 12.27 per cent, and for the next year it will be precisely the same. Yet once again New South Wales and Queensland, the two States which have already seen the largest share of funds for national highways, had the largest share of overall funds allocated also. What is more, I would expect this to be a matter of concern for senators from South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory to take up during this debate. These States will actually lose part of their share in the 1983-84 deliberations in order that the proportion of the overall funds allocated to New South Wales and Queensland can be increased. I can say only that when the final figures for these allocations are calculated in consultation with the State governments, I hope that it is not decided to reduce further the proportion which is earmarked for Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australians are already aware that the proportion of Commonwealth funds made available to them is not sufficient, and that the proportion is far exceeded by that State's actual share of the overall road network, and they will accept not further reductions. When I last canvassed this subject during the Road Grants Bill debate I indicated that there were very good reasons why that was to be the case. Previous road developments, such as the beef roads program in the 1960s, were particularly important in opening up the north-west. A modest outlay of $40m opened up an industry in the region which was responsible for export sales in excess of $200m during that same period. Similarly, the more recent road programs provided access to the site of major mineral developments which have brought with them important new population centres, often in very isolated parts of the country.

The costs associated with living in the north are naturally greater than in the more populous, more temperate southern regions of Australia. Earlier this year I indicated to the Senate that the cost, for instance, of building a three-bedroom house in Port Hedland suitable for Pilbara conditions was 78 per cent higher than in Perth. Many of the building materials and the internal fittings necessary must be transported from Perth or other major centres in the south and most of it is in fact carried by road. Food is also transported mainly by road. So it is essential that roads in the north of Western Australia be in the best possible condition to ensure not only regular reliable supplies in all weather but also prices that are as close as possible to capital city prices.

Figures recently provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicate that on average retail food prices are 21 per cent higher in the north of Western Australia than they are in Perth. They are 36 per cent higher in Kununurra, 31 per cent higher in Halls Creek and Wittenoom and 33 per cent higher in Marble Bar. One way to ensure that prices are kept down is by keeping the roads in the best possible condition. That in turn impinges on freight costs by reducing maintenance costs for transport operators, which improves the quality of life in these regions and may as a consequence improve such other areas as industrial relations and productivity.

In other words, Western Australians have a just call for a greater share of Commonwealth road funds which meet the objectives of keeping roads at a standard sufficient to ensure that one of Australia's fastest developing regions can continue to expand. From the way in which the funds have been allocated over the past decade and from the indicative figures for allocation of funds from this program, there is reason to believe that Western Australia's allocation will continue to be insufficient.
In this respect there is another very important reason to ensure that roads in the north-west of Western Australia are kept in good condition-that is, the matter of defence.

At the Seventh Northern Australia Development Seminar held in Port Hedland this year the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Ray O'Connor, emphasised the need to ensure the defence of the north and of its vast mineral resources. The entire northern and western coastlines are possible threatened areas and road planning should take into account the supply requirements of Australian forces deployed to meet any perceived threat. For that reason a road network close to the coast must be maintained at the highest possible standard. However, for the same reason as such roads are necessary in an attack situation, they are also very vulnerable because of their proximity to the coast. For example, in a hypothetical attack on Darwin there would be two distinct supply routes-one to Adelaide and the other to the Sydney-Melborne industrial triangle via Mount Isa. On the other hand, the Pilbara does not have this advantage. It has only one road leading to Perth which at times is perilously close to the coast. Of course , in those circumstances road contact could be very easily broken.

In the context of Australia's northern defence requirements consideration, in my view, should be given to an alternative road network to ensure flexibility in the deployment of forces, equipment and supplies in the event of an attack on this country. Consideration should be given also to hardening suitable strips of national highway so that in such an event they could be used as airstrips. In that way they would be subject to constant maintenace in the normal course of roadworks and would be immediately available in the event of any emergency. In that instance they could well have civil defence functions. In such events as flooding, which isolates parts of the north from normal road communications, such an innovation is useful also in peacetime.

Finally in this vein, it is clearly an important defence function of Australia' s road network that it be designed to specifications sufficient to cope with the bulk and weight of military road transportation and equipment. Such developments will contribute to a level of defence preparedness which is increasingly important in today's uncertain world situation.

However, the principal question in considering the allocation of road funds is whether they are sufficient to meet the needs of each State. In the case of Western Australia, I submit that they are not. It is now time for the basis for the allocation of road funds to be reassessed. A system must be devised which more closely follows the extent of the road network in each State so that no one region is favoured or discriminated against in road fund allocations. If a particular State has 20 per cent of the country's roads, as does Western Australia, allocation should be made after consideration of the general condition of those roads, given of course the other impinging factors. The fact is that Western Australia has one of the largest strips of unsealed national highway in Australia. It has been estimated that it would take longer in Western Australia to bring highways to intermediate highway standard as defined than in any other State. Yet Western Australia's share of road funds over the past decade has been declining. These are anomalies which require urgent redress.

Certainly the Western Australian Government recognises that fact and has considerably increased its contribution towards road funds. In 1968-69 its contribution to roads was $13.19m or, to put it another way, about 43 per cent of the Commonwealth's contribution to Western Australia's road funding. In 1981- 82 the Western Australian Government set aside $78.7m for roads against $83.9m in Commonwealth grants. The Western Australian Government has therefore lifted its contribution to nearly 94 per cent of that of the Commonwealth Government. Over the period 1968 to 1982, while the Commonwealth has increased its funding for roads in dollar terms by 175 per cent, the State Government has increased its road spending from State revenue sources by nearly 500 per cent. In 1981-82 Western Australians paid $62.46 per head in State charges for roads-a commitment by the people of that State which not only improved their lifestyle but which, in my view, also contributed towards a generation of further export income for this nation.

Western Australians clearly understand the importance of developing a road network in their State and they have acted accordingly. The State Government's commitment to the road network has been constantly increasing in real terms throughout the past decade. With respect, it is therefore incumbent on the Federal Government to recognise the importance to the national economy and to the regional economies of Western Australia of the road network and to adjust its financial commitment accordingly. The relative allocation between the States must be reassessed and redressed. If the condition of roads in Western Australia is not to suffer relative to other States, a new formula will have to be devised .

The matter which concerns me and which concerns all Western Australians is the level of funding received by Western Australia for its roads as compared with the total allocation to all the States. The Bill before us today does not allocate funding on a State by State basis. It simply provides a mechanism by which these funds are to be raised and distributed. As I said earlier, to that extent I believe it is a bold move, a wise move and one worthy of support in this chamber. Any initiative which increases the level of road funding is welcome and a program which will spend an estimated $2.5 billion by the end of 1988 is especially so. Without hesitation, therefore, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any matter that is ever brought before this place that indicates more the need for a States' House, as the Senate is, than does a Bill dealing with roads. One has only to look at the repeated speakers lists that come up whenever a roads grants Bill is debated, or whenever a report on roads is debated, to find the majority of speakers come from Western Australia, South Australia or Queensland. We are not facing a different circumstance today. Six of the seven speakers are from those three States-the three largest states in the Commonwealth and the three States which, as the previous speaker has already indicated, are the hardest done by when it comes to road funding. I do not very often find myself in agreement with Senator Crichton-Browne, but I am forced to endorse wholeheartedly his call for a different formula to apply to the disbursement of road funding and road grants in Australia. I have not bothered to check with the Minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), but I do not think it is possible to incorporate a map in Hansard, I really would not like to push the issue, but it is a pity that we cannot without causing Hansard a great deal of additional--
—Would you like to read it into Hansard?

—Yes. It is like trying to incorporate a three dimensional matrix or something. Anybody who sees the Australian Bicentennial Road Program national highways map would be aware of why senators such as Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Jessop, Senator Colston and I are on our feet or are intending to be on our feet today to speak on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Bill. A quick look at the work which remains to be done on Australia's national highway system indicates that the majority of that work is in South Australia and Western Australia with a lesser amount to be done in Queensland; nevertheless there is still substantially more work required there than in Victoria and New South Wales, the two states which tend to be most favoured when it comes to the allocation of funds vis-a-vis the extent of their road systems. So I say to Senator Crichton- Browne that South Australia is just as hard done by as Western Australia is when it comes to road funding allocations. This Bill goes some little way towards correcting this inequity, but as Senator Crichton-Browne indicated, it does not go far enough.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill in effect is to establish the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund from which an estimated $2.5 billion will be provided over the next six years to upgrade Australia's roads by 1988. This will be spent mainly on upgrading and sealing national highways, but a certain amount of it will also be allocated to local and arterial roads. I say that that is not before time. I have said before in this place that Australia's roads are a national disgrace, if not exactly a national liability. One thing is certain, and that is that they are not a national asset. One hopes that after the expenditure of this money, with the additional $3.65 billion which has been provided for the States under the Roads Grants Act 1981, our roads system will become more in tune with the needs and rights of the Australian people in all States, not just in Victoria and New South Wales. The two programs will together provide some $914m in 1982-83, rising to something in the vicinity of $1,208m in 1983-84 for all categories of roads. This money is sorely needed, partly because of the inequities in the disbursement of the funds over the years but also partly because it has been a habit of this Government to reject the recommendations of the Bureau of Transport Economics for funding; a fact that I have pointed out on previous occasions and which I do not intend to go into again today. I suppose we ought to be grateful that after withholding what I would consider to be basic funding entitlements to large parts of this country, the Government has at least grasped the 1988 nettle to make some sort of bicentennial roads razmataz. As I said, for that we ought to be duly grateful.

It is ironic that, as Senator Gietzelt pointed out earlier, in order to do this the Government has imposed a levy on the one item in this country which affects the price of almost every other commodity and that is the price of petrol. Nevertheless, if that is the price we have to pay to get our road needs fulfilled, I suppose we have to grin and bear it. I cannot see much else being done at the moment. However, I sincerely hope that the Bicentennial Road Development Program does not simpy become an excuse for ribbon-cutting or some sort of self-congratulatory exercise in 1988, that in fact it does contribute substantially to the transport, movement, defence and safety needs of the people of Australia. I hope too that in particular it does something for those people in isolated rural areas and not just for those who are on tourist tracks, which is something which rates continual mention in the Bill. There is constant reference to tourist development. I ask the Government to pay just as much consideration to the needs of people in isolated rural areas whose contribution to the economy of this country is at least as great as that of tourists, either international or national.

As I said, over recent years the Government has continually ignored the recommendations of the Bureau of Transport Economics and as a result a critical situation has developed; a fact which the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) admitted in his second reading speech when he noted that the level of this Government's funding of roads has not kept pace with increases in road construction costs. He particularly mentioned in his speech the road between Rockhampton and Townsville as being 'to put it mildly-totally inadequate '. That is something I would have to endorse, having recently travelled by car that part of the road from Townsville to Mackay and discovered the rather nervewracking experience of shattered edges, very narrow roads and these astonishing one-way bridges that one runs across, if not actually into, on this route.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows that we need the money.

—Indeed it does. It shows that at least in that section, Queensland needs the money. Drivers in Queensland have this game of Russian roulette on one-way roads. I am sure Senator Bjelke-Petersen will correct me if I get my directions wrong, but between Townsville and Mackay southbound traffic has right of way, but between Townsville and Cairns northbound traffic has right of way. When I was travelling that road I passed a number of Western Australian cars, campervans, trailers, caravans and so on and I just wondered who had initiated them into the local rules of whom they were or were not supposed to give way to. I trust the Government will pay some attention at least to getting the give-way signs all going the same way in Queensland; or is this a plot by the people north of Townsville to get a separate State?
—They think their interstate visitors are very clever people.

—Is that what it is? I certainly hope for the sake of the interstate visitors, as well as the locals, that indeed they are. There is no question, however, that the demands on the road system in Australia are increasing all the time. As I said in an earlier speech, despite increased fuel prices the amount of travel on metropolitan road networks in particular is expected to increase by a further 40 per cent by the year 2000; and that, I remind the Senate, is only 18 years ahead of us. As has already been mentioned today, Australia is highly dependent on an efficient road transport system for the movement of its people and its primary and manufactured products and for its defence as well as, of course, the safety of the people who are travelling on those roads. For a variety of reasons we have a scattered population in a very large country. Vast distances exist between large population centres and even vaster distances exist between small population centres and urban areas. We are extremely vulnerable when it comes to any sort of attack from outside, although I sometimes suspect that the attackers might get to our shores, take one look at our road system and go home again.
—They would not get very far.

—No, I do not think they would get very far. Certainly any very heavy armoured equipment would have to stay on the periphery of our country. The Australian Democrats believe that Australia is sorely in need of a national transport commission to co-ordinate all types of interstate transport in Australia and to promote a national transport system which makes efficient use of the resources that we have. We believe that we need substantially increased road transport planning and research allocations. We believe that it is essential to take a long term comprehensive view of these matters rather than the present piecemeal or ad hoc approach. The Democrats favour the allocation of increased funds from Federal sources to existing road construction authorities through a rolling five-year program which allows proper forward planning of works. We believe that more attention should be paid to the administration of national road safety programs. Finally, we believe that specific attention should be paid to the protection of wildlife and the environment generally with regard to road programs. It is this latter point, to which I will refer in a moment, that relates to the amendment that we intend to move to the Australian Labor Party's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said in his second reading speech that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program will save lives. I sincerely hope that he is right. If it is one of the aims of the Program, I suggest that it would be wise to have as one criterion for funding programs that are suggested by local and State governments, an evaluation of the cost effectiveness of various measures for increasing safety rather than just blandly assuming that general upgrading, sealing and patching of roads will be an adequate safety measure in itself. I do not believe that that is the case. Certainly, the Director of the Road Accident Research Unit at the Adelaide University does not believe that that is the case. He believes that road safety involves not only sealing and maintaining roads but also improving roadside design and road design, which include measures such as making sure that in country areas there is distinct separation of lanes; that there are sufficient traffic signs not only in the countryside but also in the cities; that there is an increase of embankments, barriers and so on. All of these things need to be considered when projects are put forward for funding.

The Australian Democrats support any increased funding for roads and commend the Government for the action that it is taking, although we believe that it is overdue. We are pleased to see that local government authorities will be encouraged to be involved, given that for the last few years at least they have been particularly hard pressed, with increased responsibilities for upgrading and maintaining their local roads, while their responsibilities to rate payers in other areas are having to take second place. We are pleased also to see that this is a labour intensive program in a period when unemployment is reaching record heights. I understand that it is estimated that 8,000 jobs will be directly involved in this program, with a toal of 20,000 jobs brought in on an indirect basis.

Having said that we support the concept of the Bill and the basics behind this program, I refer to some specific concerns that have been raised, particularly with regard to the environmental and conservation aspects of road development in this country. I have received a letter from a Mr D. G. Hill, the Deputy Director of the Conservation Council of Western Australia. He raised a matter of concern to him and to other environmental groups with regard to the potential destruction of the environment by some road projects. He specifically mentioned two. The first is the proposed road through the Hamersley Range National Park which is to be funded by the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund . He is concerned that he has received information-I have no knowledge whether this is correct-that the 18 kilometre road through the park will be fenced on both sides. He acknowledged that this is necessary to stop off-road vehicles moving into the more vulnerable sections of the national park. But he questions the fact that there has apparently been no public environmental assessment on the road proposal. The first that anybody knew about it was apparently when legislation was introduced into State Parliament to excise the road reservation from the national park.

The second project that he mentioned is a new urban controlled access highway which, as he rightly pointed out, is only a freeway by another name, which has been approved by the Western Australian Government, despite the fact that it has been strongly and consistently opposed by residents and local government authorities in the area. This route passes through prime coastal lands, including the Bold Park and Wembley Golf Links. Although no Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust funds have yet been allocated, Mr Hill understands that the State Government is seeking such funding. The concerns that he raised about these two projects have been echoed by a number of other environmental and conservation groups which ask only that when projects are being assessed by the Commonwealth Government for funding, environmental and conservation aspects be taken into consideration. That is behind the amendment that the Democrats will move to the Australian Labor Party's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. I move:
After paragraph (b) of the words proposed to be added,-
That is, to be added by the Australian Labor Party's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill-
add:
'(c) is of the opinion that no grant should be made under the Bicentennial Road Development Program unless the proposed project
(i) is subject to the procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 as if it were a Commonwealth project, and
(ii) makes provision for appropriate rest areas and for the enhancement of the adjacent landscape by the planting of trees and other vegetation'.

The Commonwealth Government is involved not only in a road funding and development program but also in a national tree program for the bicentenary. We are asking through this amendment to the second reading motion that the Government takes the opportunity of tying the two things together. It should tie its concern for environmental maintenance and development with its concern for the development of the road system in this country. It is an ideal opportunity to do both. If it ensures that some of the criteria used for determining whether a project will be given the go ahead under the roads program are a satisfactory environmental study and satisfactory awareness of potential damage to the environment, I believe it has a first class opportunity for achieving both its aims and achieving something very worth while for Australia as whole and for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1982 is finally being debated in the Senate. I congratulate the Government and the Minister for Transport and Construction, the Honourable Ralph Hunt, on the introduction of this Bill. I take the opportunity this afternoon to make some comments on it. I was in Mundubbera last Saturday and I met the Commissioner for Main Roads. He asked me when this Bill would be passed so that they could start to organise their schemes. I met the Under Treasurer of the Queensland Treasury Department at the Premiers Conference the other day and he asked me the same question; so once the Bill is passed the governments of the various States will have the opportunity to get their bicentennial roads schemes under way. Comparisons of Australia's road system with those of many other countries leave us wondering whether the other countries were wrong and over-invested in road networks, or whether they were right and Australia, with its relatively poor road networks, was wrong. I feel that not enough money has been allocated to roads in Australia over many years. One can certainly experience the consequences of that as one travels in western Queensland. Senator Haines seems to have had a few experiences while she was travelling up north in our beautiful State.
—It is beautiful, but it is dangerous.

—That is right. I can understand why she likes to go up north. I am glad to know that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program will provide a beautiful road right up to the north of our lovely State. I cannot understand why money for roads has assumed such a low position on the scale for such a long time.
—That is because most of the politicians come from New South Wales and Victoria.

—That is a good answer. I think that could well be taken into account. I am glad to know, from my reading of the figures, that Queensland will have a share in the goodies when this bicentennial roads scheme goes through. It is not before time. Queensland is the most decentralised State in Australia. Its roads cover vast distances. For a long time Queensland has had roads which need improvement. On an overall look at Australia's roads needs, three factors should be kept in mind: Firstly, the Government must make decisions based on current knowledge and rational future predictions; secondly, it must see all transport modes as interacting parts of our overall communications system; and, thirdly, funds must be allocated in accordance with real needs. That, I feel, is what the Government is trying to do through this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the Government has taken a considerable step forward in the right direction with the introduction of the Roads Grants Amendment Bill, in the first place, and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1982, in the second place. Both of these will contribute towards making significant changes to the Australian road systems, in terms of not only additional revenue but also forward thinking policies. The aim of this Trust Fund is to receive moneys raised by a special surcharge on motor spirit and diesel fuel excise for the purpose of funding major road construction and urban public transport projects to significantly upgrade Australian roads by 1988-the bicentennial year . The only thing I regret, along with previous speakers in this debate, is that money has to be raised by imposing a tax on fuel. Fuel is used in large quantities by people who live in the outback and this charge will be very costly for them. But if the roads are improved through this program it will be of distinct advantage to them.

An estimated $2.5 billion will be provided over six years to upgrade Australia' s roads by 1988. Of course, this funding is in addition to and separate from the $3.65 billion provided to the States under the Roads Grants Act 1981. Together both programs will provide $914m in 1982-83, rising to $1,208m in 1983-84, for all categories of roads. This is the biggest single drive to boost road construction and improvement of roads ever mounted in this country. Its object is to fund national, arterial and local road projects of significance that will develop the Australian road network to a high standard. I feel confident that these two Government initiatives will help to alleviate some of the problems faced by Australian motorists and particularly the country dwellers who have had to cope with very bad roads for such a long period. It is hoped that this injection of funds will indirectly help to reduce our phenomenal road carnage- the single biggest killer of Australians each year. No doubt honourable senators are aware that most fatalities on the roads occur in country areas. I cannot help but blame the poor-in some cases, very bad-condition of roads in those areas for a large percentage of those fatalities. We can only hope-I certainly do-that better roads will reduce this senseless destruction of human life.

Apart from that most positive benefit, a number of other significant benefits will accrue from these schemes. Lives will be saved as a result of the improved safety of our roads. Communications between States and regional centres will be enhanced. Savings in vehicle and transport operating costs will result. Obviously, there will be savings in travelling time. Some honourable senators have referred to the fact that 8,000 jobs will be provided in the road construction industry alone. At least 20,000 jobs are expected to be provided in both direct and indirect employment throughout the Program's duration. The Government has acknowledged that the level of its funding for roads in recent years has not kept pace with increases in road construction costs. The Minister has indicated to me on several occasions that Queensland, of all the Australian States, is the most disadvantaged and underfunded State when it comes to road funds.

An assessment of the Australian road system by the Bureau of Transport Economics in its analysis of results stated that expenditure in Queensland represented two-thirds of the efficient allocation, with underallocations in all categories other than rural local roads. Expenditure on national highways in Queensland was one-third of the efficient allocation for this category. Expenditure on rural arterials in Queensland was half the efficient allocation. That represents the largest misallocation of expenditure of all the Australian States. Expenditure on rural local roads in all States was above the efficient allocation, except in Queensland where it was the lowest. It is very good to know that more funds will be spent on Queensland's roads.

However, total Commonwealth road funding in 1982-83 will amount to some $914m, which is an increase of $2,299m or 33 per cent when compared with road funds allocated in 1981-82. The special ABRD surcharge on motor spirit and diesel fuel excise is being phased in to allow State and Northern Territory road authorities time to gear up for the substantial increase in construction activity that will result. Queensland, for its part, will recieve a 35 per cent increase this year and an 81 per cent increase in 1983-84 compared with 1982-83 figures. This is a substantial increase and will provide the much needed funds for Queensland to develop its massive road network. I know, from personal discussions with the Queensland Minister for Main roads, the Honourable Russell Hinze, that he and the Queensland Government also are very pleased with the allocations and there now seems to be hope that much can be done to improve the 42,000 kilometres of roads which Queensland possesses. In Queensland the grant will be distributed according to a formula developed by the Main Roads Department in consultation with the local Governemnt Associations of Queensland and the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Construction. A total of 52.7 per cent or $17,786, 000 of the local roads grant will be distributed to councils for expenditure on roads under their control. The balance of the grant will be allocated to the Main Roads Department for roads under its control and for special works on local government controlled roads.

If there is any criticism of the initiatives in road funding which the Government has introduced-both last year and this year-I think it is the requirement that tenders be called for all construction work on national roads. According to my research, there is no evidence to suggest that this approach will result in more efficient and cost-effective construction. In fact, it appears that the disadvantages which may accrue from the proposal outweigh the advantages. I feel there are some disadvantages in this proposal. It is likely that there will be retrenchments of departmental and local authority employees. Parts of existing departmental and local authority employees. Parts of existing departmental plant fleet, could become redundant.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good point. I have been making it around Tasmania for months.

—That is good. I am glad that Senator Tate and I agree. Capacity to handle emergency works would be lost and the continued existence of some departments' offices would need to be questioned. I feel that perhaps that this is a retrograde step for local authorities although I was talking to the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) just last night. He said that a number of local authorities have put in tenders for road works and that they have been awarded contracts. He does not feel that I have anything to worry about in this connection.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, the work provided by road construction, particularly in country areas, is often the only thing which keeps some townships alive, not to mention the families that are affected. In an otherwise excellent road-funding program this is what I find rather difficult to accept. I would like to take this opportunity to commend the Minister for his obvious concern for the problems associated with our road systems and for his intiative in coming to grips with those problems. Roads are the arteries of our community. Let us keep these arteries healthy and their lifeblood flowing. Once again I commend the Government on this excellent scheme to improve Australian roads as an Australian bicentennial year project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Australia we have enormous problems with road construction and road maintenance. Given the physical size of our nation and the decentralised nature of our population it is little wonder that we have these problems. Some States, of course, have greater difficulties than others. We have had speakers this afternoon from Western Australia and from South Australia who have outlined the problems in their States. Queensland, the State that I represent and the state that the previous speaker, Senator Bjelke- Petersen, represents, has a large area and is extremely decentralised. Our difficulties are immense. Some roads which should be regarded as major highways are nothing short of a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not make those comments lightly, nor do I make them with any political bias. The Minister in charge of main roads in Queensland, the Honourable Russ Hinze, would readily agree with my comment about some of Queensland's roads. He would probably use the opportunity while agreeing to say that the cause of Queensland's road problems lies at the feet of the Commonwealth Government. Whilst the fault is not necessarily all that of the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth does have a significant role to play, if not in actual road building and maintenance, then at least in road funding in Australia. There is no reason why the Commonwealth should not play a role in road funding. If for no other reason than it has a responsibility for the nation's security-there are, of course, other reasons-then it should ensure that there is an effective road network throughout the Commonwealth.

It is nothing new for a national government to have a role to play in the construction of roads. During the time of the Roman Empire, for example, constant care and an enormous amount of effort were applied to construction and maintenance of roads. Whilst the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1982 which is under discussion allows for funds to be made for urban arterial roads, this would not have occurred in the Roman administration. Owners of buildings in Rome were responsible for the maintenence of roads which ran past their properties. This obligation was policed by a group of aediles- probably what we would call public works supervisors. In some respects, our urban dwellers find that not much has changed. When they purchase a building block on a new estate the cost for associated road construction is included in the price. The comparison with ancient road building practices probably does not end there, even though there are marked contrasts in the actual methods of construction. In rural areas the Romans recruited local labour and also employed soldiers on road building and the repair of existing roads. We do not, except in special circumstances, ask the Army to assist in road construction and maintenance. Our leaders however, still follow an ancient practice. Even though labourers and soldiers shouldered the arduous task of building roads, the Roman Emperors took all the credit. The result is that there are still many inscriptions in existence today extrolling the achievements of various Emperors. Similarly our highways are littered with signs which proudly advertise the source of funding for road construction projects. I doubt that these signs will have similar durability to the incriptions of the Roman era.

It is notable that the Bill being debated by the Senate actually specifies the erection of signs and the nature of those signs on bicentennial road construction projects as a condition to the granting of funds to the states, I doubt that this provision is included to give the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) some form of immortality. I suspect it is designed to guard against misrepresentation by State authorities and I envisage that it will be a provision that will be useful in Queensland when the Australian Labor Party wins the next Federal Election. I shall illustrate what I mean. Not far from where I live in Brisbane some roadwork is being carried out by a contractor to the Queensland Main Roads Department. Part of the project requires the construction of a bridge. The Queensland Government has erected a sign which reads as follows:
A Queensland Grant ProjectMain Roads Department
Western Arterial
Fig Tree Pocket Road InterchangeBridge
Construction Authority: Main Roads Department
Construction Cost: $1,150,000
Construction: Thiess Constructions P/L

What the sign does not reveal is that the Commonwealth this financial year will provide $51,397,000 to the Queensland Government for the construction of arterial roads. Whilst it is impossible to say with absolute certainty that the funds for this particular bridge are being paid out of this $51m, I strongly suspect that they are. Yet no mention of this is being made on the State Government's sign.

It is difficult to argue that the Commonwealth Government should not be making a major assault on the substandard roads all too prevalent in Australia. Indeed, it is a simple matter to argue that this assault should have begun many years ago. In some respects it can be convincingly argued that road users should pay for road construction and maintenance, but that type of argument is far too simplistic. Even before the imposts of the August Budget were introduced Australian motorists were paying substantial taxes to State and Federal governments. State governments charge a wide variety of fees, many of which have risen considerably this year. Probably the most significant State government motor vehicle charge is registration-a charge that is borne by many people throughout the community. But after motorists have struggled with that charge of registration they are faced with taxes on the fuel that they use.

In 1980-81 the crude oil levy and excise on petroleum products yielded $3,940m to the Federal Government. In 1981-82 this increased to $4,070m and the estimate for this financial year is $4,500m. Over this three-year period about $12,500m was received by the Federal Government from the oil levy and excise on petroleum products. How much of this has come back to the motorist by way of road funding? Over the three-year period I have just mentioned about 15 per cent came back- that is, $1,978m. I would not argue that all fuel taxes and levies should be applied in the transport area but I would argue that a return of 15 per cent is far too low. Surely additional taxes to finance the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program are not necessary. But there will be increased taxes. Before the Budget, 5.155c per litre excise was levied on petroleum products and on road diesel fuel. To allow the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program to proceed this excise was raised by 1c per litre to 6.155c. I am just getting to the very interesting part of my speech. Rather than go on, I will pause at this stage to allow other business to be dealt with.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Amendment Bill 1981, which was introduced into this chamber by Senator Haines, was referred by the chamber to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. On 19 May and 16 September of this year, on my motion, at the agreed request of the Committee of which I am chairman, the Senate resolved that the date for the presentation of the Committee's report be extended. It was necessary for the Committee to seek these extensions of time because submissions requested from a number of interested groups had not been received. In fact, the Committee is disappointed that the Housing Industry Association of Australia has still not forwarded a submission on the Bill, having been invited to make its submission on 17 February of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee received submissions from the Treasury, a number of interested banking organisations, the Association of Permanent Building Societies and the Australian Consumers Association. The opinion expressed in the submissions received was that the terms of the Bill had two basic flaws. The first was that the Bill, if enacted, could only control those interest rates charged by banks subject to the terms of the Banking Act 1959. The second was that the mechanism for control of interest rates on first home loans proposed by the Bill was inflexible and time-consuming and would have the probable effect of reducing funds available to the banks from depositors and, as a result, reduce funds available for home loans. The Committee has drawn attention to the effect of the operative parts of the Bill and the likely economic effects of its introduction. It has also noted the Government's housing policies introduced since the Bill was brought into the chamber. These policies were introduced in March and August of this year and were designed to assist first home buyers.

I wish to make it clear that the Committee had discussions with Senator Haines and was attracted to the aims of the legislation but it did not receive evidence which would enable it to report in any other way than it has reported. In summary, the Committee is attracted to the aims of the Bill and recognises the severe economic effect that rising interest rates have on people who are paying off their first home. However, the Committee believes that the Bill would not achieve those aims and should not be proceeded with for the reasons which are outlined in detail in its report, and it so recommends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want at this stage to make only a few comments on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Banking Amendment Bill 1981. I have not had the opportunity since the report was presented earlier today to study it in any depth, largely because of other business that I had to attend to in the chamber. Suffice it to say at this stage that I am not particularly surprised at the final recommendation of the Committee, notwithstanding the fact that it did mention, as Senator Peter Rae noted, that it was attracted to the aims of the Bill and that it recognises that rising interest rates have had a severe economic effect on people who are either paying off a loan or are seeking a loan to finance a first home. The question which was raised at the end of that comment was whether the Bill in effect provided acceptable or better machinery to control interest rates than the existing system. It argued that it did not. I would say, however, in defence of the legislation that surely just about any system would be able to provide better machinery to control interest rates than the existing system.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not suprise me that Government members, whether they are members of the Committee or not, would be opposed to this legislation. The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) made the Government position very clear when she spoke on the Bill. After all, it does fly in the face of the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and is quite against the principle of deregulation. It is deliberately intended to fly in the face of those two things, since we felt that an area as crucial as housing finance and the major factor which impinges on it-that is, interest rates-were something which required benevolent interference on the part of the Government.

I am more surprised and somewhat disappointed at the apparent acquiescence of the Opposition in this rebuff to the legislation since it stemmed initially from a public meeting that I attended in Adelaide at which I put this suggestion and had it heartily and publicly endorsed by the now Deputy Leader of the Labor Government in South Australia. Indeed, it was also endorsed at that meeting by the representative from the South Australian Consumers Association, apparently in contradiction to comments made by the Australian Consumers Association, which felt that the legislation would affect only part of the financial community in Australia. Indeed, this criticism was raised by the Committee itself on pages 8 and 9 of its report, and by a number of comments in submissions that I have had the opportunity to look at. In chapter 3, paragraph 4, of the report the Committee states:
Evidence from the submissions received indicates that the effect on banks as lenders and borrowers could be marked.

It makes the point, which I think from memory I made during the second reading stage of the Bill, that the Banking Act 1959 regulates only those banks listed in the Act and its controls do not extend to State savings banks, finance companies, building societies and other non-banking financial intermediaries; in other words, that the legislation, if effected, would affect only part of the financial sector and hence the provisons of the Bill would not apply to more than 50 per cent of existing housing finance. Even leaving aside the fact that this is so, I would have thought that something which affected 50 per cent of existing housing finance was something to be approved of in the present financial conditions. Nevertheless the comment is, at least in part, irrelevant since it is easily remedied. If those sections of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 which have yet to be proclaimed were in fact proclaimed, this would then give the Commonwealth Government jurisdiction not only over the banks, with the exception of the State banks, but also over building societies and a variety of other financial organisations involved in lending money for purchase of homes.

I do not, either, have a great deal of sympathy for the banks' arguments that they will have their operations severely curtailed and that they will have curtailed also the flexibility and ability to fund their lending operations. It is a faily well-known fact that the banks are amongst the few businesses in this country which have had massive rises in profits over the last few years-I believe in excess of 30 per cent last year-so that for them to be crying poor at the moment is nothing more than a display of crocodile tears.

It is in marked contrast to the genuine crying poor which exists among people who would like to borrow money or who have already borrowed money and who are finding grave difficulty in meeting their mortgage repayments in view of the continued increase in interest rates.

The intention of my Banking Amendment Bill was, as the Committee so correctly pointed out at the beginning of its report, to assist primarily those on lower incomes, although it would have had some effect on those on middle incomes. I was aware that it was breaking new ground in that it gave Parliament rather than the Reserve Bank of Australia the right to alter interest rates or to approve increases in interest rates. I was aware also of a number of other effects that the Committee has pointed out. However, I do not want to spend any longer discussing this since I have not had an opportunity to look in great detail at the comments made by those organisations which responded to the Committee's repeated calls, as I understand it, for submissions on this legislation.

Leaving aside the fact that there may be a number of groups in this community as I understand there are a number of honourable senators in this chamber who believe that I have absolutely unmitigated effrontery to even have considered putting forward this legislation, I would have thought that there would be enough interest in its intentions, if not its ultimate effect, for more groups to submit their comments to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —We took it seriously.

—Indeed, the Committee did. I am not passing any comment on the Committee in any way at all or casting any aspersions on it. The meeting at which I appeared before the Committee indicated to me completely that the Committee was taking the legislation extremely seriously, spending a great deal of time on it, and going to a great deal of trouble to get submissions. I, like it, am disappointed that a number of organisations which it approached either did not put forward a submission, as is the case with the Housing Industry Association, or were rather late in submitting as was the case with the Australian Consumers Association. I have no wish to cast any criticisms at all on the Committee except to say that I am, of course, disappointed with its recommendations. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I mentioned that the 203rd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, a progress report on medical fraud and overservicing, reached people in high places. The existence of fraud and overservicing by some doctors has been known since at least the first involvement of the Commonwealth in medical benefits in the 1950s. Computerised statistics were first collected in 1975. These led to a growing awareness of the size of the problem. The Committee has considered in detail the role and performance of the Department of Health and the adequacy of the Department's briefing of successive Ministers for Health. The report cannot cover all of the Committee's findings because the inquiries are still proceeding . The progress report, however, does emphasise a lack of performance on behalf of the Department of Health. In the progress report the Committee suggests extensive improvements in the present procedures. We believe the great flood of responses and information to the Committee reflects a widespread public concern. This publicity has helped the Committee to get a more accurate perspective of the whole problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The hearings have produced more than 4,000 pages of transcript so far. Even estimating the size of the problem proved to be difficult because of a lack of information and because of the Health Department's low level of activity in so many areas. The Australian Federal Police and the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office appeared to give, at times, low priority to some of the problems in this health area.

The Department of Health estimates the level of fraud and overservicing by doctors to be at least $100m per annum. That is just under 10 per cent of the medical benefit expenditure. The Australian Medical Association accepts the figure of $100m. The figure does appear to be, on the face of it, somewhat conservative. Despite the size of the figure, very few doctors have been convicted. In fact, only 39 doctors out of about 17,000 who are in full time private practice were penalised for fraud in almost seven years. Only 12 were penalised for overservicing in the same period. These figures are an incredibly dramatic demonstration of the present shortfall in the investigative processes at a number of levels in a number of departments. In fact, one major problem is that no one body has complete authority. In fact, there is too much buck-passing and there are too many delays. Therefore it is very easy for those involved to pass on the blame or to leave the problem for another day.

Those involved include the Department of Health, the Australian Federal Police, the Deputy Crown Solicitor, State health authorities and the courts. But of all those the Department of Health must shoulder most of the responsibility. In fact , we have yet to take further evidence from most of the bodies mentioned. We believe that the Department of Health bears a great responsibility. In fact, at times its excuses were fairly flimsy. The Department of Health had a responsibility for overall implementation of health policy. It should have been well informed especially as the Director-General was also Chairman of the Health Insurance Commission from mid-1976 to November 1978.

The failings of the Department were numerous and will be outlined in detail in the report. I will mention just a few: The Department failed to monitor the activities or to give sufficient direction and guidelines to State officers; it lacked guidelines regarding fraud; investigators lacked training; the Department gave low priority for investigations which meant low funding and low staffing. These restrictions severely limited the success of the fraud and overservicing detection service. Long delays occurred between the different responsible bodies and there were unacceptable court delays. The Committee admits that defining ' overservicing' is a difficult problem. On the other hand, 'fraud' was quite easy to define. Overservicing involves certain value judgments and analyses of typical patterns. Not all doctors are deemed average as problems in the differences in the age of patients, location and specialisations all created problems in determining the extent of overservicing. But it is not an insurmountable problem. It is possible, with careful thought, to devise checks and more adequate programs as the Public Accounts Committee has been doing.

We admit that in some cases some doctors have proved their intelligence, their inventiveness and their ingenuity; some proved very devious. I cannot resist sharing a few of the anecdotes, apart from those concerning the usual, unsophisticated fraud such as claiming fees for social visits, lengthening the time of visits, and splitting operations and tests into multiple claims, for example, chest x-rays and x-rays of several different parts of the body. One or two of the memorable cases come to mind. A doctor doubled his fee by charging for 114 grafts when performing 57 hair transplants on the dubious grounds that the grafts were taken from one place on the body and replaced elsewhere. A doctor gave all members of his son's football team a medical checkup before they played and so received payment for 15 consultations for a number of games. A doctor paid a pensioner $20 to have his lawns cut and then asked the pensioner to sign an assignment form to enable him to receive a $22 consultation fee which was more than sufficient profit for pay also for the petrol to run the mower.

Some of the many ways which in which the Public Accounts Committee recommends improvements include the integration of procedures. If the investigative section of the Department of Health and the Australian Federal Police worked as one, there would be a better performance. New roles must be created and additional resources provided. For example, we believe that a medical investigator should be appointed to investigate patterns of excessive services and to allow the tracing of overservicing. Because of past situations and the lack of action by the Department of Health, special short term remedies are now needed as a catch up. For example, we recommend that a special national task force be established to investigate the backlog. There is a need for a check on management processes and for streamlining to ensure that lines of responsibility are clarified much more clearly. I think there is a responsibility to make doctors' accounts more comprehensible so that lay people can understand and check them. There may be a case for accounts to be signed in a doctor's presence after a service has been provided. Medical benefits tribunals should be set up and severe penalties for offending doctors are recommended. The progress report contains much more detailed ways in which abuse can be reduced. In some ways medifraud is perhaps the best known variety of white collar crime. Perhaps we have been working on prototype procedures.

In conclusion, I wish to point out that the Committee will refer to other matters. As I have said, this is only a progress report. Other areas for investigation include patent fraud, fraud associated with hospitals, overservicing associated with the pescription of pharmaceuticals, fraud and overservicing associated with pathology-there is a great need for investigation in this area-unnecessary surgery, possible strengthening of legislation with respect to medical fraud-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief in my remarks. As a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I would like to point out to the honourable senators that this is an interim report which touches only the surface of the problem. The Committee dealt with 5,000 pages of submissions and evidence. We found that there is an incredible difference of opinion about what is overservicing and what is fraud. In some instances it is quite easy to say what is fraud. However, it is difficult to determine what is overservicing. The submissions and evidence given to the Committee show that it is impossible to say whether a doctor is guilty of overservicing. This is a grey area. I believe that the Committee has to give close attention to defining what is overservicing . We have to be able to determine whether overservicing has taken place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee came across a problem concerning new doctors. We were told that the 1,700 new doctors admitted each year in Australia are not told during their studies about the legal problems of overservicing and fraud or anything about ethics. One of the recommendations of the Committee is that medical schools and colleges should include in the last year of a course the subject of ethics and the problems associated with possible overservicing. It is a fact that counsellors are not able to contact all new graduates and as a result an increasing number of young doctors have no idea what overservicing is. Therefore , I feel it is absolutely necessary for universities and colleges to ensure that new graduates know exactly the pitfalls before they enter a medical practice.

I would also point out that the Department of Health estimates show that approximately 2,000 doctors are overservicing or commit fraud. I admit that 2, 000 seems quite a lot. However, there are 17,000 general practitioners practising in Australia and on that basis 2,000 represents merely 11 per cent. I do not intend to cover up for or try to shield doctors who commit fraud. However , I would like to point out that the number of cases of fraud which has been detected and punished is very small. Therefore, it would be absolutely improper for anyone to consider that all doctors are cheats. This is not the fact. As in any profession, there are people who are not ethical in the way in which they practice. Therefore, I feel that honourable senators should study the interim report. They should take the report as such-it is an interim report which has touched only the surface. The Public Accounts Committee has made recommendations to the Government on how to deal with and improve the detection of fraud. I intend to say only these few words because I feel it is important that the public and honourable senators realise the value of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Pesticides and the Health of Vietnam Veterans

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Senator Jessop:
The Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a minute or two of the Senate's time to speak to the report on pesticides and the health of Vietnam veterans. I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and Environment that prepared the report. I think this was one of the most difficult reports to compile of any report compiled by a Senate Committee. I have nothing but praise for the Committee members who served with me, for the Committee advisers, for the secretarial staff and particularly for the witnesses, some of whom gave evidence on more than one occasion. The Committee considered a mountain of evidence. There are very genuine difficulties collecting and in interpreting the evidence that was presented to us, as illustrated by the paper presented this afternoon in the other place by the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) which referred to a whole new swag of records that have turned up in the Australian War Museum. The Committee will look at them as an extra task. However, nothing in the Minister's statement this afternoon conflicts with any of the recommendations in the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the difficulties of interpretation, the collection of data was extraordinarily difficult in our effort to find out actually what happened. The second part of the inquiry, which dealt with medical effects, involved a most complex subject. We are not dealing here with an acute condition such as toxicity, in which there is a direct cause and effect relationship, but rather with a delayed or chronic medical condition. We are not looking for a specific pathology. We must look at the whole range of human biological and neurological response. Again, the time relationship, as between cause and effect, is variable . Presumably, it could vary from soldier to soldier or from serviceman to serviceman in an unpredictable way. As I have said, we did not know the initial dose rates and there is no way now, many years after the event, that that can be established.

An aspect that does create a problem was that the chemicals used in Vietnam were and are also used in Australia, in agricultural applications in particular. We have the problem of isolating any war-related cause for a present health condition from any background or environmental exposure that may well have occurred when the soldier was a youth.

All of these things are very hard to quantify. This is of course an epidemiological study and such studies are a science in themselves. Epidemiology has developed considerably over the last 30 or 40 years. One is usually looking not for a dramatic cause and effect relationship but rather for low grade effects which produce results over large populations and over a lengthy period. But it is a science and I regret that the public at large does not understand the degree of sophistication involved in epidemiological studies.

One of the other problems with which we had to cope in preparing the report was the negative philosophy adopted by some. Many people have very genuine concerns. I do not set them aside lightly or irresponsibly, but one of the attitudes of mind with which we had to cope was the attitude: 'You cannot prove that such and such was safe, therefore it must be unsafe'. It is very hard to cope with such a point of view. The chemicals with which we are dealing here, agent orange a mixture of 2, 4, 5-T and 2, 4-D-have been used in Australia for almost 40 years. In some agricultural applications very high dose or application rates have been used. Given the nature of the farming community which uses them, they have been used frequently in less than ideal conditions and certainly not in accordance with directions or with more than minimal safety precautions. In addition to use by farming communities they may be used as was DDT, in urban areas, in backyards , on lawns and so on.

I return to the question of the difficulty of making a large-scale epidemiological study and the ignorance of the community at large, which does not appreciate the complexity of running such a study and relating cause and effect. Unless one is involved in the health professions one does not realise the number of people who become sick at any one time. The other thing that one does not realise is that with any pathological condition-a good example is provided by leukemia-one has clustering. One may find three of four people in a particular street who develop monocytic leukemia or something of the sort at the same time. Then everyone races round and says that it is an infectious condition , but if one looks at it over a 10 or 15 year span, and over a large population of several hundred thousand, one realises that some degree of clustering occurs frequently as a natural aberration.

I have every sympathy for Vietnam veterans when they talk about the rates of carcinoma or suicide amongst their friends. However, that must be measured against the statistical averages for the community. Most of the veterans are now in the 30-39 year age group and, as the report states, of 100,000 males in that group 41 will die of malignant disease and 44 will commit suicide. Certainly, no evidence was advanced to the Committee that the incidence of either malignancies or suicides were higher in Vietnam veterans than in the community at large.

The most worrying aspect with which we had to deal was that of birth defects. The Committee comes out quite strongly with the opinion that in this direction there is nothing to fear. Birth defects are an enormously emotional subject. They affect all of us as males and affect every female. It really is a frightening subject, but there is no possible way of showing that exposure to herbicides could have affected the incidence of birth defects in Vietnam veterans. That is explained quite clearly in the report and I will not take the time of the Senate to repeat it. Basically it is because the defects would have had to come throught the male line and the time delay is of such length that, from a biological point of view, such a result would not have been possible.

The worry about birth defects leads us to what is probably the most important concern that we have about the veterans. I refer to their morbidity, to the way in which they worry about conditions which might or might not be related to their war service. All of us have an enormous sympathy for those who served because to them such worries are very real. The community, through the Parliament and the repatriation service, should do everything that it can to assuage those worries.

The report offers at page 14 a list of recommendations, basically on the need for the constant surveillance of the veterans, on the need for immediate care where required and, specifically, in relation to possible delayed neurological damage and matters of that nature. The Committee requested the Government to respond by the end of March 1983, and I am sure that it will take up that request because, in dealing with this problem, speed is of the essence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Committee that was involved in this very difficult, lengthy and quite complex investigation, I wish in a few words to put my point of view and that of the Australian Democrats. We see the report very much as an interim report which expects a great deal from the Government over the next few months. Having heard the evidence submitted over a period it seems to me that the greatest inadequacy of all, in what I believe is the undoubted cause of the Vietnam veterans is a lack of information. Time and again we found that when expert witnesses came before us, especially from the medical research field, one set would say one thing and another would say almost the opposite. When we pressed the matter we found that, often as not, the differences were attributed to a lack of information, a lack of research and a lack of statistics and figures in that particular area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for that reason that I feel, as I am sure the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment did unanimously, that there is good reason to lay on the Government at this stage an obligation, in a rather unusual way, to produce within a period of three months some of this further information that will help unravel this very tangled and difficult story concerning the question of morbidity, the causes of disease among Vietnam veterans, the question of mortality and causes thereof, an accurate comparison between birth abnormalities among veterans' children and those of the community at large. These very important aspects have yet to be established and I believe that in the cause of the Vietnam veterans, in the cause of common justice and in the cause of veterans' peace of mind they must be established permanently and finally. Until they are and the real truth behind the matter is revealed and action taken along the lines suggested by the facts, the matter will never be laid at rest. It will continue to be one which concerns and worries the conscience of Australian people almost universally, and certainly my own.

There is a need, then, for more information. Perhaps we will need to take another look at the total effect of the veritable cocktail of poisonous chemicals to which these young people in Vietnam were exposed. One of the most interesting things about the inquiry was that it ranged away from the original look at agent orange, a plant destroying material, to pesticides and insecticides. Evidence was given that regularly soldiers in the Nui Dat camp in Vietnam, wearing nothing more than a pair of shorts in that hot climate, were exposed to the direct blast of a chemical fogging machine as often as once a week. That blast would contain a cocktail of such delectable items as dieldrin, lindane, malathion, chlordane and a number of other dangerous substances. I cannot believe that those men were not affected one way or another by that. The real problem now is to determine the extent to which they were affected and in what ways they were affected, and to try to take some course of action based on that.

Whatever the feelings of people and the apparent sense of urgency to have another inquiry held, I feel strongly that another inquiry should not be held right now. If a royal commission were held now it would tend to come up with the same results as our Committee has done, for sheer want of information. When further information is available there may well prove to be good reason for a further inquiry based on that information. That is quite likely. I spoke to a meeting of 200 Vietnam veterans at Randwick in Sydney last Sunday. They are still unhappy. They feel that the Committee's report is a whitewash. I might say that many of them had not read it thoroughly and some of the points I was able to put to them corrected some of their views. I hope they justify the point of view I am putting now. However, I make it quite clear, as a member of the Committee, that it should be understood that this is an interim report. The very important obligation of getting something done quickly and finding out about these things has been laid on the Government. I shall be looking for a response in March. If it does not come up, or if it is unsatisfactory, I will be among the first to support the Vietnam veterans' call for a further inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take only a minute of the Senate's time in relation to the report of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. I was not on the Committee but I read the report with great interest. It seems to me that in terms of evidence to be obtained the report does take us a fair way down the track. The report shows that the Committee members spent an enormous amount of time sifting the evidence and attempting to come to some reasonable conclusions from the evidence presented to them. Again the Senate committee system has been shown to be a very useful device in furthering the cause of providing information to Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: That said, I am unhappy with a number of the conclusions. I believe that, for example, the conclusion that it is unlikely that the majority of Australian troops were directly exposed to herbicides does not seem to be a reasonable conclusion given the evidence contained in the Hansard record and in the report itself. I believe that a conclusion which said simply that the Committee could not determine the degree of soldiers' direct exposure may have been a more correct conclusion to draw from the public evidence available. However, the point that Senator Mason just made is important. It is certainly one that most people who have been involved with this matter are also concerned about. The recommendation in the Committee's report that more detailed evidence is required in the areas delineated by the Committee as needing immediate investigation, with an endeavour to come forward with the types of statistics that obviously are necessary, ought to be taken up and pursued vigorously. Once one has read the report one is struck, as Senator Mason has already said, by the enormity of what we do not know about this matter. That, in a sense, is also an extremely useful result of this Committee's report. Having reviewed all that it was able to find out, it could point time and again to loopholes in our understanding of this extremely important area.

I believe that in that sense the Committee's report ought to be applauded by Vietnam veterans as being a further step in taking their cause down the road to ultimate solution. Of course it is not a solution for the difficulties that veterans and their families have but the community itself should accept that they and their families have suffered grievously in the service of their country and that the country has an abiding obligation to support them in the difficulties that they have had since returning from Vietnam. Once again I commend the Committee's report. Although I cannot say that I agree with everything in the report, it does make an extremely useful contribution to the debate and to our understanding of this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Northern Territory) (4.16)-The report of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment is a most important one on a subject in which I have taken a lot of interest over the years. I do not intend to pursue the matter at this stage but I believe it should stay on the Notice Paper and so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
