DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON SOUTH WEST TASMANIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Archer:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -When the debate on this matter was interrupted I had just been granted permission to table a chart which proved that at the moment Tasmania has the cheapest power in Australia. I go on to the cost of the power schemes. The Select Committee on South West Tasmania has suggested that there be a three-year moratorium before we start building the dam . The dam will take 10 years to build and by the year 1990 the estimates of the Tasmanian Government for the cost of the project are certainly different from those put forward in the Committee's report. It has been indicated that the cost of the dam, in 1982 prices, will be $453m. There have been various quotations, all without foundation. That is the correct figure in 1982 prices. In the past, Tasmania has built and paid for much larger schemes so the great fear about what it will cost the community and how long Tasmanians will be paying off this dam must be seen in its true perspective. We must also take into account that almost the total amount spent on building the dam will stay in Tasmania. That includes the amount spent on labour and construction materials. It will stay in Tasmania and will create additional employment in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: The quotations as to costs by various groups vary considerably. The Committee decided that it could not come to an accurate assessment of the various alternative energy sources. Some academics with conservation persuasions say that the Hydro-Electric Commission costings were not accurate. However, every assessment made by independent professional consulting engineers confirmed the general correctness of the HEC's costings. Perhaps I may list those, because they have been done time and again: Sir Alexander Gibbs and Partners, in association with Merz and McClelland, a report dated September 1979; Cameron, Preece International, consulting engineers, a report dated March 1982; the Ziedler Committee of Inquiry into Electricity Generating and the Sharing of Power Resources in South-east Australia, report, 1981. The McLachlan Group report on Supply to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania also reported in 1982 that its estimate for the year 2000 was well within the HEC's estimates. So we have no disagreement in this area. I am sure that Senator Coates would agree that that is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the other way around.
—Well, it was the year 2000, was it not, that it came within the HEC's estimate?
—The HEC estimate came within the consultants' estimate.

—It seems to me that that is splitting hairs. The Committee paid particular attention to Dr Kellow's work. There was quite a degree of investigation into his work. But the Committee did not mention that Dr Kellow had omitted the cost of 33 million tonnes of coal, quite a considerable omission , from his costings on the thermal program. I should like to ask anyone following me in this debate why that question was not asked, and why 33 million tonnes of coal were not costed. Surely that is a considerable cost. Dr Kellow happened to omit that vital statistic. There were quite a number of other areas in which Dr Kellow was wrong, but I shall not go into them now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee also said that no new industries had contracted for power in the last 20 years. I am surprised that the Tasmanians put that forward, because I am sure that Tasmanian members would know that at least 10 new industries have been established in Tasmania since 1962, and these new industries have contracted demands amounting to 80 megawatts. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a schedule of the names of those industries.
Leave granted.
