TALK.START.PARA: —That is not where the industrial load is.

—It is said that that is not the major industrial load. That figure for bulk sales to contract industrial customers in the HEC's annual review is equal to the major industrial load. That is what the Committee consultant seems to have said. In fact, it excludes industrial load from Tioxide , Renison, Tasmanian Pulp and Forest Holdings Ltd, in addition to the transmission losses, so perhaps that will answer that point.
—On a point of order, Mr President. Will Senator Walters be speaking for a further 10 minutes because she is in continuation from last week, or-
—No, Senator, I have noticed that the time has just expired. Your time has expired, Senator Walters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the importance of the work of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania was that it did not approach the matter from the usual tack of assessing the importance of the national heritage and then looking at what effect the proposed Gordon-below-Franklin dam would have in relation to that heritage but, rather, that it looked at the importance of the dam and the hydro project on the Gordon from the point of view of its impact upon economy of Tasmania. We did that by looking at the existing supply system, the anticipated demand to the year 2000, and then looking at the economic viability of alternatives to meet any shortfall. In looking at the existing system, we found it to be almost entirely hydro based. Historically, it appears to have served Tasmania well. But the scene is changing. One sizable hydro scheme remains-either the integrated or separate development of the Gordon , Franklin and King region. After that, only a limited number of small options exist. Even the Hydro Electric Commission, in the longer term, accepts that it will have to look to alternative sources of power.

SPEECH.PARA: This seems to be often forgotten. We are looking at the last of the major hydro schemes. Whether Tasmania likes it or not, in the long term it will have to move to some other form of power production. In looking at future demand, the Committee accepted the advice of its consultants. The key to the advice which was received was flexibility. But there is considerable uncertainty as to the future requirements of power, and the system must be sufficiently flexible to meet the highest demand whilst at the same time recognising that under utilisation of a highly capital-intensive scheme is economically undesirable. Someone must pay that cost.

The demand band settled upon is wide, and the further ahead it projects, the wider it becomes. But a most important point is that it would be very difficult to argue that it is restrictive of future industrial development. It is a forecast that takes account of the most optimistic but yet realistic level of industrial growth. In comparing that forecast with the current supply, taking into account completion of the Pieman scheme, it was obvious from the point of view of power availability that there is no need to commence a major option for at least the next three years. The major options are the Franklin-Gordon-King hydro interconnection with Victoria, or a coal-fired thermal plant. But furthermore, it is economically unsound to do so if one accepts that the demand projections call for flexibility.

However to be within the highest and most optimistic projection of the demand band, it would be prudent to commence the development of small schemes, small hydros in non-contentious areas-the HEC has already done considerable work on this option-or small wood-powered thermal plants. Delay in commmencing a major option would allow a more detailed evaluation of the two non-hydro options- interconnection, and coal-powered thermal. The importance of this is the advice of our consultants that on economic grounds alone-I stress that it is on economic grounds alone-at least interconnection may be competitive with the Gordon-below-Franklin hydro-scheme. It depends on the methodology used for economic comparison-anticipated utilisation, the cost of Victorian power, and so on.

We would not promote our consultants' view as being beyond dispute. Rather, it is a view of independent experts. But I believe that it changes the whole parameters of the debate. In certain demand scenarious, hydro may not be cheaper . Therefore, there are good economic reasons to delay construction of the dam irrespective of the environmental debate. The Tasmanian Government is clearly determined to move Tasmania back into an industrial growth pattern. For that it is to be commended. The unemployment position, though largely inherited, is intolerable. But unfortunately the dam is being promoted as the answer to Tasmania's economic woes, and that simply is not so. Very rarely are there simple answers to complicated problems.

The days of hydro industrialisation are past. No longer will new industries be established utilising ore from as far away as the Northern Territory and Queensland simply because of the availability of cheap power. They have been overtaken by the relativities of transport and other costs. The emphasis for the future must be in the development of resources indigenous to Tasmania but with further downstream and value-added processing, expansion of the tertiary sector, and so on.That is not just my opinion; it is the view of the Department of Industrial Development in Tasmania. The demand will be for power at a price competitive with that of the mainland. Certainly that will be available provided Tasmania moves to an averaging system of pricing. It will be available from either interconnection or from coal-fired power stations. In mentioning the latter, I must say that there is potential for a new industry. Knowledge of Tasmanian coal resources has developed greatly over the past three years. Another three years could indicate whether such an industry could be economically established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.30 p.m., under sessional order, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of general business.

—I inform the Senate that His Excellency the Governor-General, in accordance with a recommendation by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and myself, has today appointed Mr Hillas MacLean to the office of the Parliamentary Librarian. Mr MacLean, who is 53 years of age, joined the Parliamentary Library in 1979. He was appointed Head Librarian in 1980. He commenced acting as Parliamentary Librarian on 9 July 1981, when the former occupant of the office, Mr H. G. Weir, ceased duty.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference to Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs
Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Senator Harradine:
That the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report, and that the Committee particularly report on-
(a) inadequacies and amibiguities identified in the Seventeenth Report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills;
(b) the desirability or otherwise of a limitation being placed on the standing and class of persons who may bring proceedings;
(c) the nature of the offence and likely penalty arising from a breach of the order of the Court; and
(d) whether it would be appropriate for the Commonwealth to invoke the foreign affairs power of section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to legislate in the manner proposed by the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that the Senate is able to identify the subject of the debate this afternoon, let me just refresh the memory of the Senate on the subject, and on what stage the debate has reached. The Bill before the Senate is a private senator's Bill, introduced by Senator Mason, and it is entitled 'An Act to give effect to the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage'. That Bill has had a second reading debate. Prior to that Bill's coming into the Senate chamber the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills examined the Bill and reported-
—Not prior.
—Senator Missen corrects me.
—After it came in.

—I am sorry. Senator Missen corrects me. Of course, the Bill came into the Senate first and was then referred to the Committee. The Committee considered it before the debate commenced and reported to the Senate, in accordance with its principles, before the debate commenced. I should like to read to the Senate from the report of the Committee. The quotes are very short, but I think it is important that they be placed before the Senate so that we know where we stand as we go into debate. First of all, in paragraph 5, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage.

In fact I will divert there for a moment to say that when the Senate last debated this Bill, Senator Chipp did not say that that was not the purpose of the Bill but he made some statement along the lines that everyone knows what the purpose of the Bill is. According to him, the purpose is to stop somebody in Tasmania from doing something which apparently that somebody is currently doing. So in fact Senator Chipp, who is the leader of Senator Mason's party, apparently says that the purpose of the Bill is different from the purpose described in the Bill. It is important to note that. Of course, if Senator Chipp and Senator Mason had wanted to introduce a Bill which prevented somebody in Tasmania from taking a particular action, I see no reason why they could not have introduced a Bill which was specifically directed to that purpose. Then not only would we have all been clear but also the rights of other people-small people in Tasmania -might not have been overriden by this general shotgun Bill which endeavours very roughly and rudely to prevent all action being taken in this area of Tasmania. The report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills further states:

Clause 6-Protection of Properties This clause makes it unlawful for a person to ''do any act or take any action that is likely adversely to affect'' the general conservation of a property listed or nominated for listing, under Article 11 of the World Heritage Convention. The clause provides very little indentification of the scope of unlawful actions with which the Bill would deal.
That seems to me to be a very serious criticism of the Bill by the Committee. The report of the Committee further states:

The Committee is concerned that in the absence of any list of specific offences , persons may not be able to arrange with any certainty those of their affairs that relate to the use of nominated or listed properties.

The report is very brief in that last sentence but very significant in pointing out the imposition that this Bill places on the people of Tasmania-not just on the one body to which apparently Senator Mason and Senator Chipp wished to direct their attention, but generally on persons being unable to arrange with any certainty their affairs in relation to the use of nominated or listed properties. The report further states:

Clause 7 provides that any person may seek a court declaration that a certain action is in breach of the Act and a court may order to remedy or restrain the breach. Court action might be taken against a person who had no intention of damaging a property, whose actions however might be regarded as likely adversely to affect the protection, conservation, presentation or rehabilitation of a property.

How significant is that criticism by the Committee. Of course, people going into this area, moving on to these properties, may very well take actions. In fact the mere walking across properties clearly damages the environment of the property and some person may inadvertently stand on some area which is significant and do damage to it. Some person may accidentally light a fire in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chip fires.

—Senator Martyr is very keen on talking about chip fires. I can assure Senator Martyr that I have not seen a chip fire heater anyway in 30 years and I do not see one in this chamber, that is for sure. But it is clearly one of the unfortunate consequences of our Australian bush that people light fires, perhaps deliberately, but then accidentally allow them to get out of control. Frequently, the result of that is very serious damage to the environment. It is one of the problems that our nation and our environment have to put up with no matter what governments endeavour to do. The report further states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the doing of an act can include the failure to do an act, the declining by an owner to take, for example, steps to preserve or restore a property, area or building may fall within the prescribed conduct.

It is clear that there the Committee is reporting on the significance of some owner failing to do something as a result of which the area falls into the problems created by this Bill. Then the owner might find himself unfortunately at risk. The report concludes:

In the absence of any clear guidelines in the Bill as to the precise scope of the prscribed actions referred to in clause 6, the Committee draws this clause to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that it might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties.

It is interesting that it is very much the people in this place who always claim that they stand for civil liberties, who want to stand up and be heard when the matter of civil liberties is being raised, who are supporting this measure and who are totally ignoring the report of the Committee that this clause might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties. They want to ride roughshod across the rights and liberties of the people of Tasmania; they want to ride roughshod across the constitutional responsibilities of the Government of Tasmania; they want to have their will and they will leave no stone unturned until such time as they have had their will. Indeed, that is the very reason I am on my feet today. As I mentioned in an earlier debate today; I am on my feet because when this matter was last before the Senate these so- called protectors of civil rights and liberties were in fact shouting down a fellow senator, Senator Walters, because she was putting a view to the Senate which was different from theirs. They were howling her down and using every device within the Standing Orders to prevent her being heard on the subject. That is what attracted me to this debate and that is the reason I am on my feet today. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills having brought this matter to the attention of the Senate and after the second reading debate on the Bill, it was up to the independent senator for Tasmania, Senator Harradine, to bring this matter properly before the Senate by a motion which he put, and which I will now read so that the debate is understandable by all those who are endeavouring to follow what is happening here today. The motion put by Senator Harradine is:
Pursuant to Standing Order 196A I move:
That the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report . . .

I interpolate at this stage to say that Senator Missen is the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and when this matter was put before the Senate he protested that he had not been consulted about that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all, that is right.

—He confirms it again today. He said: 'Not at all, that is right'. I remind Senator Missen of what happened when a question in relation to East Timor was pushed on to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-
—It was well notified beforehand.

—As Senator Missen said, that Committee was well notified. It certainly was. It was so well notified that it considered the matter and decided that it did not want to take the reference. It reported back to the Senate that it did not want to take the reference because it had other matters which it considered to be more important that it wished to deal with. What happened, but that this Senate, having considered the report, then ignored it and thrust it upon that Senate Standing Committee-
—Which it is entitled to do.

—Which, as Senator Missen said, it is entitled to do; so Senator Missen would have to agree-I might say he was one of the proponents of that move -that if his Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has this matter referred to it by the Senate, that would be a valid exercise of the Senate's duties and in accordance with what Senator Missen has previously done and supported in relation to another matter-
—Indeed; no question.
—He says: 'Indeed'. So I presume I have won that debate with him. Senator Harradine's motion then went on to state that the Committee should particularly be required to report on:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) inadequacies and ambiguities identified in the Seventeenth Report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills;
I think I have covered that adequately so that people know what we are talking about. It continues:
(2) the desirability or otherwise of a limitation being placed on the standing and class of persons who may bring proceedings;
That is a matter which Senator Harradine drew to the attention of the Senate when the debate was taking place as being a matter of grave concern. He continued:
(3) the nature of the offence and likely penalty arising from a breach of the order of the Court; and
(4) whether it would be appropriate for the Commonwealth to invoke the foreign affairs power of section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to legislate in the manner proposed by the Bill.

It is that last matter to which I wish to direct the attention of the Senate because I believe that the most significant matter raised by this whole debate and the bringing into the Senate of this Bill is this section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution and the decision in the so-called Koowarta case. That decision raises matters that the Senate should apply its mind to in great detail. I propose to spend some considerable time looking at that matter. That so-called Koowarta case in fact is the case of Koowarta v. Bjelke-Petersen and others and the State of Queensland v. the Commonwealth of Australia. It is reported at page 625, Volume 56, 1982 Australian Law Journal. To summarise the case, it was about the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and its validity, and as to that particular aspect of it I do not think I need to say any more. The particularity of the case was not necessarily relevant but the constitutional aspects of it are of grave importance to the Senate. I will read firstly from the headnote which people would know is a summary of the actual decision but is not in the words of the judges and therefore is not binding as such. It is purely and simply a summary for people to read quickly although, of course, frequently such summaries run to many pages. It was a majority decision held by Mr Justices Stephen, Mason, Murphy and Brennan with the Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs and Mr Justices Aickin and Wilson dissenting that sections 9 and 12 of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 were laws with respect to external affairs within the meaning of section 51 (xxix) of the Commonwealth Constitution and they were accordingly intra vires and valid. There was a demurrer in the case and they held that the demurrer by the defendants in this action should be overruled and the action of the State of Queensland dismissed. The headnote endeavours to give a very brief summary of the reasons and it states:

Per Stephen J.-''External affairs'' in s. 51 (xxix) refers to such of the public business of the national government as relates to other nations or other things or circumstances outside Australia. A subject-matter of international concern necessarily possesses the capacity to affect a country's relation with other nations. It is not enough that a challenged law gives effect to treaty obligations, and it is not necessarily excluded from international affairs because it is not the subject of a treaty to which Australia is a party.
The next paragraph contains the summary of the reasons of Mr Justice Mason and Mr Justice Brennan. It states:

A treaty is an external affair or a matter of external affairs, subject only to its not having been entered into solely for the purpose of attracting Commonwealth legislative power. But a treaty is not an essential prerequisite. Thus a matter of external concern to Australia having become a topic of international debate and negotiation, or a subject which affects or is likely to affect Australia's relations with other international persons constitutes an external affair.

The next summary is that of His Honour Mr Justice Murphy. Notwithstanding that he was once the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the Senate, I am prepared to read into the Hansard his apparent reasons. The summary states:

There is an external affair wherever Australia is involved with any entity, circumstance or event outside Australia (whether or not this involves any affair in Australia). Any purported treaty or agreement between an Australian State and a foreign country is a nullity.

Those were the reasons given by the four judges of the High Court who upheld the Commonwealth power in this matter. Honourable senators will see from those summaries, and certainly from a reading of their judgments, that it is clear that their desire is to expand the powers of the Commonwealth whenever that possibility arises. They talk about the Commonwealth Constitution having to be read broadly. It would seem to me from their judgments that they would read into the Commonwealth Constitution an ability to exercise the power whenever they possibly could, unless for some reason or other they saw it to be specifically excluded. In many ways, especially with regard to what Mr Justice Murphy said, it seems to me that the Commonwealth could enter into any sort of external agreement and then exercise its powers and pass legislation, no matter how restrictive, on a State of Australia. I turn to what is, to my mind, the most significant judgment; that is, the minority report; the judgment of the dissenting judges, of which there were three. What they had to say is summarised clearly in just a few lines. The Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, Mr Justice Aickin and Mr Justice Wilson, in their dissenting judgments, stated:

A law which gives effect within Australia to an international agreement will only be valid under s. 51 (xxix) if it is with respect to a matter which itself can be described as an external affair. Any subject may constitute an external affair if the manner in which it is treated in some way involves a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia.

I put to the Senate that that is a very generous interpretation of section 51 ( xxix) which any Commonwealth government would be able to implement but, at the same time, it is fair and reasonable for the State governments in this nation. The judgment of the Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs states:

What however remains unclear is the extent to which the federal nature of the Constitution requires that limits be imposed upon the broad power to implement international obligations seemingly conferred by par. (29), thus ensuring that exercise of that power will not destory the federal character of the polity.

Suggestions that there are some such limits to the power recur in the cases, although their precise nature is not very clearly defined. In Burgess Starke J. suggests at p. 658 that the external affair may have to be ''of sufficient international significance to make it a legitimate subject for international co- operation and agreement'', citing United States writings for that proposition. Dixon J.,-
The famous Mr Justice Dixon, later Chief Justice Dixon-
at p. 669, would apparently confine the power to the implementing of treaties which relate to ''some matter indisputably international in character''.

Who in this chamber could disagree with those words in relation to the powers of the Commonwealth Constitution given to this Commonwealth Government by our founding fathers? Who could disagree with that sort of interpretation in relation to those powers as they should exist, not only for the remainder of this century but also into the next century? They are certainly broad enough for any Commonwealth government to exercise those powers which it might properly exercise. At the same time, we do not have a unitary system of government; we have a federation. A federation involves the recognition of the validity of the existence of State governments and their rights to operate in their own sphere without interference from the Federal government. I see that my time has just about expired. I want to discuss a number of other things in the Senate in relation to this legal matter. I believe I will have an opportunity later during the Committee stage of this Bill. I will then resume at the point at which I now finish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Harradine's motion to refer the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs because it seems to me the only way we can get out of the mess that we are in with this totally inadequately drafted Bill. Furthermore, it accords with the practice of the Australian Democrats. I nearly said the policies of the Democrats, but it occurred to me instantly that the Democrats never have any policies; so I use the word ' practice' for what they intend to do.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill contains so many inadequacies that the longer we look at it and the longer it is debated the more that surfaces. It is just falling to bits before our eyes. If Senator Mason feels that something can be salvaged from it, I invite him to withdraw the Bill and redraft it. If he does so, I am sure I could prevail upon Senator Harradine to withdraw his motion to refer it to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. If it were referred to that Committee at least we could obtain a balanced view on the most important issue, which regrettably Senator Lewis, in an excellent speech, did not have time to touch upon-that is, the matter of States' rights and the fact that we are a federation of Australian States.

I am not prepared to accept the proposition that is put to us that the States have no rights, that they are an anachronism, and the other statements that have been flying around this chamber in relation to this Bill. They are the views of people who come from Victoria and New South Wales. We can expect that sort of big brother view from them. They think that everything turns in the great conurbations of Sydney and Melbourne. But I have news for them. Australia is different from that. It is growing and the formerly great areas of Sydney in New South Wales and Melbourne in Victoria are not the places where Australia's history will be written during the coming decades. In particular, now that we have Labor governments-socialist governments-in both New South Wales and Victoria, we will see Brisbane develop as the financial capital of Australia to exploit the great resources, both human and physical, in Queensland. If Australia is to benefit from what Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania have to offer, we cannot be tied with practical examples of this centralist, socialist dogma that is being canvassed in the form of this Bill. Those States in Australia do have rights. I believe that their rights are severely abridged and trampled on by this legislation. I welcome the opportunity to refer it to the Committee to look at this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -No one who has arisen in this place-very few honourable senators have-to oppose the reference of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has addressed himself to the issues that were raised by me and by other speakers in support of that reference.
—A plain filibuster, that is what this is.

—Senator Missen says that it was a plain filibuster. That is the sort of invective that I have had to suffer in the Senate in the last week or two because I had the temerity to suggest that this Bill which, according to Senator Missen's own Committee, has ambiguities in it should be referred to a standing committee of this Senate. I have had my right as an honourable senator in this place to refer a piece of legislation to the Committee described as a diabolical contrivance.
—True.

—Senator Mason says that is true. So he is in accord with his leader, Senator Chipp, in that regard. The comments of his leader were published in the Press but certainly the arguments which were advanced in support of the proposition were not published. Senator Chipp said:

SPEECH.PARA: This move by Senator Harradine is an extraordinarily clever but diabolical device to delay the passage of this Bill.

Were I thin-skinned I would have taken a point of order at that stage and asked Senator Chipp to withdraw that allegation which has characteristics bordering, to use his words, on the obscene. We heard Senator Missen's comment and I am suprised that it came from him. We heard the other barrel that he fired over the chamber in opposition to the shots that I fired in support of my proposition. His two barrels were that it was a filibuster and that he, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, had not been consulted. What nonsense that is. On the morning of the day when I introduced the motion in the Senate I spoke to you and raised with you the issue of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask you to address your remarks to the Chair.

—I raised with Senator Missen the worries I had about this Bill. I was concerned that the Bill was defective, as described by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and that it placed emphasis on the external affairs powers. I discussed that with Senator Missen.
—And you never told me what you were going to do.

—No. I did not tell Senator Missen what I would do because Senator Missen's response to me in regard to my raising courteously with him that matter was unintelligible mumbling which left me under no uncertain impression that Senator Missen would not have a bar of it. So I did not proceed with asking him, as Chairman of the Committee, whether it ought to be referred to him. Mr Acting Deputy President, in your address you indicated quite validly that there is no responsibility on a member of this chamber to ask the chairman of a Senate committee whether he can move in this chamber for a Bill or some other matter to be referred to a Senate Standing committee. The rights of individual senators in this chamber are being undermined as it is, and too much, I believe, by the committee system. Now we have the impertinence of a Senate standing committee chairman suggesting that a senator has a responsibility to discuss with him the reference to a committee.
—To his committee.
—To his committee.
—That is just courtesy.
—I ask Senator Tate how long he has been in the chamber.
—I was listening intently.
—I do not know whether he heard that I had discussions with Senator Missen that morning and his response--
—Not about this.

—About this Bill, Senator, and about the issues involved. Senator Missen left me under the clear impression-there was not the shadow of doubt about it-that he would not have a bar of any discussion on this issue. Neither Senator Missen nor any of the other senators have addressed themselves to the issues that I raised in the debate. Senator Missen himself said that the Bill is defective. On page 3107 of Hansard Senator Missen said:

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that some objection has been raised to the Bill. Some matters raised by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) have some merit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you identify a piece of perfect legislation? I would love to see it.
—Even Senator Mason is now admitting that this legislation is not perfect. That is why I want to see it referred to the Committee. Senator Missen went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I think the major defects have been covered by the Australian Labor Party in its amendments.

So at least he admits that there are major defects in the legislation as it stands, but he thinks the major defects have been covered by the Australian Labor Party in its amendments. He knows it is defective. He continues:
I see some defect in that if a State has a plan of management for parks and so forth there is no way at the moment that that could be protected from action.
He then goes on with, I presume, other matters and makes the point:
It is a relatively minor point; it could easily be picked up in the House of Representatives if it is thought desirable and if the Commonwealth decides that this is the course of action to take.

So we have an admission by Senator Missen. Incidentally, Senator Button also admitted that there are faults in the Bill but that they could be fixed up in the House of Representatives. So what do we have? We have a general recognition all round that the Bill is defective but that-according to those who oppose my reference-it can be fixed up in the House of Representatives. What are we? According to the opponents of this reference we are not a States House and now, according to the opponents of this reference, we are not a House of review. I thought that the two major purposes of this House were to act a States House and as a House of review. I do not know why the people who have advanced these specious reasons against the reference of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill to a Committee take their money home. They ought to pack up, go home and save the taxpayers a lot of money.

I now turn to the issues which were not met by any of the opponents of this reference. Senator Lewis, in his very perceptive address to the Senate this afternoon, detailed again the Koowarta decision and its effects. He pointed to the fact that the Koowarta decision indicated, inter alia, that certain actions can be taken by the Commonwealth pursuant to its external affairs powers under section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution, notwithstanding that the legislation concerned may impinge otherwise upon the constitutional powers of the States.

Senator Mason, in his second reading speech, which incidentally was almost identical in parts to evidence given by a witness from the Australian Conservation Foundation to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, said that the Koowarta decision applies equally to this Bill. On 25 November 1982, as recorded at page 2862 of Hansard, Senator Tate said:
. . . the possibility of this legislation-
He was referring to the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill-
being based on the external affairs is based on a very biased reading of the Koowarta decision.

Why did any honourable senator who opposed this reference-for example, Senator Chipp or Senator Mason-not address himself to that question, which after all is fundamental to the Bill? Here we have a fundamental difference of opinion as to the applicability of the external affairs powers in respect of this legislation. Why did they not address themselves to that clear difference of opinion?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is you and Senator Tate, on the one side and everybody else on the other, is it not?

—Senator Mason will have an opportunity at the Committee stage of the Bill to answer a lot of questions which might otherwise have been discussed by the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Frankly , I am going to ask him questions time and again and time again until I get some answers.
—Another filibuster.
—Senator Grimes says: 'Another filibuster'. I am not prepared- -
—Start asking sensible questions.

—These questions have been asked by Senator Tate and others. Senator Tate raised the question of the external affairs power. He raised another important question to which no person who has opposed the reference of this Bill to a committee has applied their minds. The question raised by Senator Tate was whether the mechanism is set off at the time of listing-the word used in the Bill is 'submission'- or whether the trigger is acceptance of the nomination by the World Heritage Committee. Again, it is fundamental to the Bill to know that.
—Is it not for the High Court to decide?

—It is important to resolve, if at all possible, the problems surrounding legislation before it is passed by the Parliament. Otherwise we are doing two things: First we are not acting properly and directly to achieve an objective which we have set out to achieve. Secondly, we are overburdening the High Court of Australia with useless and costly litigation. A reference to a committee might have ironed out some of these problems. Senator Evans had a different point of view from Senator Tate in respect of the trigger. It was Senator Evans's view that the mere nomination would trigger the provisions of the Bill.
—We have heard all this before, of course.
—Yes. We have heard all this before and I am repeating it because neither Senator Missen nor anybody else who has opposed the reference to a committee has addressed his mind to these issues.
—You will go the whole half hour, I suppose.
—Just to filibuster, I suppose.

—I am disgusted at this sort of nonsense. I challenge any honourable senator, any member of the Press or any member of the public to read the Hansard record of this debate and to see which argument prevails and which of the issues have not been addressed by those honourable senators who have opposed blindly this reference to a committee.

SPEECH.PARA: All they want to do is to use this Senate to steamroll the Bill through for their own political purposes.

There are a large number of other matters to which those who have opposed the motion have not addressed themselves. It is not my purpose to go through all of those matters. I recommend to members of the Press and the public that they examine the Hansard record of these proceedings to see who is trying to steamroll the Bill through, who is trying to muzzle debate and who is trying to deny not only the basic rights of individuals but also the rights of honourable senators. They will also see who is trying to undermine the role of this Senate as a States' House and a proper House of review. Let us not hear anything further on that subject from Senator Missen.

A number of other people have preferred using invective to addressing themselves to this particular reference. Indeed, it occurred last night when Senator Grimes used a smear tactic which was found to be totally baseless and false. Many things have been said by the opponents of this measure that have been inaccurate and indeed downright false. I referred to one of those inaccuracies last night. It is not my intention to do so today. Let me refer in particular to the questions of the reference. We are seeking to have this Bill referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and have that Committee report on the inadequacies and ambiguities identified in the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. We seek to have the Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs raise the desirability or otherwise of a limitation being placed on the standing and class of persons who may bring proceedings. In the debate, Senator Missen said: 'Oh, that is no problem. You are worried about eskimos. There is no problem about that'. Will then Senator Missen or anybody else move an amendment in the Committee stage which limits the locus standi to those who are normally resident in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can move it yourself if you want to.

—But will Senator Mason support it? This matter has been agreed to by Senator Missen. It will be interesting to see whether he will move an amendment accordingly. The nature of the offence and the likely penalty arising from a breach of the order of the court is a very serious matter. Let us see who is likely to be affected by the provisions of this Bill. The workers in the Hydro-Electric Commission are likely to be affected by this Bill because they, under this Bill, will have to bear the brunt of this Bill that is moved by the Australia Democrats and which is now supported by the Australian Labor Party . Let us have a look at the provisions relating to who is responsible.
—Don't shout. Keep your voice down. I am sitting directly in front of you. It is disgraceful enough without your shouting.
—Order! Senator Chipp. Senator Harradine has the floor.
—I have some rights, too. I do not want him shouting in my ear.
—Order! Senator Harradine has the floor.

—I am concerned about the civil rights of persons who may be under instructions from an authority which is acting pursuant to what is, in its mind, its lawful obligation under a State Act of Parliament. Under this Bill, the workers can be lumbered. An order can be made against them and they can be held in contempt of court. Is that what honourable senators want? There is deadly silence. Of course that is not what they want, but that is what they will get because that is what is in the Bill.
—What about all the other courts?

—Senator Mason refers to other courts. He is presumably referring to the contempt powers. The general penalty for contempt is imprisonment. It is not a fine, it is imprisonment. What happened recently to that member of the Press in South Australia? He was imprisoned, and that is what it is proposed to do here. That is why I am suggesting that the nature of the offence and the likely penalty arising from a breach of an order of the court ought to be the subject matter of further consideration and that ought to take place in the Standing Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of whether it would be appropriate for the Commonwealth to invoke the external affairs power in section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to legislate in the manner proposed by the Bill. That is fundamental. Again I refer to what Senator Tate said. He indicated that the provisions of this Bill and the possibility of this legislation being based on the external affairs power is based on a very biased reading of the Koowarta decision. Surely those are weighty matters for a Senate committee to consider. I ask all honourable senators in this place to give full regard to what they are doing about this matter, to recognise that the issues that have been raised have not been met in any shape or form by any of the speakers against the proposition that I moved last week and that is before us today.
Finally, I say this: The Bill was predicated upon a belief that the Federal Government may use it as a way of intervening in South West Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still stands.

—That is right. That is what Senator Missen advanced and he says that it still stands. That is precisely the point. It is a political weapon being used against decisions that have been taken democratically. I do not object to that. What I do object to is if the people who are advancing this proposition then go and support the blockading of work which is being undertaken by workers pursuant to the legitimate authority of an Act of the State Parliament of Tasmania. I therefore challenge Senator Mason and Senator Chipp to stand up in this place and condemn the unlawful activity that will take place in Tasmania, to condemn the confrontation that is involved in the blockade against workers trying to do the work that they are lawfully required to do and want to do. I ask them to stand up in this place today and condemn that confrontation and urge that that blockade not proceed next Tuesday.
—They are those trained protestors. Did you hear that this morning ?

—To answer that interjection I refer to a telex that all honourable senators received today from the Wilderness Society, New South Wales Branch, which said, in effect, that the Tasmanian Wilderness Society can also be ruthless. What is being suggested by Dr Brown is this, that no member of the Federal Government will be able to point a finger at those who break the new trespass law when they have broken international law. What a statement to make. The Australian Democrats cannot have it both ways. Let them, if they will, use this as a political tool within the democratic process, but let them stand up today and ask that the blockade be called off next Tuesday.

—I wish to make a statement. I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Harradine frequently makes statements which one could reply to. I normally do not reply but on this occasion I will. He accused me of indulging in slandering and slurring and not speaking the truth in a speech I made last night. The point I made last night was that Senator Harradine went on at considerable length and with great piety, I think were the words that I used, about the blockade which was to be conducted on the south-west coast of Tasmania . I compared this with the fact that he had not protested in this place at any time about a similar blockade-
—That is not what you said.

—Senator Harradine should read the Hansard. Senator Harradine has never protested in this place about that sort of blockade. That was the point I was making. I was pleased when he got up at a later hour and, for the first time ever, said he was opposed to blockades of the type against Dr Wainer or anyone else. That was the point I was making. That is why I have made this statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented. I have yesterday's Hansard. On page 3258 of yesterday's Hansard Senator Grimes said:

SPEECH.PARA: His complaint is very selective. His arguments about blockades are very selective.
I interjected:
That is not so.
Senator Grimes said:
Senator Harradine will support the blockades which suit his arguments-

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, come on! Read the whole thing. Go back a paragraph.
—Mr Deputy President, if you want me to read the whole material I will, but Senator Grimes specifically said 'support'. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine will support the blockades which suit his arguments-
After having said that I supported what I had not supported, Senator Martyr said:
So do you.
Senator Grimes said:
And he will oppose blockades that do not do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President-
—It's a bit hot in the kitchen, hey.

—No, not at all. I seek leave to make a further statement as I claim to have been misrepresented again. I realise this is getting tedious and this is why I normally do not protest about this sort of thing.
—You started it.
—I started it?
—Order, Senator Grimes! You are making a personal explanation.
—Who spoke first this afternoon? Not me.
—Order! Senator Grimes, you will address the Chair and make your personal explanation.
—On page 3258 of yesterday's Hansard, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I would prefer that we had a protest there that was not of the blockade type and did not involve breaking the law. But it makes me laugh to hear Senator Harradine and, for that matter, Senator Martyr get in here and talk about democratic rights and the breaking of democracy by people who do that. Has Senator Harradine ever got up here and complained about people who blockade clinics in Victoria-
No, of course he did not. I continued:
Did Senator Harradine complain when a group of ladies-I agreed with their right to do so-blockaded the offices in Hobart of a member of this Parliament?
No. It was only in answer to Senator Harradine's interjection and not as a direct consequence of those statements that I said:
Senator Harradine will support the blockades which suit his arguments-
Senator Harradine misquoted me last night and he selectively quoted me this afternoon. We could go on with this all day and all night. But I think he should read the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented because Senator Grimes is not addressing himself to the facts. I certainly did not know of any blockade at that particular time, but certainly-
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Does Senator Harradine not have to obtain leave? I certainly will not give leave.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Standing Order No. 410 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator who has spoken to a Question may again be heard, to explain himself in regard to some material part of his speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood-
Under that Standing Order, Senator Harradine does not need leave. I call Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes started all this last night. I make it perfectly clear to honourable senators that in what Senator Grimes said today in respect of his selective quote of the transcript he omitted the word 'support'. The point that was made by me last night was clear, that in the circles of pro- life I have always opposed the physical violence involved in blockades of that sort. That is far more important than standing up here-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Harradine is not allowed to debate the personal explanation.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resoloved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 1 (Short title).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the clause be postponed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'd be one of the most contemptible people in this place.
—You are as good there as you are in the chair.
—Order! Senator Lewis has the call.

—Mr Chairman, clearly you did not hear what was said, but I did. I was insulted firstly by Senator Chipp and secondly by Senator Grimes. I take strong exception to it. I have been insulted all day by Senator Chipp over a matter which occurred last night. I am not going to put up with it for much longer.
—Order! Senator Lewis, frankly, I did not hear the remarks.
—It was clear to me, Mr Chairman, that you did not hear the remarks made by Senator Chipp and Senator Grimes.
—If the cap fits.
—Order! Senator Lewis has the call and I ask honourable senators to respect his right to address the Chair.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I have moved that the clause be postponed . This is a formal motion. I quote from page 318 of Odgers's Australian Senate Practice, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A common practice is to move that clause 1 (normally the short title)-
In this case it is the short title of the Bill-
be postponed-as an instruction to the Government to do certain things relevant to the Bill. A debate then proceeds on the subject-matter of the proposed instruction5. . . .

I am having distributed in the chamber at the moment the proposed instruction, which is to Senator Mason and not to the Government, of course, because this is Senator Mason's Bill. For the purpose of the record the instruction is:
(a) To take advice on the validity and Constitutional propriety of this legislation; and
(b) to re-draft the Bill so that it:
(1) no longer contains the inadequacies and ambiguities identified in the seventeenth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills;
(2) places suitable limitations on the standing and class of persons who may bring proceedings;
(3) identifies the nature of the offence and likely maximum penalty arising from a breach of the order of the Court; and
(4) after re-drafting, represents a balanced and complete document suitable to pass through the Parliament,

The situation that I was trying to explain to the Senate when my time to speak ran out during an earlier debate relates in particular to instruction (a). I say seriously to Senator Mason that we have a federation. It is time that the Senate realised that a federation means that the States have rights, duties and obligations. It is not the right of this Commonwealth Parliament to ride rough- shod over those rights and duties. This is an attempt to do so. It may very well be that in due course--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise to order. I refer to page 318 of Odgers's Australian Senate Practice, which states;

INTERJECT.PARA: The Chairman quoted Standing Order 202, which states that 'no new clause or amendment shall be at any time proposed which is substantially the same as one already negatived by the Committee. . .'

My point of order is that the amendment proposed by Senator Lewis is substantially, though not formally, the same as the one moved by Senator Harradine. Its intent is the same as the intent of the one moved by Senator Harradine. The sub-sections of the amendment and its thrust are very much the same as that moved by Senator Harradine. According to that Standing Order, I ask that you rule this amendment out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, this is a motion to postpone a clause; it is not an amendment. I remind Senator Bolkus that this is the first motion that has been moved in the Committee stage of this Bill. There is, therefore, no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. What I was trying to do was to draw the attenton of Senator Mason, the Australian Democrats and those who support this legislation to the problems of a federation. We have in a federation a fabric which must be retained. We cannot ride rough-shod over the rights of the Commonwealth Government or the State governments. There must be some give and take. I draw the attention of the Committee to the report of the Koowata case and the statement in the head note of the dissenting opinion of Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs and Justices Aickin and Wilson that:

SPEECH.PARA: A law which gives effect within Australia to an international agreement will only be valid under s. 51 (xxix)-
Of the Constitution-
if it is with respect to a matter which itself can be described as an external affair.

I stress the words: 'if it is with respect to a matter which can only be described as an external affair'. I suggest to the Committee that where we have a federation and this sort of delicate fabric of give and take between the States, among the States and between the States and the Commonwealth it is necessary for the Commonwealth to tread very carefully in the exercise of its powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a minority.

—Yes, it was a minority view, but one of these days it may become a majority view. In any event, it has not necessarily always been the situation that minority views are not always correct. There is a particular minority view in this Senate which is far more correct than the majority view of a particular committee back in 1975 and this view is held on both sides. What I am trying to say to those honourable senators who wish to apply their minds instead of their mouths to this subject is that when we are endeavouring to get a balance in a federation, when we do not want to destroy what has been achieved in 82 years, we must look to exercising our powers properly. I put it to the Committee that this description of how those powers should be exercised is valid and proper. The best way to go about exercising our external affairs powers is to make sure that the subject matter can be described as an external affair. In no way can the subject matter of this Bill be described as an external affair.

SPEECH.PARA: Other constitutional difficulties have been raised by Senator Evans, Senator Tate and Senator Harradine. These major difficulties relate to the treaty arrangements and whether the treaty powers can be used at this stage when, in fact, only a submission to the World Heritage Council has been made. I do not want to go into those matters at great length. They have been spoken of before and are recorded in Hansard for the benefit of honourable senators who wish to apply their minds to the matter. It may very well be that in due course Senator Evans will explain them to us again, but I am not raising those particular aspects. I am talking about the general concept of the Commonwealth of Australia exercising its external affairs powers. The Bill in no way relates to any matter which can be described as an external affair. Clearly, what it relates to is an internal affair, specifically one concerning a part of a State of the Commonwealth. On 2 December, Senator Chipp, as reported at page 3129 of Hansard, said:
The . . . Bill . . . is designed for one purpose; that is, to stop the vandalism that is taking place in one of the most beautiful places of the world.

Therefore, it has nothing to do with any external affair or matter. Under the description given by Senator Chipp, the claim is made that vandalism is taking place in the State of Tasmania and the Bill is designed to stop that vandalism. How can that be said to be in any way an exercise of the external affairs power of the Commonwealth? I hear not a dissenting voice.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are plenty of dissenting voices; it is kids stuff.
—Order! The honourable senator is addressing the Chair.
—It is clear that at this stage the deficiencies are even greater because the matter has not yet been considered by the World Heritage Council. What is involved is only a submission to that Council.
—You are a demonstrated vandal, Senator Lewis.
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw the remark.

—For the sake of those who keep making spiteful and vicious remarks, let me make clear my position in relation to dams in Tasmania. I am totally opposed to the construction of this dam. I have indicated that view to Government Ministers. I have taken that viewpoint repeatedly whenever I have had an opportunity to do so in my party room. But I am also desperately concerned about the rights of States. I am not necessarily saying that the exercise of States' rights is always correct, but there are various matters that one must look at carefully if one is to exercise one's judgment in this chamber. It is not just a question of whether a dam is to be built in Tasmania. That is not the only question raised here. Involved is the question of the use of the external affairs power of the Commonwealth, the question whether it can validly be used to impose something upon a State in order to change what has been decided by its Government.
—So you oppose the Racial Discrimination Act, do you? That is based on the external affairs power. You are not fair dinkum.
—Really the honourable senator is not even bright as a lawyer, is he?
—Answer the question, you oaf.
—Who is an oaf? You are the oaf, an academic oaf.
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw it.
—I will withdraw mine too.
—I ask all honourable senators to respect the right of Senator Lewis to address the Chair.
—Let me quote again the judgment of the High Court on the enforcement of treaties by Oliver, as reported at page 644 of ALJR of 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: A constitution would cease to be federal if the central government, without consultation with the states, could enter into any treaty and by so doing increase the legislative powers of the central government at the expense of state legislatures. If the treaty power can cut across all reserved powers and interdict the powers of the member states, then there are no real powers reserved to the internal sovereignties.

That, of course, is the fundamental principle involved in what is being proposed in the Bill. Senator Evans, who claims to be a constitutional lawyer, ought to have some knowledge about these things. Instead of making personal attacks on me and my ability as a lawyer, he ought to be applying his mind to matters which are of concern to us here. Are we to destory the federation? Are we to exercise these powers, or say: 'We may have this power but this is not the sort of use that we ought to make of it'. I have put to honourable senators that, according to the dissenting judgment, the proper use of the power is with respect to a matter which itself can be described as an external affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis, as did Senator Harradine, has quite properly drawn attention once again to the basic inadequacies of Senator Mason's Bill. Senator Lewis has offered Senator Mason a perfectly logical and proper way out of his difficulty. I cannot understand why Senator Mason does not accept his magnanimous gesture. It would give Senator Mason a way out of all his problems with this dreadful Bill. Senator Lewis has properly outlined the basic reason this Bill will not be able to function. I repeat, it is quite incredible that such a Bill should be presented to the Senate. It is quite incredible that the Opposition, containing, as it does, a number of lawyers, some perhaps of doubtful quality but others probably of some quality, does not seem able to help Senator Mason with his Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Its deficiencies are obviously directly attributable to the over-enthusiasm of such people as Dr Moseley, the Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, who ought to stick to conservation and stay out of the area of the law. His over-enthusiasm is obviously sustained on government handouts. We feed the conservationists and they seek to destroy us. Why Senator Mason listens to such people instead of going to the lawyers and fixing up his Bill so that it might be acceptable to this chamber, I do not know. Instead, Senator Mason goes beyond the law and asks these enthusiastic conservationists for advice. Yesterday I called them greenies, and that is what I think they are. They ought to stick to their flora and fauna and leave the law to the lawyers and to honourable senators who know a little about it.

I support Senator Lewis's instruction to Senator Mason. He has given perfectly logical reasons why the honourable senator, if he had sense, should withdraw the Bill and redraft it after proper advice. If he then brought it back and it was suitable, we might even, on this side of the House, be enthusiastic about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to paragraph (a), concerning constitutional propriety, which seems to me to be the threshold point of the proposal put before us by Senator Lewis. We do have a federation, one that is becoming more and more fragile, one that more and more seems to be deteriorating and collapsing as a result of the purposeful endeavours of some people. We have to make up our minds on whether we want it to work or to fail, whether we want in Canberra a centralised system and the total abolition of the States. If that is the case perhaps we should say so. If it is we will find that slowly but surely this great country of ours will tear itself apart. I believe we have to continue to recognise that there should be checks and balances as was intended in the first place by the founding fathers. If this power, this insidious proposal were put to the people in a referendum, even with the support of the Government and the Opposition, it would be ignominiously defeated. I have no doubt about that and I am sure the Opposition knows the same thing. I am sure that the great majority of people do not want further powers vested in the hands of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is a sensible one. In regard to constitutional propriety, there have been endeavours and moves-reasonable, altruistic and with good purpose-to review the Constitution from time to time. Senator Evans has been one of those who has led the push towards reform, at least as he sees it. On each of those occasions he, like everybody else who has participated, has recognised that if there is not goodwill or co-operation from the States then endeavours to amend the Constitution in any way and find a more suitable framework are bound to fail . If it is the view of some in the Senate that the States should be completely abolished, they ought to say so. It seems to me that they have a convenient excuse for the time being but the moment the States take a contrary view on something then they say the States ought to be overruled completely. That seems to be the second best thing to abolishing them. Senator Lewis has put before us an ideal, practical and sensible proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would appear that I have still not succeeded in persuading the Senate to adopt my point of view so I am bound to go on.
—You have persuaded me.
—Is the honourable senator indicating that he will support the motion.
—Order! Senator Lewis will address the Chair.
—I thought for a moment that Senator Button would join us in supporting this proposal. In that event I would not have bothered to go any further.
—Are you still filibustering?
—No, I am not endeavouring to filibuster. I am endeavouring to persuade honourable senators and I hope that they will listen to what I have to say. Again in the Koowarta case, Mr Justice Wilson-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 421, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The President or the Chairman of Committees may call the attention of the Senate or the Committee, as the case may be, to continued irrelevance or tedious repetition, and may direct a Senator to discontinue his speech.
Mr Chairman, I request that you direct Senator Lewis to discontinue his speech on the ground of tedious repetition. I further remind you and Senator Lewis that the Standing Order goes on:
Provided that such Senator shall have the right to require that the Question whether he be further heard be put, and thereupon such Question shall be put without Debate.

I urge you in the exercise of your chairmanship responsibilities to direct Senator Lewis to desist, and if Senator Lewis feels aggrieved and offended by that he may test the matter by requesting the Committee to vote upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am aware, that Standing Order has never been exercised by a Chairman of Committees. There is no point of order.

—Senator Missen has mentioned to me his concern about the reputation of the Senate. I am certainly concerned with the reputation of the Senate and I am concerned with the reputation of the Commonwealth of Australia. I am concerned with this Federation which has been in existence for 82 years and which has served us well. I am not repeating myself because I now turn to the judgment of His Honour Mr Justice Wilson in the Koowarta case, on pages 658, 659 and 660 of the report to which I referred earlier.
—Can't you tell the difference between a majority and a minority judgment?

—Senator Evans, who was an academic lawyer, keeps asking whether I can tell the difference between a minority judgment and a majority judgment. Senator Evans ought to know that ever since common law commenced, lawyers have been arguing their cases on the basis of dissenting or minority judgments, and frequently those minority or dissenting judgments have subsequently been accepted and previous decisions overruled. For Senator Evans to be saying that I ought not to be quoting from this judgment because Mr Justice Wilson was in the minority shows what absolute ignorance of the law this so-called academic lawyer has.
—Order! Senator Lewis, I ask you to come back to your motion.

—It would be a pleasure to come back to it. Mr Justice Wilson referred to the only four cases which had been before the High Court in relation to the interpretation of section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution. The Koowarta case was only the fifth case on our history when the High Court was able to give consideration to this provision. The first case was Burgess's case in 1936, which was followed by Sharkey's case in 1949, the Airlines of N.S.W. case in 1965 and finally, in 1975, the case of N.S.W. against the Commonwealth. Having referred to each of those decisions and having gone through them, Mr Justice Wilson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have reviewed these cases in order to show the very limited authority that they provide.
That is very significant. He went on:

In every case, the law in question was one which in the words of Chief Justice Latham in Burgess's case had an external aspect. The operation of the law within Australia was necessarily invested with an international character. Whether it was the extradition of fugitive offenders from abroad, the seizure of the property of enemy aliens, the safety and efficiency of aerial navigation within Australian air space used by foreign aircraft, the vesting of sovereignty in areas beyond Australia or the protection of foreign governments from seditious activity within Australia, the law bore on its face the marks of an external affair.

We should appreciate how significant that is. He went through each one of those cases and in a sentence summarised the nature of the case which came before. See how they are related to an external matter. Compare the seizure of the property of enemy aliens with the interference in Tasmainia in relation to the Tasmanian Government wanting to construct a dam. Compare the use in Australia of air space by foreign aircraft with the interference in Tasmania of the Tasmanian Government's desire to build a dam. Seditious activity within Australia by a foreign government and all of these matters have an external affairs section to them. A part of all of them is related to external affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Racial Discrimination Act, the treatment of Aborigines in Queensland.

—I know that Senator Evans and those of his ilk wish to extend the powers of the Commonwealth of Australia but the people of Australia do not want to extend the powers of the Commonwealth. They have rejected repeatedly any extension of the powers of the Commonwealth Government. They have said that this isolated area, Canberra, ought not to have any more powers. Yet people such as Senator Evans wish continually to impose upon the people of Australia any device that they possibly can to extend those powers. Mr Justice Wilson said:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the external affairs power is sometimes likened to the defence power, there is in my opinion a significant distinction to be drawn. Whereas the needs of defence will vary with the existence and character of hostilities in which Australia may be engaged and consequently the scope of the power will expand or contract accordingly, there is no such ebb and flow in the conduct of Australia' s international relations. There is now no limit to the range of matters which may assume an international character.

When talking about communications and satellites he pointed out that there is now no limit to the range of matters which may assume an international character and this situation is unlikely to change. He said:
These considerations underline the importance of identifying clearly the criteria which will attract to a law of the Parliament the character of a law with respect to external affairs.
So Mr Justice Wilson was pointing out how the external affairs power will continue to grow and that it is most unlikely ever to stop growing. He went on to say:

The broader question then is whether the Parliament is competent, by reason of Section 51 (xxix), to give effect within Australia to every obligation which Australia assumes within the community of nations. In answering that question, it must be borne in mind that a distinction is to be drawn on the one hand between Australia as a fully autonomous sovereign nation within the international community with all the rights and responsibilities that attach to that status, and on the other hand the identity of the Commonwealth as a constituent unit of a federation possessed of the legislative powers conferred upon it by the Constitution.

So Mr Justice Wilson drew clear a distinction between Australia as a sovereign nation exercising its external affairs power in relation to other countries, and Australia as a constituent unit-not as the dominating controlling unit-of a federation possessed of the legislative powers conferred upon it by the Constitution. Mr Justice Wilson then came to this conclusion:

In my opinion, the power in Section 51 (xxix) does not extend to enable the Parliament to implement every obligation which Australia assumes in its international relations. The discrimen to be applied is that which is established by the earlier decisions of this Court.

In other words, what he is saying is that one has to look at the external power in relation to external affairs and whether the manner of the implementation necessarily exhibits an international character-which is a summary of how Mr Justice Wilson put it.

That brings me back to the summary that was so very well put in the headnote and which seems to me to make so much sense-that when we exercise this power as a Commonwealth we ought to recognise that the laws that we implement under this head of power should be laws which give effect within Australia to an international agreement to be valid only if it is with respect to a matter which itself can be described as an external affair. I go on to quote further:
Any subject may constitute an external affair.
It is not a very limiting power. Any subject may constitute an external affair. Surely that is of enormous value to the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. The judgment goes on to say:
Any subject may constitute an external affair if the manner in which it is treated in some way involves a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia.

Of course, that makes good sense. But this Bill in no way relates to those matters. In no way does it relate to or involve a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia. All that the Bill does is to ride roughshod over the State of Tasmania, over the desires of the Government of Tasmania and over the wishes of the people. A recently elected government of Tasmania has made a particular decision on this matter, and this Bill proposes that that should be wiped away. The way in which it is proposed that it be wiped away is by using the external affairs power. That must surely be a nonsense, and in no way could it be said to be a proper exercise of the constitutional powers of this Parliament. That is why I propose that Senator Mason ought to withdraw the Bill, take it away and take advice on its validity-I doubt its validity, anyway-and then he ought to take advice on its constitutional propriety and consider whether it is right and proper, with all the soft fabric of a federation, to destroy that fabric with a Bill such as this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. Am I to understand that Senator Lewis who moved the motion has just closed the debate?
—No. There is no point of order, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that Senator Missen's understanding of the Constitution is a little better than his understanding of the Standing Orders. This is a matter of great importance. After hearing the previous speakers, I am moved to support this proposition. I want to make it perfectly clear that the first time that I saw this proposition was when it was handed to me as it was distributed in the chamber. I had thought that we were going into the Committee of the Whole, and I had distributed among senators some amendments -not that I will necessarily move them, but they are amendments which senators should be able to consider moving themselves if they so desire. However, having heard Senator Lewis, Senator Martyr, and Senator Crichton-Browne, I am convinced that what Senator Lewis has done by proposing this measure is to get Senator Mason off the hook and to preserve the dignity and role of this Senate as a States House, a House of review, and a House which is committed to the protection of personal rights and liberties of individual citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from what Senator Missen said during his speech on the second reading of the Bill, I do not know what advice was obtained by Senator Mason in the preparation of the Bill. Normally, of course, when governments bring measures before this Parliament, we are quite certain that they have received advice. The advice that they may have received may not have been accepted by them, and quite frequently we take issue with the measures. Quite frequently also, as in the industrial legislation package, we in this chamber refer the measure to a Senate select committee. However, that opportunity has now been denied to the Senate by virtue of the vote that has just taken place. So now Senator Lewis provides to Senator Mason an opportunity to advise us as to just what legal advice he has taken on the validity and constitutional propriety of this legislation. If he has done so, let him stand in this chamber and state from whom the advice was received and what it was, and then we will be able to examine for ourselves whether we regard that advice as valid. But there is a deafening silence from Senator Mason on this subject. He is in charge of the Bill. He has chosen to remain silent on the very important constitutional issues that have been raised in the chamber today, last week and, indeed, the week before by Senator Tate and Senator Evans. There is no excuse for this silence. It is a reflection on the chamber. It is a reflection on the intelligence of individual senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only on you. It is just holding you in contempt. Don't you recognise that?
—It is holding me in contempt? If the proposer of the Bill-
—You are not worthy of a reply. That is the message. Any fool could have seen that.
—Senator Chipp, Senator Harradine has the call.

—I cannot see it. I suppose the corollary follows. But if any honourable senator places before the Parliament a Bill and seeks to have the Parliament enact that legislation, it is that honourable senator's responsibility at least to address his mind to the matters that have been raised by other honourable senators. Senator Mason has not done that. But if he wants Senator Lewis's motion not to be supported, let him say from whom he has taken the advice. If he does not want to say that, I do not mind. Senator Missen has suggested that it was the Australian Conservation Foundation President but let him at least table the advice so that we have the information before us. Otherwise, if he has not taken advice let him, as proposed by the motion, take the advice on the validity and constitutional propriety of the legislation. Let him also redraft the Bill in the manner proposed by Senator Lewis. We are talking about this chamber as a responsible chamber, a States House. I point to what was said in Odgers's Australian Senate Practice. He made it perfectly clear in his first chapter that this is a States House. We are talking about fundamental issues of federalism. DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT BILL 1982BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
