Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT BILL 1982
The Bill introduces legislation to give effect to the Government's decisions on supplementary licences which were announced on 11 August 1982.

Honourable Senators will recall that the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1981 provided the legislative framework for the extension of commercial FM broadcasting through the supplementary licence scheme. The present Bill makes a number of significant changes to that scheme and includes provision for supplementary television services.

A constant source of complaint over many years by people in country and regional areas has been the imbalance in broadcasting and television services available in those areas when compared with the five mainland State capital cities. Apart from national services, these people often have access to only one commercial broadcasting service and one commercial television service.

A major difficulty in attempting to redress the balance has been the inability of many of these areas to support fully competitive stations without endangering the viability of existing services. A further consideration has been the need to maintain, as far as practicable, the local flavour and character of country and regional services. The supplementary licence scheme has been developed as a means of resolving these major problems. It also provides a mechanism for the indentification of those areas which are able to sustain additional commercial licences.

The pattern of commercial broadcasting and television services in country and regional areas has essentially remained unaltered since the early 1960s, in the case of television, and even longer, in the case of broadcasting. The supplementary licence scheme heralds a major expansion in those services. It will enable the progressive development of an additional commercial FM service and commercial television service in most country and regional centres thereby offering people in those areas greater program choice. A maximum of 99 commercial FM services and 36 commercial television services could be established uner the supplementary licence scheme.

Careful attention will need to be given to the planning of these new services. The Minister for Communications intends to make a full statement on planning guidelines for the implementation of the supplementary licence scheme as soon as possible after the legislation has been passed by the Parliament. This statement will cover all the practical steps required to implement the scheme and will cover matters relating to the commencement of the scheme, the definition of service areas, the procedures by which applications will be processed and the determination of technical specifications. Consultations will also be held with industry bodies and individual licensees on these matters. The Department of Communications is establishing a special task force to handle the implementation of the scheme and to institute more effective procedures for handling the large number of planning proposals which will result.
Mr President, I would now like to turn to the provisions of the Bill.
The Bill introduces a major innovation in the licensing of broadcasting and television services.

Honourable Senators will be aware that the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 as it stands is a particularly complex Act, due in part to the fact that it provides for the licensing of stations and technical facilities, rather than broadcasting or television services as such. As new types of services have become available, or new uses have been found for existing technology, it has been necessary to accommodate these changes through the creation of new classes of licence with the result that the Act has become exceedingly complex.

Under the system adopted in the Bill, a supplementary licence will authorise the provision of a broadcasting or television service to a specified area. There will no longer be any need for the licensee to apply separately for licences for translator stations to re-transmit the supplementary service. In determining the service area of a supplementary licence, the Minister will endeavour to ensure that, as far as practicable, the supplementary licence will serve the same area as that of the related commercial licence and associated translators.

The Government believes there would be great merit in adopting a service-based approach throughout the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, and it is gratifying that a start is being made with the supplementary licence scheme.
Mr President, I now propose to give a brief outline of the scheme.

The Bill allows the licensee of a commercial AM broadcasting service or a commercial television service to lodge with the Minister an application for a supplementary licence to operate one additional commercial service within his service area. In the case of broadcasting this additional service must be an FM service. The Bill also allows a consortium of licensees serving the same area to apply for a single supplementary licence.

Once an application has been received the Minister may either accept the application and forward it to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, together with a specification of the area to be served by the licence and other technical specifications, or reject the application on planning or technical grounds, giving his reasons to the applicant.
As the supplementary licence scheme will not apply to the five mainland State capitals, applications will not be accepted from licensees serving those areas.

Once the Tribunal receives an application from the Minister it may conduct a public inquiry into the grant of the supplementary licence, and must determine whether an independent commercial licence would be viable in that area, and if so, whether it would be in the public interest, on certain specified grounds, to invite applications for such a licence.
As a result of its consideration, the Tribunal will either recommend to the Minister that applications for an independent licence be invited, or grant the supplementary licence for up to five years.

After eight years of operation, or earlier if the licensee so elects, special renewal provisions provided for in section 86A will come into operation. At such a renewal the Tribunal must re-examine the question of whether an independent licence would be viable, and if so, whether it would be in the public interest to invite applications for such a licence.

If the Tribunal determines that the area still cannot support an additional independent licence or it is not in the public interest for such a licence to be granted, the supplementary licence will be renewed for up to three years. The viability of an independent service and the public interest consideration must be re-examined at each subsequent three yearly renewal.

Once the Tribunal determines that an area can support an additional independent licence and that applications should be invited, it renews the supplementary licence for up to three years, notifies the supplementary licensee of its determination and recommends to the Minister that applications be invited for an independent service to commence three years later. The Minister has three months to decide if he accepts the Tribunal's recommendation. If he does not accept the recommendation, the supplementary licence continues in force, until the matter is re-examined by the Tribunal at the next three yearly renewal.

If the Minister accepts the Tribunal's recommendation, the licensee is notified , and has at least three months to decide which licence he wishes to retain. He may choose either to retain his original commercial licence or his supplementary licence. The licensee must also decide whether he wishes to allow the unwanted licence to expire, or to seek to transfer it to another party.
If the licensee chooses to retain the supplementary licence or transfer it to another party, it subsequently becomes a full commercial licence.

If he decides to transfer one of the licences, he has eight months in which to arrange the transfer and gain the approval of the Tribunal. This time limit may be extended at the discretion of the Tribunal to ensure continuity of service in the area concerned. If a successful transfer is effected, no further action is required by the Minister.

If the licensee elects to allow one of the licences to expire, or is unable to arrange a successful transfer, the Minister may invite applications for an independent commercial licence. If he does not do so or if an independent licence is not granted for any reason, the supplementary licence continues in force.

Supplementary licences will be subject to the normal requirements imposed by the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 and related legislation, however there are several special requirements. A supplementary broadcasting or television licensee will be required to gain the approval of the Tribunal before undertaking regular broadcasts or telecasts of programs from the related commercial station, and in the case of television only, the programs of any other station operated by another licensee, the Australian Broadcasting Commission or the Special Broadcasting Service. Special provisions relating to local content will also apply to supplementary television services. A supplementary television licensee will be required to encourage, as far as practicable, local advertising and the provision of local programming on his supplementary television service.
The above outline broadly sets out the main features of the supplementary licence scheme as embodied in the Bill.

As the Minister for Communications announced on 11 October 1982, the increasing workload being experienced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal due to the rapid increase in size and complexity of the broadcasting industry and the even greater workload anticipated with the introduction of supplementary licences, has made it necessary to increase the maximum membership of the Tribunal from five to eight members, including the Chairman and Vice-Chairman.

The supplementary licence scheme, as provided for in this Bill, is an effective means of bringing a wider choice of services to those areas which, because of their limited population, cannot support additional independent commercial licences. The scheme will also contribute to the steady growth of the commercial sector in non-metropolitan areas. The Bill before the House provides the means to do this, and allows for the necessary increase in Tribunal membership to handle the volume of inquiries which the supplementary licence scheme will generate.
Detailed notes on the clauses of the Bill are included in the Explanatory Memorandum that has been circulated to honourable senators.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill makes a consequential amendment to the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act to make the terms used to refer to supplementary broadcasting licences and stations consistent with the terms used in the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill amends the Television Stations Licence Fees Act 1964 to extend that Act to supplementary licences for television stations, consequential to the introduction of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982. References in the Act to commercial television stations, licences and licensees are applied to supplementary television stations, licences and licensees. Provisions have also been inserted to deal with licence fees payable by a consortium of commercial television licensees holding a supplementary licence. The Bill provides that the supplementary television station will be regarded as a separate operation for the purposes of licence fees assessments. The effect of these amendments is to place supplementary licensees on the same basis as commercial licensees in respect of the imposition and calculation of licence fees.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: USE OF HERBICIDES AND OTHER CHEMICALS BY THE AUSTRALIAN FORCES IN SOUTH VIETNAM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present a report on the use of herbicides, insecticides and other chemicals by the Royal Australian Air Force in Vietnam; secondly, a signal message from the Australian Embassy, Washington, notifying United States comments on the Army report on the use of herbicides, insecticides and other chemicals in South Vietnam; and, thirdly, a report on the use of herbicides, insecticides and other chemicals by the Australian Army in Vietnam. I seek leave to make a statement concerning the reports and to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

On 6 May this year, in response to a question without notice from the honourable Member for Banks, my predecessor gave an undertaking to provide any further information that might become available on the use of chemicals in South Vietnam by the Australian Army. That undertaking was given in reply to a question about the large number of Army records created in Vietnam which dealt with Australia's involvement in the Vietnam War that had been recently transferred for archival purposes to the Australian War Memorial.

A painstaking search of Army records, comprising over 20,000 files including Army files created in Vietnam and in Canberra, war diaries of units which served in Vietnam, and appropriate records of functional commands and military districts, was undertaken by teams of up to 30 Officers and Warrant Officers at a time from Army Office.

The result of that task, conducted in a sustained effort over three months, is a detailed report on the use of herbicides, insecticides and other chemicals by the Australian Army in South Vietnam. The Report also fully covers all known and possible cases of exposure of Australians to chemicals used by United States forces.
I now table that Army report. I am also tabling an Air Force report on the RAAF role in the transport and spraying of these chemicals.

Previous research by my Department on the subject of the use of chemicals in Vietnam was based almost wholly on files created in Canberra, which were thought most likely to contain all the information being sought. These concerned principally policy issues rather than operational details. Records created in Vietnam, giving operational details, were not examined exhaustively until early this year.

Already extensive documentation has been made public in such forms as the report ''Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and their use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study'' (the Pesticides Report), answers to Parliamenary Questions, Ministerial statements, press releases and, most recently, evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment and its report on Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans. The Army report does much to confirm what was previously known and made public about this subject, but it also provides new information, some of which contradicts earlier statements. These earlier statements were, of course, made in good faith on the basis of the then known facts. But, new information having come to light, some of these statements are seen to have been wrong.

I shall refer briefly to the salient points, but I stress-and the media might note-that the Army report, which is a comprehensive and accurate summary of a vast mass of material, needs to be read in its entirety to ensure a correct perspective on the events depicted in the many files examined.

The Australians in Vietnam were involved with herbicides in three ways: there was the aerial herbicide spray programme carried out by the United States; there were crop destruction missions principally carried out by the United States; and herbicides were used to control vegetation around perimeters and bases.

I wish to emphasise to honourable members that the use of herbicides in Vietnam has to be seen in the context of the war and the terrain in which it was fought. Chemical products were used in and around the Australian Army's bases in an attempt to keep down vegetation which posed risks to Australian lives because it offered cover to hostile forces. There was, and is, no mystery about this matter . The Australian Army took reasonable and responsible steps to protect Australian lives.

I draw the particular attention of honourable members to Book 2 of the Army report where it is recalled that ''the defoliation programme was seen as an important measure in helping to deprive the enemy of the advantages that he enjoyed through the use of natural vegetation for cover in Vietnam's tropical environment. In addition, through crop destruction, mainly utilizing herbicides, it was intended that the vital in-country food support that the enemy relied upon could be substantially reduced. The use of herbicides to control base area vegetation was also seen as an important protective aid to local defence.''

From 1962 to 1971 the United States carried out, in support of the Government of South Vietnam, an aerial herbicide spray programme over a wide area. This became known as the RANCH HAND programme. The aim of this was to expose enemy installations and communication routes to observation from the air and to provide improved observation and easier going for allied troops on the ground. May herbicides were used in the RANCH HAND programme, but mainly Agents Orange and White. The Army report makes it clear that the RANCH HAND missions over parts of Phuoc Tuy Province were mostly at the request of our forces from about mid 1966 to mid 1968. The cessation of the United States defoliation operations in Phuoc Tuy Province appears to have resulted from comments by the Commander, 1st Australian Task Force, among others, that they were not achieving the aims set for the RANCH HAND programme.

Control of vegetation by Australians around the Australian Task Force base area was a major task in South Vietnam. A variety of products used for that purpose was, and still is, commercially available in Australia and widely used in this country. It has been previously stated that no records had been found which showed that Australian forces had used Agent Orange. The Army report refers, however, to indications that on one occasion Australian forces may have used six drums of Agent Orange to control vegetation in 1966 but it is not possible to say with certainty that they were used.

With the exception of the mention of an Australian crop-destruction operation in the Pesticides report, it had been previously understood that Australians did not conduct crop-destruction in South Vietnam. The Army report shows Australian forces destroyed crops by using herbicides, by burning-off, by contamination with oil and by breaking padi bunds. In addition to these Australian crop- destruction operations, the US undertook similar operations at our request. Known herbicidal crop-destruction operations took place on five occasions between July 1967 and July 1968. Two others may have occurred, one in September 1968 and one in August 1969.

The Air Force report shows that 3 of the 5 crop-destruction operations I mentioned involved the use of RAAF helicopters and crew. The reports indicate that up to 13 drums of herbicide, possibly Agent Orange, may have been used in 1967. However, of these 13 drums, the documentation suggests that the US Force sprayed 10 drums and it is probable that the remaining 3 were sprayed from a RAAF helicopter.

In spite of allegations that the Army continued to use helicopters after the US stopped, there is in the Army report a record of only one request from the Australian Task Force in Vietnam, made after the US suspension, to employ the herbicide Dalapon to destroy crops. This request was not agreed to by the Department of Defence. The report also notes one instance of a post-suspension order to kill weeds on a helicopter pad at Nui Dat. Whether herbicides were to be used, or even whether the order was carried out, is not clear.

The Army report reveals little new information regarding our use of insecticides in South Vietnam. A variety of measures was used to combat insect- borne diseases, including extensive aerial insecticide spraying as well as ground spraying.

The spraying of insecticide was designed to prevent such diseases as malaria, encephalitis, and filariasis and was completely in accordance with the recommendations of the World Health Organisation (WHO) for other areas such as Africa, Central America and the South-West Pacific, and indeed with practices of long-standing and continuing present use and acceptance in Australia.
The Army report also summarises the use of other chemicals such as riot-control agents, camouflage creams and medicines taken for the prevention of malaria.

The Army report makes clear that prior to, and during, the war in South Vietnam , Australian Military Board Instructions were in force on the safety precautions for ground-spraying weed-killers and insecticides.

There were two recorded departures from these instructions. The first occurred in December 1967 when an Australian ground-spraying test of herbicides for the control of perimeter vegetation, using chemicals supplied from Australia, resulted in the exposure of eight individuals. This was attributed to the failure of the individuals to use all their safety equipment. The second involved two people, who had drunk alcohol, using aerosol insecticide sprays in a confined space during what was described as ''horseplay''. One was hospitalised.

On the topic of the extent of the exposure of Australian troops to chemicals, the Army report records two instances of aerial herbicide exposure. On 15 September 1967 V (vee) Company, a New Zealand Company of the combined Second Royal Australian Regiment/New Zealand (ANZAC) Battalion, was exposed to aerial ' 'crop dusting''. This is the only herbicidal crop-destruction operation using a helicopter in which it seems likely some personnel may have been exposed. The other exposure-and this one has already been made public-involved C Company, Fifth Royal Australian Regiment on 22nd August 1969. Some of these troops were exposed to herbicides sprayed by the US forces as part of RANCH HAND.

There were only two cases of Australian soldiers being temporarily overcome by riot control agents to the extent that formal notification was made. On a number of occasions unidentified troops suffered minor ill-effects from these agents which did not need treatment.

As well as recorded instances of exposure, the Army report points out possible exposures in the operational area of the Australian Task Force. There were eleven occasions when friendly troops may have been exposed to herbicides sprayed by the US forces as part of RANCH HAND. Details of ten of these occasions were covered in evidence on Army units given to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. There were, of course, instances where exposure to Australian ground spraying herbicide operations was possible.

The Army report indicates that on occasions during the RANCH HAND programme, herbicides were sprayed in Phuoc Tuy by the US forces at considerably higher than the recommended application rate. Only two of these cases occurred in close proximity (less than 4 km) to Australian troop locations. In view of the apparent variations in application rates I have asked that this matter be investigated in the United States.
In completing my brief summary of the Army report's contents on exposure I note that any ill-effects recorded were in those few cases where safety rules for ground-spraying were not followed.

There has been particular interest in what Ministers of the day knew about Australian herbicide spraying programmes. I shall outline briefly the instances described, in the Army report, of Ministers receiving information on this matter .

In summary, Ministers for the Army were told of problems encountered in the control of vegetation around base perimeters during 1967, and of the subsequent action taken to implement an adequate herbicide programme to protect Australian lives.

Mr Fraser, then the Minister for the Army, during a visit to the Australian Task Force in Vietnam in 1967, asked whether one of the substances tested to control vegetation contained toxic organophosphates which could be absorbed through the skin; it was subsequently confirmed that it did not.

From June 1967, quarterly reports from the Field Operational Research Section, HQ Australian Force Vietnam, appear to have been passed regularly to the Minister for the Army, Mr Fraser, at his request. The reports covered a wide range of subjects, and occasionally contained brief references to herbicide use for perimeter vegetation control.

Another document shows that in August 1967 the Deputy Chief of the General Staff wrote to the Minister for Army, Mr Fraser, ''As you are aware, 1 ATF requires defoliants and herbicides to remove growth from their defensive wire and minefields, and to keep fields of fire clear, both at Nui Dat and the Horseshoe feature''. DCGS indicated that he would seek the Minister's approval to send an expert from the Defence Standards Laboratories to Vietnam to see the problem at first hand.

In November 1967 the Minister for Army, Mr Fraser, approved the visit of Major E. S. Holt of the Scientific Advisor's Office, Army Headquarters, Canberra, to Vietnam to overcome perimeter vegetation control problems. He undertook this task with a Defence Scientist, Mr G. A. Lugg of the Defence Standards Laboratories, Department of Supply.

In a brief to the Minister for the Army, Mr Lynch, in 1969, the Secretary, Department of Army stated that Australia had not participated in warfare contrary to the 1925 Geneva Protocol, and defoliants had been used only for weed -killing.

The Returned Servicemen's League in December 1969 sought assurance from the Minister for Defence, Mr Fraser, that Servicemen's records would be endorsed when they served in places where chemicals were employed. The Minister directed the Services to review their recording arrangements. In responding to the Minister for Defence in January 1970, Army stated that current policy called for a blood test to be made on all casualties and on persons suspected of having been subjected to chemical attack; that protective measures were taken to eliminate the risk of exposure where chemical agents were used for defensive purposes; and that accidental exposure was recorded on individual medical documents. In reply to the Secretary of Defence regarding the Minister's directive that Army review its recording arrangements (April 1970), Army said in August of that year that its arrangements were adequate but would be kept under review.

In Navy's case, there were no existing arrangements for recording exposure to chemicals, but arrangements were made in 1970 and appropriate naval authorities were asked to report any case of exposure to the Head of Naval Personnel Branch, Navy Office.

The Air Force considered that Air Board Order A7/28 was adequate to ensure the medical recording of chemical exposure. However, a specific question was included in the post-South East Asia medical examination procedures relating to ''any history of exposure to Weedicides/Pesticides or CS (tear) gas''. The RAAF also issued instructions for appropriate blood examination if there was any suspicion of exposure.

These requirements were subsequently embodied in RAAF Director General of Medical Services ''Medical Services Circular Serial No. GEN 1-31'' issued on 30th April 1970. This circular directed that a medical examination be carried out within 3 months of a member's return from Vietnam and provided that ''a specific history of exposure to toxic chemicals of the weedicide/herbicide type, or to CS (tear) gas is to be recorded and appropriate action taken.''

Finally, although as I have said Ministers were aware of the use of herbicides to control vegetation around Australian bases, there is no record of Ministers having been informed of Australian participation in crop-destruction operations or of Australian requests for US forces to carry out aerial herbicide spray missions.

The report recalls in various places that the enemy mounted a propaganda campaign about the deleterious effects of herbicides. This campaign aroused fears and concern similar to those experienced today. The US provided information which stressed that herbicides when sprayed and used as directed would not harm humans. It is possible that many present-day worries over the use of herbicides are born out of that propaganda campaign.

Now I would like to mention several other related matters. There may be some concern that in tabling its report on ''Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans'' the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment was not aware of the general findings of the Army report. I can say that the salient facts I have outlined here today were presented to the Committee. That Committee will, no doubt, assess the Army report.

Previously, in the Pesticides Report, the extent of RAAF involvement in the aerial spraying of herbicides and insecticides had been specified. Also, as mentioned earlier, the Air Force report provides new details of the participation of RAAF helicopters and crew in crop-destruction missions. The Air Force report also covers other RAAF chemical activity.

In the Pesticides Report a fairly high degree of probability was accorded to the delivery and use of twenty 50 gallon drums of Agent Blue by Australians in September 1967. The Army report finds no evidence to support such a conclusion.
The Army Office personnel who undertook the task of researching the records and preparing this report are to be congratulated on their extensive and meticulous investigations.

I cannot guarantee that further information will not come to light in future. However, given the enormous volume of records already examined, I strongly doubt whether any files that might hereafter be found will yield new information that would materially alter the picture that has emerged.

Given the high public interest in this topic, I have directed that special arrangements be made to make publicly available the files and documents on which the reports are based. In addition to other material, these include about 400 files created in Vietnam and now in the custody of the Australian War Memorial. Some of the documents on these particular files are of foreign-mainly US-origin and the agreement of the originators is being sought to their public disclosure. Australian documents on those 400 files are also being examined prior to release to protect individual privacy and, if relevant and necessary, national security. Those cleared should soon be available for public inspection.
I stress that all the documents, whether security classified or not, were examined and reported on by the Army team. Thus security considerations in no way affect the contents of the Army report.

In our efforts to ensure that our reconstruction of the events of those days is accurate, my Department sought from the US Department of Defense an assurance that the Army report does not contain information contrary to any they hold. They know of no information contained in US documents or reports which will contradict the findings of the Australian report. The US review of their Vietnam records is continuing, but at present, they have no information which would qualify this report.

My Department has co-operated in this by providing information to the Commonwealth Institute of Health, which is studying the possible effects of Vietnam service on Australian troops, to the Departments of Health and Veterans' Affairs, and to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment in its inquiry into pesticides.

The reports constitute a major work of reference for those bodies and I know that they will find them useful. They supplement information already given to the Senate Committee in evidence by officers of my Department and in written answers to questions from the Committee.

The source documents to these reports, other than the few restricted by privacy and security considerations, will be available to all these interested government agencies as well as to private bodies and individuals for further research.

In addition to the normal tabling distribution of the report, I am making copies available to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment , to Departments, to the Commonwealth Institute of Health and to interested persons outside the Parliament.

The Army report being a summary of the Vietnam files tells us nothing about any possible long-term effects of exposure to herbicides and the other chemicals. That subject was covered by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment in its report on 'Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans', tabled last month. What this Army report covers is the extent of exposure to herbicides, and it will be noted that Australian troops in Vietnam, in fact, experienced relatively little exposure. The Government is determined to unravel the events of the past and to assess any possible implications for the welfare of Vietnam veterans and their dependants. This report represents a further major contribution to our knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one or two final remarks. The article is epitomising the decision of the majority in the Koowarta case as follows:

Where matters have, by virtue of general multilateral Conventions or treaties, to which Australia is a party, or by reason of customary international law, become a proper and genuine subject for co-operative international action, in which such international action the Commonwealth of Australia has a clearly discernible interest, legislation by the Commonwealth Parliament legitimately dealing with such matters or giving precise effect to the Commonwealth's obligations under the relevant multilateral Conventions or treaties, or under the relevant rules of customary international law, will be held valid as being supported by the external affairs power, notwithstanding that the legislation concerned may impinge otherwise upon the constitutional powers of the Australian States, and accordingly State Governments and the citizens of the States will be bound to comply with the provisions of such Commonwealth legislation.

I draw the attention of the Senate to that epitome, as it is called, for the reasons of the decision. —That is $18,000 that you have cost the taxpayers so far.
—Order! I suggest that the Committee come to order. I call Senator Lewis.

—When the quorum was called I was referring to the article in the Australian Law Journal and stating that the dicta of 1936 had not met with universal approval, that it had in fact contributed to the development of a substantial body of controversial literature concerning the range of the external affairs power.
—Senator Lewis has cost the Commonwealth $21,000 so far.

—I keep hearing interjections from Senator Mason about how much I am costing the people of Australia, or something of that nature. I do not believe that the people of Australia will think there is any undue cost in the making of an analysis of the external affairs power of the Commonwealth, which is what this debate is all about. The late Sir Robert Menzies, in his book Central Power in the Australian Commonwealth, questioned the extended view of the external affairs power adopted by Evatt and McTiernan in the Burgess case as the Evatt doctrine, and subjected it to a critical examination, making various rhetorical queries as to the consequences of its full application.
—Including the consequences for the conciliation and arbitration power.
—Yes. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, due to the doubts as to the interpretation of clause 29, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Constitutional Review recommended in 1959 that the Constitution be amended so as to enable the Commonwealth Parliament to make laws with respect to the manufacture of nuclear fuels-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about 1859?
—Nuclear fuels would be a subject that would be dear to the heart of Senator Gietzelt. The statement continues:

SPEECH.PARA: -the generation and use of nuclear energy and ionising radiations in order thereby to be able unchallengably to implement international decisions and arrangements in the nuclear area.

In other words, in 1959 a Commonwealth joint parliamentary committee was so concerned about the weakness of the external affairs power that it recommended that the Constitution be changed to enable the Commonwealth to pass this sort of legislation because it was of the view-that is, the Committee was of the view- that the power was not wide enough. The article then goes on to say how joyfully Senator Evans welcomed the judgment when it was published on 11 May this year. It then summarises the principal general points about the external affairs power which received authoritative endorsement by the High Court. As I said, I am trying to be unbiased in this matter and to give to the Committee the views of the majority decision of the High Court, which is the broadest interpretation of this power. I am reading from this summary of them for the benefit of other senators. It states:

(1) section 51 clause (xxix) confers a plenary, distinct and independent grant of power; that is to say, a power not merely ancillary to or restricted by the other powers possessed by the Parliament under section 51.

That is an interesting point. I do not think it is any great constitutional point; it is one that most constitutional lawyers would have accepted a long time ago. But still it is made in this decision. The summary continues:

(2) any subject matter may constitute an external affair, provided that the manner in which it is treated involves in some way a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia.

This is the summary in this article of the views of the High Court, which the author of the article believes are fairly put by the decision. For those who do not appreciate it, when the High Court gives a judgment it is not a single judgment as each judge is entitled to and frequently does give his own decision and so sometimes one ends up with six or seven exposes of what the law is all about. That makes it very difficult to summarise what the law actually is because there might be six or seven different interpretations. The author of this summary said that:
A fair summary of this is that any subject matter may constitute an external affair . . .
Who could argue with that? That would certainly enable this legislation to be valid. He then goes on to say:
. . . provided that the manner in which it is treated involves in some way a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia.

How could it possibly be said that the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill , which deals specifically with a part of Tasmania, in some way or other deals with persons or things outside Australia. That is why I have repeatedly put to Senator Mason-I put it to him again as strongly as I can-that he ought to take this Bill away and get some advice on its validity before he subjects the people of Australia to the putting through of this legislation. Imagine all the rigmarole we would have to go through. Senator Mason talks about the expense of me speaking in this chamber. The expense of a High Court judgment in which the validity of this Bill was considered would be 20 times the figures that he has been yelling at me across the chamber tonight. The author of this article continues:
(3) The external affairs power is to be construed liberally, not narrowly and pedantically, provided, however, that its exercise is not related to matters of purely domestic concern.

I draw the attention of the Committee to that statement again. The power is to be interpreted liberally-we accept that-but its exercise must not be related to matters of purely domestic concern. Surely this proposal of Senator Mason's, this Bill, relates to matters of purely domestic concern. The article goes on:
(4) The power is, however, to be exercised within established limits-

(a) like all other powers given by section 51 of the Constitution, it is subject to this Constitution so that the grant of such power must be read as subject to the restraints upon legislative power imposed by other sections of the Constitution.

(b) an exercise of the power would not be valid if it contravened some basic features of the Constitution and of the Federation; for example, if it operated to prevent a State or States from continuing to exist and function as such.
In other words, it is clearly indicated that the exercise of the power must not prevent the States from operating in accordance with the federation. The summary continues:
(c) It could not be exercised so as to amend the Constitution and thus to conflict with the power of amendment conferred by section 128 of that instrument .

(d) A statute enacted in order to give effect to a treaty concluded by the Government merely as a means of conferring legislative power that is colourable and not bona fide could not be supported by clause (xxix) of section 51 of the Constitution.

That is the view of the majority which Senator Evans has been pushing to me across the chamber as the view that I ought to be talking about. He suggests that I should not talk about the view of the dissenting judges. I suggest to the chamber and I suggest again to Senator Mason, if only he would listen to me, that even within that interpretation his proposed Act, the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill, would not be valid. If it is carried, ultimately it will have to be subjected to review by the High Court at enormous expense to the people of Australia because the people of Australia will be paying all sides-the judges, the plaintiffs, the defendants and everyone involved-in order to discover what I have just told the Committee, that this Bill is invalid. I say again to Senator Mason that he should take to his heart the words of Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs in relation to the exercise of this power, as summarised in the headnote which says:

A law which gives effect within Australia to an international agreement will only be valid under section 51 (xxix) if it is with respect to a matter which itself can be described as an external affair. Any subject may constitute an external affair if the manner in which it is treated in some way involves a relationship with other countries or with persons or things outside Australia.
Finally, I again quote from the Chief Justice, who in fact was quoting Oliver:

A constitution would cease to be federal if the central government, without consultation with the states, could enter into any treaty and by so doing increase the legislative powers of the central government at the expense of the state legislatures. If the treaty power can cut across all reserved powers and interdict the powers of the member states, then there are no real powers reserved to internal sovereignties.

Clearly that is what is proposed in this Bill. That is why I once again beg Senator Mason to adopt the proposal I have suggested to him-that clause 1 be postponed, that he take the Bill away and seek legal advice on its validity. He should consider the constitutional propriety of this legislation, which rides rough-shod over the views of a constituent part of the federation and should then come back here and explain to it whether he is going to go on with the Bill or whether he is going to withdraw it. He may even be able to produce some other form of Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to deal with the civil liberties side of this motion moved by Senator Lewis. In quite a number of areas his motion relates to the civil liberties of the Australian people. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills also referred to civil liberties in regard to this piece of legislation. I quote from the last sentence of its report on this Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: In the absence of any clear guidelines in the Bill as to the precise scope of the proscribed actions referred to in clause 6, the Committee draws this clause to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that it might be regarded as trespasssing unduly on personal rights and liberties.

I wonder how much members of this chamber really are concerned about civil liberties. Yesterday Senator Chipp threatened 23 members of parliament whose seats would be lost with an electoral swing of less than 3 per cent. The civil liberties of those members of parliament are threatened by Senator Chipp. If we read the Hansard we see that Senator Chipp very clearly threatens those members that if, as he would say, they do not kowtow to his demands, he will take action . Action will be taken against them, and there will be considerable lobbying to put those members-- (Quorum formed). As I was saying, Senator Chipp has threatened those 23 Government members of parliament. He has said that they will be the target--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Chairman, I must ask you to rule on the relevance of what Senator Walters is saying.
—Senator Walters, I ask you to relate your remarks to the question before the Chair, namely, that clause 1 be postponed because of the circumstances set out in the motion.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. As I indicated when I rose, I am referring to the civil liberties that I believe this Bill tramples on. Not only I but also the members of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee believe that this Bill tramples on civil liberties. I quoted from the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Senator Chipp, as I say, does not believe that the civil liberties of those members of parliament are all that important.
—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. I ask you again to rule on the relevance of what Senator Walters is saying.
—Senator Chipp, I think Senator Walters related her remarks to sub- clause (b) (1) of the motion before the Committee and, therefore, I rule that Senator Walters is in order.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Let us look at Senator Chipp's behaviour on this, because I think the civil liberties angle is terribly important. Let us set aside the issue of South West Tamania. Let us set aside the Human Rights Commission Bill, from which I would like to quote. Senator Chipp clearly enunciated what he believed were the civil liberties of members of parliament. As I said yesterday, he said he would trample on those civil liberties and he would intimidate them--

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I tried to save time by being very brief in my previous points of order. I made a statement yesterday, when speaking to a statement by Senator Baume, about putting on notice members of parliament who are members of the Liberal Party and exposing the views of the Liberal Party to the electorate at the next election. I ask you to rule as to the relevance of what Senator Walters is saying about that to the motion moved by Senator Lewis, the most forgettable senator in the place.

—Order! Senator Walters has already indicated that she is relating her remarks to the 17th report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and comments made by that Committee on the Bill now before us. If honourable senators look at Senator Lewis's motion they will see that it suggests that clause 1 be postponed and that the Bill be redrafted so that it no longer contains the inadequacies and ambiguities identified in that Committee's report. I suggest that there is no point of order at this stage. But I ask you, Senator Walters, to try to restrict your remarks to Senator Lewis's motion.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I have already indicated that Senator Chipp had decided that threats were in order. But I now read from Senator Chipp' s speech on 20 March 1980 when he was debating the Human Rights Commission Bill. Again, this speech referred to the civil liberties that are mentioned in this report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and in Senator Lewis's motion. Senator Chipp, on that occasion, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I resent some people in the Right to Life organisation, the indefatigable blackmailers as Senator Evans describes them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I cannot see that Senator Chipp's views on the Right to Life organisation have any bearing whatsoever on this discussion. I think that you must seriously consider calling Senator Walters to order. She is continually irrelevant.
—Senator, I cannot see the relevance at this stage, either, of the references that she has just made to the clause. But I am listening so that I can ask her to relate her remarks.

—Mr Chairman, I wish to speak to the point of order. Since you have ruled on it I will be very brief. My understanding is that there is a linkage proposed for a number of different statements and this is merely the first of them, so I will speak to the point of order if it is raised again.
—Senator Chipp continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the . . . blackmailers as Senator Evans describes them. I refuse to see most of them now.
I despise the way they use their weight and their blackmail over members in the other place who have a small majority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, they did.
—That is right. Senator Chipp said that he despised the way they used their weight and their blackmail over members in the other place who have a small majority. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: If those honourable members do not kowtow to their demands, some of the Right to Life people say, 'Right, we will get you . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters has transgressed from the particular clause which we are debating. What Senator Chipp said in another place in another circumstance has absolutely no relevance at all to the matter that is being debated. It is clear that Senator Walters is involved in just wasting the time of the Senate, wasting taxpayers' money, and spending time raising matters which are not relative to this debate. It is clear we are involved in a filibuster of some magnitude by some of the troglodytes of the Liberal Party.

—Order! I notice the Chairman of Committees has ruled several times. It is an historical debate. Fleeting references have been made, and I think Senator Walters will be aware of earlier rulings given and will follow that directive.

—Perhaps I may just finish the quotation. Senator Chipp then spoke about the Right to Life people. He said: If those honourable members do not kowtow to their demands, some of the Right to Life people say, 'Right, we will get you. You are finished.' That is despicable blackmail in my view.

—I raise a point of order. I put it to you most seriously, Mr Temporary Chairman, that these comments of Senator Chipp have no relationship whatsoever to the motion, which is that clause 1 of this Bill be postponed. I suggest you instruct Senator Walters in that direction.
—On the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman, Standing Order 421 says 'continued irrelevance or tedious repetition'. I just draw your attention to the fact that we are being subjected to both.
—Speaking also to the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman, the debate in Committee so far has been a fairly wide ranging one on a motion which is suggesting--
—I do not know what Right to Life has to do with this.

—A lot of help is coming from all parts of the chamber, which is likely to postpone the matter still further. The fact is that there is a request before the Senate that the clause be postponed as an instruction to Senator Mason to do certain things. The postponement of the clause is a matter on which the Senate could be influenced by a whole series of different considerations. One of the considerations which have been put before the Committee by Senator Walters is that one view has been adopted by the Australian Democrats with respect to pushing for action on one issue, and a quite different course of action, a quite different approach, is being adopted with respect to the dams issue. I submit that it would be in accord with the usual practice of this place in Committee if the honourable senator were given the opportunity to develop her argument in her own way. It would avoid undue further delay if that could be done without undue interruption from the other side.

—Order! I know that this has been a marathon debate-I am tempted to ask for black coffee and sandwiches to be brought in so that honourable senators will get back to following a sane line. It has not been easy for any of us. I know that some honourable senators want to wind it up. I make this appeal. There is a grey area. People on each side have taken offence at some terms which have been used. However, I repeat: Senator McClelland, the Chairman, has had to walk a tightrope, as I have. Nobody wants to stifle speakers, but perhaps if every honourable senator is not quite so provocative we shall reach the light at the end of the tunnel.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I have just read two statements that Senator Chipp has made-one when it suited him, to intimidate the honourable members in the other place, and one when he was being threatened by an outside organisation and he called it despicable. He said that honourable members are expected to kowtow to their demands. What on earth is Senator Chipp suggesting? Is he suggesting that those 23 members he named are meant to kowtow to the demands of the Australian Democrats and that otherwise they will be acted against? I am appalled at the hypocrisy of the Democrats, and I appeal to the media to take up this matter and to divulge Senator Chipp's hypocrisy about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am again supporting Senator Lewis's motion to postpone consideration of clause 1 of Senator Mason's Bill. Senator Walters was quite obviously supporting what Senator Lewis has proposed. Above a lot of noise, most of which was irritating and was designed to disturb her to throw her off the point, she was supporting Senator Lewis's motion. Mr Temporary Chairman, I have to make this point with you. It seems to me here that if one agrees with Senator Chipp and Senator Mason about this Bill, everything is fine; there is no problem. One is not subjected to a continual flow of disturbance and interjection. The same thing applies to other honourable senators opposite, who have just determined that those of us who appear to be a minority are just not going to be heard.

SPEECH.PARA: I insist that what I am saying is germane to the Bill, because embodied in what Senator Lewis has tried to say in this motion are those individual rights and individual liberties which we all enjoy as citizens of States and of this Commonwealth. Senator Lewis has sought to ensure that these important things are retained and that this Bill of Senator Mason, this attempt to batter into submission those of us who believe that the States have some rights, should not prevail. Obviously Senator Mason has not taken much cognisance-his Bill shows it -of some of the constitutional and legal history that Senator Lewis has been drawing to out attention. I draw Senator Mason's attention to section 61, the executive power, in the Constitution. The exercise of this executive power was important for the establishment of departments such as the Department of Education and the successive Commonwealth departments which have dealt with the environment-currently it is the Department of Home Affairs and Environment.

While the Commonwealth has no direct legislative control in these areas it can set up an administrative structure to co-ordinate activities with the States, to keep statistics, to research and advise and to monitor grants made to the States pursuant to section 96 of the Constitution. I think this is important. These are some of the essential features that Senator Lewis has sought to draw to Senator Mason's attention-quite unsuccessfully so far. Section 61 is also an important basis of power when considered in conjunction with the concept of the national implied power. I think Senator Lewis has referred to the AAP case in which Mr Justice Mason considered that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation was a legitimate exercise of the executive power. He said in that case:

In my opinion, there is to be deduced from the existence and character of the Commonwealth as a national government and from the presence of sections 51 and 61 a capacity to engage in enterprises and activities peculiarly adapted to the government of a nation and which cannot otherwise be carried on for the benefit of the nation.

I submit that in no way does Senator Mason's Bill fit in with that interpretation of Mr Justice Mason. Indeed, had he looked at some of these precedents, his Bill would have been more constructive. I assure Senator Mason that he would not have had the trouble had his Bill been better presented and better researched.

As I keep insisting, we are trying only to save the Senate from embarrassment. We do not want to be infected with the professional incompetence displayed by Senator Mason. The Senate is going to be blamed for this, and people not present here at the moment have suggested that we are trying to make a laughing-stock of the Senate. Indeed, we are not. We are not trying to make a laughing-stock of the Senate; we are trying to save the Senate and the reputation of the Senate. The only way in which we can do that is to amend this ridiculous Bill and to try to give it some reasonable, logical and legal presentation so that it may be acceptable to the people of Australia. Senator Lewis has made his best efforts and this stubborn man over here will not bend. He is absolutely intractable. Surely the power to convince rests in the Senate chamber. It is our objective to convince each other, particularly those on the other side, of the justice of our cause. Senator Lewis in his motion has tried to do this. For some reason obscure to us, we are not able to make our point. I regret that deeply. I say to you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that the Senate will be a laughing stock if this Bill is passed by the Senate. It is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Hansard reporter was not writing before I rose. I consider that those who voted to negative the adjournment have been unfair to the Hansard reporters. They are not taking a written transcript.
—The proceedings are being recorded on tape, Senator. We have wasted enough time.
—I understand that-
—I ask Senator Harradine to resume his seat. We have cleared it up. I have got Senator Harradine's message. It has been fixed up. I call the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene in the debate to say that two weeks ago when it was proposed that we should continue sitting I suggested to some honourable senators that it would be very bad for our health. It turns out that honourable senators are in much better voice after five weeks of sitting than they usually are after three days. I congratulate all honourable senators on their strength. As far as the motion currently before us is concerned, the Government shares the concern about the quality of this Bill. That was made clear in the second reading speech of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume). I am sorry that Senator Peter Baume has had a long-standing commitment which has required him to take leave. I simply reiterate at this stage of the Committee debate-
—Where has he gone?

—It would be helpful if I could at least comment briefly. It might enable us to make some progress. The fundamental concern which has been expressed about the Bill is its possible impact upon the federal nature of our Constitution. The view has been expressed by the High Court of Australia and others that the federal nature of our Constitution requires that limits be imposed on the broad power to implement international obligations seemingly conferred by the Constitution. That is a very valid concern to be expressed by the Committee. Some honourable senators feel that it could have been expressed more briefly but the fact is that it is fundamental to the Australian constitutional arrangements and, therefore, it is quite reasonable that there should be a high level of Senate interest in the matter. It does appear, however , that views about this aspect are relatively fixed. Some honourable senators feel that the request is unreasonable. Other honourable senators feel that, in view of the importance of this matter and in view of the technical problems about which Senator Peter Baume talked in his second reading speech, it really is incumbent on the Australia Democrats to pause, to take further and better advice and to redraft the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that the eloquence of any honourable senator will change anyone' s view at this late stage. I suspect that we have reached the point where the argument has solidified and cemented us into our respective positions. Therefore , I suggest respectfully to the Committee that we should test the temper of the Committee by taking a vote on this motion. The fact is that other amendments are to be proposed. I understand that the Australian Labor Party is moving at least two amendments. The position of the Government in relation to those amendments-I do not wish to take a lot of the time of the Committee if we deal with them-is that whilst we retain our fundamental concern about the Bill, which has been expressed by other speakers and by Senator Peter Baume, we do believe that the amendments proposed by the Opposition improve the Bill, although they do not make it totally acceptable. I indicate on behalf of the Government that we propose to support those amendments in Committee. It is a reserved sort of support but it would mean that the Bill would be in a--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are amendments to the amendments.
—I reserve judgment on those for the moment, Senator.
—They have been distributed.

—That is a very good reason for reserving judgment. My indication to the Committee is that we will be supporting the Opposition's amendments because they improve the quality of the Bill. Notwithstanding our support for those amendments, it is still a Bill that the Government opposes. I suggest to the Committee that, unless someone has a particularly new and burning argument, we proceed to vote on this matter, then deal with the Bill clause by clause to enable senators who have particular suggestions or concerns about clauses to speak to them, and try to reach some conclusion on the matter in that way. I do not intend to go over ground that has been traversed by other speakers. I affirm , on behalf of the Government, our concern about the federal implications of this legislation and on that basis indicate that the Government will support the motion moved by Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, were I able to I would move the adjournment of this debate to enable the Hansard writers and senators to have an hour for tea, but I seek your ruling as to whether I am able to do so. I am concerned that those who have negatived the adjournment have placed an extraordinary burden on the Hansard writers and on the Committee. We have been siting continuously since 10 a.m. and I ask whether I would be in order in moving that the Senate suspend the sitting to permit an hour's break to be taken.
—I understand, Senator, that you are limited in this way: You may move that the Committee report progress and the Committee can then consider the matter.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That progress be reported.

I take this action on the specific understanding that I am not involved in a filibuster; there has been none. The matter could proceed in Committee when we return from dinner. We may be unlucky; the dining room staff may well have gone home. I do not know what the catering situation is. My hope is that senators will agree to the motion not only for their own sake but also for the sake of the Hansard writers and other staff who slave around this place.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I have inadvertently misled my senatorial colleagues slightly in what I have said. There has been a slight amount of cross-purpose between the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) and me. He is discussing the matter at the moment. When I was on my feet before in light of the fact that the Opposition was moving certain amendments which we support as being amendments which would improve the Bill, I urged all members of the Committee to proceed to a vote on this as soon as possible. The implications of that from a procedural point of view, I think, were clearly understood around the chamber. At that time I made the comments on the basis that Senator Harradine clearly indicated that he would refuse leave for the third reading tonight. He has made that quite clear and I understand that he does not propose to change his mind. The point on which I had no information when I spoke before was that apparently there are two occasions on which leave is required. One is on the reporting of progress and the other is on the third reading. It will not assist us for the rest of this evening if senators on either side proceed under a misapprehension of each other's intentions.
—We have known all along that that was what he would do.

—All I am trying to do is to indicate to the Committee that, whilst I had hoped that the debate on this part of the clause might come to an end at this stage, that is a matter on which I will not be in a position to indicate what will happen until I have some clear indication as to the Opposition's intention with respect to its amendment. I wanted that to be quite clear so that honourable senators on this side of the chamber were aware of the procedural situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Committee will again give me an opportunity to restate some of the views which I have tried to express in clear language so that honourable senators on the other side can understand the points I am trying to make. It is a very simple series of points.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. You quite properly said earlier that the Standing Order which disciplines a senator who indulges in repetition has never been used, to your knowledge, in this place. I suggest that it is no reason why it should not be used now because by Senator Lewis's own admission his opening remarks-I do not know whether you heard them because you were negotiating with your deputy-were: 'I will now restate the views for the benefit of those Opposition members who did not understand the views I stated earlier'. That is a simple statement of intent of repetition. I put it to you in clear terms that this Standing Order needs to be invoked not just because of what he said, that he would restate his argument in identical terms, but because of the context of this whole argument. Senator Harradine, Senator Lewis, Senator Martyr, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Walters are determined that this Bill should not go to the House of Representatives while it is still sitting. They will do anything under any circumstances to prevent that course of action. That is the clear tactic, Mr Chairman, which should now be manifest. When an honourable senator gets up and openly states that he is going to flout a Standing Order-that was his opening remark-I do submit with great respect that you ought to act.

—Mr Chairman, I would like to talk on the point of order because I believe that Senator Lewis is quite correct in drawing attention to the inadequacies of the Australian Democrats' proposition that is before the Committee.
—How many times?

—It is full of holes; it denies the public the civil liberties it purports to represent; and Senator Lewis has stated the ambiguities which it contains. My friend, Senator Missen, who drew the attention of the Committee to the inadequacies of the Bill is now culpable of going over to the other side to deny the opportunity--
—What rubbish!

—He says: 'What rubbish'. He goes over to the other side, denying the Committee the opportunity to examine this particular proposition and put it into some form of sensible proposition that we can discuss. The Democrats are culpable in every respect; they have no idea of bringing before this chamber any credible proposition that we can discuss. They have five members and five different ideas about what they want to do. That is the reason I believe that Senator Lewis's proposition is correct. He has drawn attention to the main inadequacy of this thing which involves section 51, clause (xxix) of the Constitution, but the Democrats have no idea of what the Constitution means. They have no idea of what the Federal Constitution means to Tasmania. I am just saying--
—Order, Senator Jessop! I ask you to restrict your remarks to the point of order taken by Senator Chipp.

—I am just suggesting that the Australian Democrats are completely irresponsible and are attempting to frustrate the progress of this Committee. I suggest that that is a totally inadequate proposition.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Harradine

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on the point of order: Senator Chipp made two points in his point of order. First, he criticised Senator Lewis for suggesting that he was going to restate a particular proposition. Senator Chipp suggested that under the Standing Orders that was repetition, though he did not say tedious repetition. The second point that he made, which was totally irrelevant, was that certain honourable senators had engaged in certain tactics in this place. I submit that on both counts there is no point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: On the latter point, all I was doing was trying to get some answers. There has been no answer at all from Senator Mason to the matters I have raised. I submit that a restatement of a proposition need not be a repetition of that proposition . One can restate a proposition in different terms. Quite often lawyers are heard to say: 'I will restate that proposition in different terms'. Under those circumstances, I believe there is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wish to speak briefly to the point of order. I have listened very carefully to the recent speeches of Senator Lewis. I must say that I think the point of order is insupportable. After listening to him, I marvel at his ability to produce new argument and new material on the same point . I have heard little that I would regard as repetitious and I ask you to rule the point of order as not being substantiated.

—I wish to speak on the point of order, Mr Chairman. It is probable that the jack-booted Opposition will deny me the opportunity to claim that I was misrepresented. It is quite erroneous for Senator Chipp gratuitously to assign motives to me as wishing to block this Bill. I am trying to see that the best legislation is passed for the people of Australia and I will thank him not to attribute motives to me.
—Order! At this stage there is no point of order. I call Senator Lewis.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. When I was interrupted-the interruption has taken some seven and a half minutes of my time to speak-I was saying that there are two sections to the instructions to Senator Mason proposed in my motion. I have proposed that clause 1 be postponed as an instruction to Senator Mason, firstly, so that he might take advice on the validity and constitutional propriety of this legislation. The reasons are very simple. We ask Senator Mason to consider this matter to ensure that the exercise of this power does not destroy the federal character of the Constitution of Australia. It is a simple proposition. Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs said:

SPEECH.PARA: A constitution would cease to be federal if the central government, without consultation with the states, could enter into any treaty and by so doing increase the legislative powers of the central government at the expense of the state legislatures. If the treaty power can cut across all reserved powers and interdict the powers of the member states, then there are no real powers reserved for the internal sovereignties.

What he is saying, in effect, is that we are thereby destroying the Federation. Now it may be that some senators and members of the House of Rep resentatives would want to destroy the Federa tion, but I certainly do not and that is why I have joined in this debate. I have tried to make it per fectly clear that I am quite opposed to the con struction of the dams in Tasmania, but I am sin cerely concerned about the rights of the States. I see Senator Button over there is looking at me. I am sincerely concerned about the deficiencies in this Bill and the rights of the States as imposed by this Bill.

Let me turn to the second part of my instruc tions to Senator Mason as proposed in my motion-that is, to redraft the Bill so that it no longer contains the inadequacies and ambiguities identified in the seventeenth report of the Stand ing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I have indicated to the Committee that subsequently I would consider this clause. I now consider sub-clause (b) (1). Subsequently I will come to sub-clauses (b) (2), (b) (3) and (b) (4). The seven teenth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills clearly indicates the nature of the deficiencies of the proposed legislation. The re port says:
The clause-
I am referring to clause 6, the protection of properties.
-provides very little identification of the scope of unlawful actions with which the Bill would deal.

Senator Chipp told us last week that the whole purpose of this Bill was to attack some alleged vandalism in Tasmania. I have repeatedly pointed out to the Committee that the Bill goes much further than that. It is the extent of the Bill which creates the problem. If Senator Chipp and Senator Mason had brought into this chamber a Bill which attacked a particular action in relation to--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you said an hour and a half ago, word for word.

—As Senator Gietzelt said, I raised this question an hour and a half ago. In fact, I think I raised it four hours ago, if the truth be known. But no one has provided an answer, least of all Senator Mason, who has the conduct of this Bill and so far has not spoken on the matter during this four- hour debate. Not once has he attempted-
—And he is not here.

—In fact, he is not even in the chamber. Yet it is his Bill that we are considering and he has provided no answers to any of the matters which we have raised in the course of this debate-matters of real significance. Mr Chairman, I ask you to look at clause 6, the protection of properties. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unlawful for a person to do any act or take any action that is likely adversely to affect the protection, conservation, presentation or rehabilitation of a property, the preservation as part of the world heritage of mankind as a whole of a property or the transmission to future generations of a property . . .
Let us just look at the broadness of that. There is no limitation on it. There are no exceptions, no proposed rules, and no detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you had a look at the amendments?

—Senator Button tells us that there are some amendments. I hope that in due course he will endeavour to amend the Bill to make it a better Bill. I have had a look at the amendments which he proposes to this stage. So far as I am concerned they do not go far enough in protecting the rights of the people of Tasmania. Citizens of that State are perfectly entitled to have their rights protected, just as Senator Chipp proposes to have some land in Tasmania protected.
—You even have the red light going now.

—What can one say? I have done my best, Mr Chairman, to try to draw the attention of the Committee to the deficiencies of this legislation. I suggest that the Bill ought to be redrafted, and that Senator Mason ought to agree tonight to take the Bill away and redraft it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a very brief debate on clause 3. In fact, one could not dignify what happened with the term 'debate'. Now that we have reached clause 4, I wish to make a couple of comments about what has just occurred. It was only on 29 July that Senator Chipp said to the National Press Club that there would be no gags in the future in the Senate, there would be no guillotines, and there would be no burying of difficult matters. I mention that because--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not mention that to start a row. I mention it because I want to suggest that it would be desirable at least to allow adequate debate on each clause so that senators wishing to raise matters of concern could have a chance to put them on record. A number of senators have indicated concern about the drafting of this legislation. It is undoubtedly one of the Senate's functions to be concerned about those matters, as it is also a concern of this Senate to be concerned about constitutional issues.
