SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Mason a couple of questions about this clause as he is in charge of the Bill. Unfortunately, senators do not have a memorandum before them explaining each clause, which is normal then Bills are presented to the Parliament. We do not have that; so I am forced, as are other honourable senators, to ask the person in charge of the Bill what certain aspects, words and clauses mean. With regard to clause 4, I ask Senator Mason: What do the words 'doing of an act' mean in clause 4 (2)? Do those words relate to clause 3 (2) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the doing of an act or taking action by a person includes a reference to the doing of an act or the taking of action by a person in association with or for or on behalf of another person or other persons.

This is a very important question. We are talking about a person's civil rights and liberties. Does this mean in practical terms that if this legislation is passed, a Hydro-Electric Commission worker-a member of a trade union, who is performing a task in accordance with works authorised under a State Act of Parliament-is the person who, under those circumstances, would be liable? That is a very important question. I want to know what is meant by the 'doing of an act' in that context. Does it refer to the doing of an act prejudicial to a property? This leads to my second question. When are the mechanisms of the Bill triggered? Are they triggered when the property is submitted under Article 11 of the Convention or are they triggered when, as Senator Tate said, in his view, the property is accepted by the World Heritage Commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —You know the answer to that one, too, don't you?

—No, I do not. In a previous debate we have had a difference of opinion between Senator Tate and Senator Evans on the matter. I remind the Senate of what those honourable senators said in respect of that question. Senator Tate raised a very important question about the time that any power arises; that is, whether it is at the time of listing-in accordance with his words; it is really at the time of sub- mission, according to the Bill.
—You have said all this 18 times.
—Well, I want an answer.
—Well, sit down and see whether you get one.
—Am I assured of an answer on that, Senator?
—You had better do as he says, or he will move the gag.
—That is right. I will sit down.
—Order! The honourable senator should address his remarks through the Chair. I cannot anticipate Senator Mason's intentions until he gets the call.

—I want him to answer specifically whether the Hydro-Electric Commission worker will be caught; when will the property be a property in accordance with this legislation; and is he of the same view as Senator Tate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to raise a couple of other matters. The legislation deals with property submitted by the Commonwealth under Article 11 of the Convention for the Protection of the World's Cultural and Natural Heritage. What would happen if the actual Convention were changed? Would that automatically change the essential nature of this Bill? For example, take the cultural heritage aspect. According to the Convention, cultural heritage includes groups of buildings. Does Senator Mason believe that this Bill would apply to the Rocks area, the Opera House or the Harbour Bridge in Sydney if the Commonwealth nominated them for listing. I ask honourable senator's to bear in mind that their nomination had previously been rejected. If they were submitted again, would their very submission-which has already been rejected-under the Bill be sufficient to trigger off its mechanism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is bringing up a grab bag of whatever he can get his hands on. I think he is really raising these points, not through any genuine desire for information but because he wishes to prolong and delay the situation. How- ever, I would like initially, of course, to cover his previous point. With the indulgence of the Committee, I would like to answer his point on clause 3. It does not really matter whether we are referring to the World Heritage Committee in the preamble or the schedule of the Bill. The honourable senator spoke about groups of buildings. This is a quibble. If a group of buildings was submitted it would be submitted responsibly and with due thought. If, indeed, it was submitted and accepted and it became part of the world heritage, the Bill would apply.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Harradine

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman-

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5 (Act binds the Crown).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a bit of a problem on my hands because I really do not know how to 'keep the bastards honest'.
—Order!

—That was in inverted commas, Mr Chairman. It was a quotation from an earlier work. The point I wish to make is that again we face the prospect of the gag before there can be any proper raising of the issues concerning this clause. I just want to point out that clause 5 purports to bind the Crown in right of the Commonwealth and hence it is a clear imposition on or an attempt to put obligations upon the Commonwealth with respect to the matter that the legislation deals with, namely, the position in South West Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a very odd discrepancy in behaviour here. There is not only the discrepancy within the Australian Democrats who have told us they will never gag -never, apparently, until today; we are going to have no more of that-but also there is some discrepancy between what is happening here tonight and what the Australian Labor Party did when it had the opportunity to do something. The Labor Party was in government in Tasmania. We know that the Labor Party here has its organic links to the Labor Party in Tasmania; we know that the Labor Party in Tasmania pursued this dam; we know that the Labor Party has the power in intervene federally in all sorts of cir- cumstances; and we know that the Labor Party did absolutely nothing to try to take the course that it is now seeking through this legislation when it had the power so to do.

In other words, we have the nice situation where it is fine to come in here and vote when one has no power and no authority but when the Labor Party had both the power and the authority, it not only did nothing but also it pursued the objective of this dam. That is the fact of the matter and it is something about which there ought to be a clear message to the electors. Why is it that when Tasmania had a Labor Government no effort was made by the Labor Party here to turn back what the Government was seeking to achieve? Why is it that it is only when the Labor Party is in a position of powerlessness, when it cannot in fact affect events, that it suddenly takes this highly principled stand? I think there is something very odd in all of this and for that reason the Government opposes this clause. I am sure that all Government members will do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There may once have been an occasion in the course of this debate when it would have been appropriate to reply to matters such as that raised by Senator Chaney. There may once have been an occasion in the course of this debate when some sweet reason might have prevailed so far as the subject matter of these clauses is concerned. That occasion has long since passed as was made manifest by the behaviour of the other side of this chamber for the last 3 1/2 hours before we commenced this run of divisions. For that reason I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6 (Protection of properties).

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Ryan.
—Mr Temporary Chairman--
—Order! Senator Ryan has the first amendment. I have to call her first.
—Well, on the understanding that the Opposition will allow me to move my amendments to its amendment.
—Certainly.
—I can give you no such undertaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition wishes to move an amendment to clause 6 of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982. I will explain briefly the purposes of the amendment. Clause 6 of the Bill makes it unlawful for a person to take action that would adversely affect the protection, conservation, presentation or rehabilitation of a property which is included, or which has been nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage List. By operation of the Bill and the Act Interpretation Act 'person' would include corporations and government bodies. Proposing to take the above action is also caught by clause 6, as is action taken in association with other 'persons' referred to in sub-clause 3 (2). The purpose of the amendment moved by the Opposition is to exclude from the action prescribed in clause 6 any action taken as a part of implementing a plan of management.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously in a wilderness area there ought to be a plan of management and people engaged in implementing that plan of management should not, in our view, be considered to be contravening this provision. I believe that Senator Mason's purpose in this provision is to provide protection for the South West Tasmanian region. We agree that that protection should be provided in this way, but that legitimate activity arising from the implementation of a plan of management under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act ought not be excluded. Indeed, it is highly desirable that such a plan of management be implemented in the park area. I remind honourable senators that such a plan of management is now implemented in the Kakadu National Park in order to preserve, conserve and generally manage the park area under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. Similarly, a plan is being prepared for the Uluru National Park which again will be a Federal plan under the Federal Act-the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975-although Northern Territory Government agencies will be involved in the day to day implementation of that plan.

I noted that in the second reading debate there was some criticism of our amendment and an expression that our amendment would preclude the operation of a plan of management of the national park which was implemented by a State government. I point out to honourable senators who raised that objection that although there is an overriding Federal responsibility here, that Federal responsibility does not preclude co-operation with the Tasmanian State Government. If the Tasmanian State Government wished to be involved in the management of this area, then it could submit a plan of management to the Federal Government. If that were satisfactory-and being satisfactory would mean that it would include such things as the opportunity for public submissions, the opportunity for a statutory period during which objections could be laid before the authorities and so forth-then there could be agreement by the Federal Government that the State plan of management of the South West Tasmanian region could be implemented.

In moving this amendment the Opposition is enabling the operation of a plan of management which would be either a Federal plan implemented under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, or, with a co-operative State government, a State plan which met the requirements and indeed the responsibilities of the Federal Government. I point out that because the area provided for in this legislation is an area which has been nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage List, there is not only a Federal Government right but also a Federal Government responsibility to ensure that any plan of management is in keeping with Federal objectives. I hope that that explanation has clarified the matter for honourable senators, particularly those who made some reference to this matter in the course of the debate. On behalf of the Opposition I move:
Page 4, clause 6, at end of clause, add the following new sub-clause:

(2) Nothing in this section shall render it unlawful for a person to do any act or take any action which is expressly or impliedly authorized by a zoning plan that has come into operation under the provisions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 or a plan of management in force under the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, or any such zoning plan or management plan as may be provided under a law of the Commonwealth, including a law in respect of South West Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment and believe it clarifies some criticisms which were made by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in respect of this clause, as it does particularly identify plans of management that may be agreed. During my second reading speech I still expressed some criticism that it may not include State plans which had been approved by the Commonwealth, but I think on reflection that the words in the amendment, including 'management plans as may be provided for under a law of the Commonwealth' are probably wide enough to do that. In addition to that fact, Mr Murray Wilcox, Q.C., wrote a letter to me on 22 November relating to the criticisms which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee made, and, not by way of a concluded determination but by way of floating, raised some possible difficulties. He answered these in a letter in which he sets out that the Australian Labor Party amendment does largely alter the situation, and moreover, that there is no real problem. I have shown the letter to the Minister, to Senator Harradine and to the Opposition spokesman. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this letter which relates to his answers to these criticisms.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Selbourne Chambers, 174 Phillip Street, Sydney 22 November, 1982 Senator Alan Missen,
The Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Missen,

Penny Figgis has mentioned to me her recent discussion with you relating to the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. I am grateful to you for your invitation to comment upon the notes on the Bill of your Committee.

It is correct that cl. 6 of the Bill is couched in general language providing ' 'little identification of the scope of unlawful action with which the Bill would deal''. The foreshadowed ALP amendment, designed to add a new subclause (2) goes some distance towards overcoming this objection. The effect of that subclause, of course, would be that management plans could be prepared in respect of particular properties and any act which was in accordance with a management plan would be lawful. I think that the result of the additional subclause would be to encourage the preparation, and adoption under Commonwealth law, of suitable management plans and this would be an obvious advantage.

However, in the meantime, I doubt that there is a real problem. The Bill does not, of course, create any criminal liability. If it were alleged, in a particular case, that a particular activity was likely adversely to affect an area then it would be a matter for the Federal Court to determine whether this claim was made out. This would involve the court considering the nature of the threat and whether that threat was likely to have adverse consequences. If it were found that there was such a threat then the court would make an order restraining the defendant from taking the action. Provided that he obeyed the order he would be at no risk. The situation is similar to that found in numerous statutes where general formulae have to be used, allowing the courts to work out the situation in particular cases.

I doubt whether it would ever be possible to formulate an appropriate and comprehensive list of likely threats. Even in relation to the existing properties on the World Heritage List or nominated for the World Heritage List there is a wide variation in the nature of possible threats. As the number and variety of properties on the List increases so will the nature of the threats they might suffer. For this reason, as it seems to me, the power of the court must be put in fairly general terms but with a provision encouraging the creation of zoning plans in respect of particular properties as soon as possible .

The Committee's comment on cl. 7 points out that court action may be taken against a person who had no intention of damaging a property but whose actions might be regarded as having an adverse effect. This is, of course, correct but, as you would know, it is the invariable practice to call upon a person said to be in breach of a statute to desist before actually commencing court proceedings . He then has an opportunity to assess his position before becoming involved in any court proceedings. The defendant would not be at risk as to costs unless, after consideration of his position and taking any desired advice, he decided to persist with his claim and if he then unsuccessfully argued that the action would not be likely to have an adverse effect. Under no conditions, of course, would he be at a greater risk than in respect of legal costs.

The Committee raises the question of failure to preserve or restore a property. This is done on the assumption that ''the doing of an act can include the failure to do an act''. With respect, I doubt the validity of that assumption. The Bill was deliberately framed so as to confine the unlawful behaviour in cl. 6 to circumstances where a person does an act or takes an action likely adversely to affect a property. One does not, of course, do an act by failing to do some other act and I see no basis upon which the court could hold that an owner was liable for failing to preserve or restore a property.
I hope that the above comments may be of some assistance to members of your Committee. Please use them as you see fit.
With kind regards,
Yours sincerely, MURRAY WILCOX, Q.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason for my rising before Senator Harradine, who I know wishes to move amendments to the amendment, is that I am a great believer in Pavlovian psychology. Five gags in a row were moved immediately after Senator Harradine spoke so one can expect the same sort of treatment. I figured I might not get a chance to contribute to the Committee unless I spoke before him. I do not say that by way of hoping that he will have the gag moved but merely out of weary expectation after the antics of the last hour. I just want to indicate, as I did in the opening stage of the Committee debate, that the Government proposes to support the Opposition amendment as one which improves the Bill. It is not an amendment which we believe makes the Bill acceptable; there are many other elements of the Bill which would require attention and that has been made clear in the debate and I do not wish to labour the point. But I would want it to be part of the Committee record that we would be supporting the Opposition amendment because we see it as a significant improvement on what is contained in the original Bill. I will, of course, have to await Senator Harradine's explanation of his foreshadowed amendment in the Committee stage, but as I understand the amendment, without having heard it, I also anticipate that the Government would support his amendment to the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Government is in accord on this matter and supports the Australian Labor Party amendment which was discussed by me with the Labor Party some little time ago. It is a positive improvement to the Bill and we are pleased to have it brought to us and moved by the Labor Party. We are pleased to see it have an input to this legislation. The Australian Democrats by no means regard themselves as the fount of all wisdom. We think that it is a proper pursuit of the business of the Senate for honourable senators to think diligently about legislation which they disagree with and to bring forward amendments. Those amendments ought to be tested by discussion in this place and passed or otherwise. If they find approval with the Senate the legislation will be passed; if not, it will not be passed. We see that as a very proper course of events in connection with this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to be extremely brief in my comments because I am appalled at the enormous sums of public money which have been wasted in the terrifying filibustering on this Bill. I think that well over 10 hours has been taken over the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill and I am not prepared to compromise extensively with anybody who wants to quibble where I am convinced that there is a quibble. We approve of the Labor Party's amendment to the clause . Senator Missen raised the point of State plans. My advice is that we can include State plans approved by the Commonwealth and this of course would be the reasonable and proper procedure. I do not want to say more than that now. Senator Harradine must, of course, move his amendments. I do not see much virtue in them at the moment but I am sure he will be trying very hard to convince all of us of their virtue when he speaks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Mason for entering this debate. It is his Bill. During the time we have debated this measure there has been no attempt by Senator Mason, nor by any other honourable senators supporting this measure, to answer the questions that have been raised. Now we see the shadow senator in charge of this Bill, Mr Murray Wilcox, having a letter introduced into this Parliament and incorporated in Hansard. At least the shadow senator who, presumably, was responsible for the drafting of this Bill has a document incorporated in Hansard. I have a copy of it. I should like a little time to go over it to assess-with assistance, of course-the merits or otherwise of what has been stated by the President of the Australian Conservation Foundation. But it really is extraordinary that Senator Mason, the senator in charge of this Bill, is unable to answer a question and a shadow senator from outside this place has a letter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: I now raise a couple of questions about clause 6 of the Bill. Of course this clause first of all refers to a peson doing-or proposing to do-an act as being in breach of this Act. I ask Senator Mason: What precisely does he mean by a person proposing to take an act? That really smacks of thought control. I should like to have a response from Senator Mason as to why those words are included in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have misread it. It is not proposing to do an act or take an action.
—It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the doing of or proposing to do, such an act or the taking of, or proposing to take . . .

When does one determine when a person is proposing to take certain action? A person may enter the area not proposing to do or take an act and then suddenly propose to do it and take it. I seek leave, in order to save time, to move two amendments to the Opposition's amendments concurrently. I will then move a third amendment, which is separate, at a later stage.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Amendment No. (1), proposed new sub-clause 6 (2), after 'has come into operation', insert 'at the commencement of this Act'.
(2) Amendment No. (1), proposed new sub-clause 6 (2), after 'in force', insert 'at the commencement of this Act'.

The amendments seek to provide certainty for the Senate as to what it is at present doing. The amendments attempt, insofar as Commonwealth legislation is concerned, to avoid a situation where we, by virtue of this legislation, are buying a pig in a poke. The amendments are somewhat uncontroversial in that we know that there is at least one zoning plan, as I understand it, in operation under the provisions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975. The Australian Labor Party's amendment does not specify 'at the commencement of this Act'. It may infer 'at the commencement of the Act'; I do not know. But it does not specify that and in order to satisfy the principle of certainty I suggest that after the word 'operation' the words 'at the commencement of this Act' should be inserted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably in law the interpretation any court would take.
—I follow that, but that is why I say it is not a controversial question and I so move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a couple of points that Senator Harradine mentioned on this question of 'proposing to do'. I would have thought that this was a matter for the discretion of the courts within the context of this legislation. The only intention is that a person can be told not to do something and if they do it they are in breach of this proposed Act. If a person merely proposes, the degree of damage which they could create does not exist, but their intention is there to be taken some note of. It would be improper not to have that provision in the Bill. To do so would be to infer a situation where damage would actually be done to valuable properties of the Commonwealth when that might have been prevented. I think this is a reasonable situation. I am not particularly concerned with Senator Harradine's amendments. I think there is no reason why we should not accept them. I do not mind accepting them. I would like to hear Senator Ryan's comments at this stage on Senator Harradine's statement.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, we would like to accommodate Senator Harradine on this. I can see his intention and would agree with it. I am not a lawyer. I ask him, through you Mr Chairman, would the insertion of the words 'at the commencement of this Act' after the words 'has come into operation' limit or preclude the application of future zoning determinations? While I agree with his intention I wonder whether by making the Act so specific, he might well be defeating the very purpose that he is seeking to achieve. I would like to hear a lawyer, such as my friend Senator Missen, on this. But that would be the doubt that I would have at this stage. I understand that is the doubt which the Australian Labor Party has as well.

—I would express some doubt about it. I would think that the court's interpretation would be that this would speak not retrospectively but as from the time of commencement. But, on the other hand, by writing those words into it, it might be said that it excludes zones that come into operation later.
—That is the purpose of it.
—There is a possibility that that is what would happen and therefore one would restrict it against future zoning plans being applied. In that event, it would be an unwise amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reservations that were expressed by Senator Missen and by Senator Chipp are reservations that we are very concerned about. The effect of the amendment to our amendment moved by Senator Harradine would be to restrict the operation of this section in relation to plans already in place-that is, one plan under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and one plan under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. We do not wish such a restriction to apply. We believe that any future plans or future zoning arrangements should also be covered by this provision, so we are unable to accept the amendment moved to our amendment by Senator Harradine.

—(Tasmania) (9.56)-I certainly did not hide anything in my explanation of the amendment. I said that what I wanted to avoid was the situation in which, under this legislation, one would be buying a pig in a poke. We know what zoning plans and plans of management are in force now under those pieces of legislation. I would envisage that if there were future plans so far as those pieces of legislation are concerned there would need to come to the Parliament an amendment to this legislation. Let that be perfectly clear.
—You might be fooling the rest of them but you are not fooling me. Come on.
—I am not attempting to fool anybody. I am trying to make the intention of the amendment perfectly clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments (Senator Harradine's) to amendment (Senator Ryan's) negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Amendment No. (1), proposed new sub-clause 6 (2), leave out 'the Commonwealth, including a law in respect of South West Tasmania', insert 'a State after consultation between that State and the Commonwealth'.

The third amendment is a much more important amendment. It takes up a point that was made by Senator Peter Rae when speaking to the reference motion. The purpose of the amendment is to ensure that what occurs as a result of this legislation is done with the co-operation of not only the Tasmanian Government but the Tasmanian Parliament. Under this provision, the machinery of this Bill applies in a coercive fashion to the State of Tasmania. There is nothing in the Bill which encourages, let alone requires, co-operation with the Tasmanian Government or with the Tasmanian Parliament. In that situation, the amendment proposed by the Opposition is quite different from the practice insofar as the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act are concerned. This fact is indicated by a release on 17 November from the Australian Heritage Commission. The Commission indicated:
The Commission notes that the propriety of the Commowealth involvement in an area of world heritage significance is being disputed in certain quarters.

The Commission would only wish to point out that the Commonwealth is involved already in two areas on the World Heritage List, that is Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory and the Great Barrier Reef in Queensland, and operates with co-operation from the Territory-and State governments.

The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that there is co-operation between the Commonwealth and the State governments. There is no other purpose than that. What the amendment seeks to do is to exclude from the Australian Labor Party's amendment the words 'the Commonwealth, including a law in respect of South West Tasmania' and include therein the words 'a State after consultation between that State and the Commonwealth'. Senator Ryan's amendment would then read:
'Nothing in this section shall render it unlawful for a person to do any act or take any action which is expressly or impliedly authorised by--
I interpolate 'any such zoning plan or management plan as may be provided under a law of'--
a State after consultation between that State and the Commonwealth'.

I think that it is appropriate for this Senate to amend the amendment in that fashion because that entails a truly co-operative approach between Tasmania and the Commonwealth. Might I refer to what Senator Rae said. Senator Rae maintained his position in respect of this Bill. Indeed although admittedly he had reservations, he voted for the second reading of the Bill. His reason for doing so was that he had been involved and was committed to a Liberal Party policy commitment issued in 1975. On page 3122 of Hansard he is reported as saying:

That policy statement referred to the fact that there had been discussions between Federal Liberals and State Liberals in relation to the question of South West National Park and that there was agreement. It stated: He quoted the agreement.
These are his words:
. . . it is important that early action be taken to preserve this area.
He went on to say:

The area referred to was a significantly enlarged South West National Park which was to be developed and maintained. The statement went on to point out that there was a need for co-ordination in relation to the park. It stated-
This is the important point that Senator Peter Rae made in respect of this matter-

. . . the Commonwealth Government provide a special grant to assist the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service to develop a management plan for the existing South West National Park as a matter of urgency.
Indeed, I might mention that Senator Missen also made the point at page 3110. He said:

I think the major defects have been covered by the Australian Labor Party in its amendments. I see some defect in that if a State has a plan of management for parks and so forth there is no way at the moment that that could be protected from action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have recanted from that position. I am satisfied I was wrong. I think it is covered by the Labor Party's amendment.
—But Senator Missen said that it is not covered by the Labor Party's amendment.
—I have learnt since. I am enlightened.
—Senator Missen has changed his mind.
—I have changed my mind.

—I wonder whether Senator Peter Rae has changed his mind. I feel that it is an important aspect and I have tried to accommodate the views of the Labor Party in this amendment. I have tried hard to accommodate them and I have done so in what I believe to be a manner consistent with the responsibilities of this chamber to attempt to ensure that there is proper consultation with the States. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has been quite clear about the purpose of the amendment. We cannot accept it because the amendment cuts across the very point that the Opposition is seeking to establish in its amendment. The Opposition's amendment seeks to establish that the Commonwealth has the legislative power and obligations under the world heritage convention to implement these plans. They are not the responsibility of State governments; they are the responsibility of the Commonwealth. Therefore, any plans must be approved by the Commonwealth Parliament. I hope I made that clear when I spoke to the previous amendment. Such plans could be proposed by a State government. There could be consultation. Senator Harradine says he is keen to establish consultative procedures and, indeed, we hope that there would be consultation and co-operation. But even if the plans are proposed by a State government they must be approved by the Federal Parliament. Senator Harradine's amendment rules out the Commonwealth legislative power and replaces it merely with an opportunity for consultation.
—This legislation would operate.
—Senator Harradine's amendment leaves out the words 'a law of the Commonwealth'.
—That is in respect of a zoning plan.

—The position of the Australian Labor Party is that those words should not be left out and the Commonwealth should legislate in this matter after consultation with the States. Senator Harradine's amendment to the Labor Party's amendment therefore is not acceptable. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Harradine's amendment to Senator Ryan's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Ryan's) agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 7 (Enforcement).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to move an amendment to this clause, which provides the procedure to have the proposed Act enforced. It enables a person to bring proceedings in the Federal court for an order declaring that any actions or proposed actions breach the Act and can order a restraining of such a breach. Any person, including a government, may seek such a declaration from the court. It is not necessary that such a person have personal rights which would be affected by the breach of the Act. Although we agree with the effect of this clause, we believe that there should not only be an enabling provision but there should also be a responsibility for the Minister, when he has cause to believe that there has been a breach of an Act, to take action to bring the proceedings to court. The purpose of this amendment is to give teeth to this provision to make the Minister obliged to act to bring proceedings when there has been a breach.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Harradine) agreed to:
Page 4, clause 7, sub-clause (1), after 'any person', insert 'who is normally resident in Australia'.
Amendment (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:
Page 4, clause 7, after sub-clause (1), insert the following new sub-clause:
'(1A) If the Minister believes, on reasonable grounds, that a breach of this Act has taken, is taking, or will take, place, he shall, as soon as practicable, bring proceedings in the Court for-
(a) an order declaring that such act, proposed act, any action or any proposed action is a breach of this Act; and
(b) an order to remedy or restrain a breach of this Act'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 7, sub-clause (2), at end of sub-clause add: ', except the power to punish contempts under section 31 of that Act'.
Page 4, clause 7, after sub-clause (2), add the following sub-clause:
'(3) A person who fails to comply with an order of the Court made under sub- section (2) shall be guilty of an offence.
Penalty: $100'.

The purpose of the first amendment is to withdraw from this Bill one of the most rigorous applications of the law available within Australia. I refer to the contempts provision, and seek some certainty as to what penalty arises, reading this amendment in conjunction with the second amendment to sub-clause (2) that I have moved. The two proposed amendments stand together. Honourable senators will recall that during the debate on the second reading, and also during the debate on my motion to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I referred to the fact that the Bill contains a rather draconian measure, the contempt of court provision. I said then that it appears that none other than Mr Murray Wilcox, the Chairman of the Australian Conservation Foundation, may have been responsible for the suggestion that the contempt powers should be available in relation to actions taken under this legislation.

It must be remembered that this is a very serious situation indeed. I mentioned either earlier today or yesterday that the contempt powers were used against the managing editor of a newspaper in Adelaide and he was in fact gaoled. It is usual in contempt proceedings for judges to impose gaol sentences. I think that is a bit rough, when consideration is given to the fact that some of the people involved could well be embroiled in an argument between the States and the Commonwealth. They could find themselves before the Federal Court and put in gaol until they changed their minds. They could be proceeding in accordance with their obligations to a statutory authority which, in turn, is, proceeding with a project endorsed and authorised by the State Parliament. It would, to my mind be a travesty of justice if an employee of that authority were hauled before the Federal Court and, after refusing to obey an order, be liable to punishment for contempt under section 31 of that Act.

As I have mentioned very frequently-I am advised that this is what happens in the majority of cases-contempt of court is one of the worst offences in the book . The courts throw the book at an offender and, normally speaking, he ends up in gaol. It may be said that the penalty I am proposing is not an adequate penalty for an offence. The penalty of $100 is the same as the penalty that applies under the State legislation in respect of the forthcoming blockade. Other senators may have opinions about what the penalty ought to be, but that is the reason that I have applied the $100 penalty in this amendment. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the two amendments. I think the carriage of these amendments would be quite disastrous to the effectiveness of the Bill. The Bill provides that the power of contempt should reside in the court. It is a power which resides normally in the Federal Court. Of course, it is subject to control by a superior court. It is an essential power to a court which is to restrain an action which may cause incalculable damage to a world heritage item, perhaps causing damage necessitating millions of dollars to be spent on reconstruction work or causing complete destruction of an item. I have no doubt that the contempt power would be exercised with sense and reason by the court and would be dependent upon the type of circumstances that arose. To take away that power would be to nobble the court in exercising a control over this.

SPEECH.PARA: The alternative penalty of $100 is, of course, quite a contemptuous amount. It is something less than the penalty for shoplifting and it is an amount which would be no deterrent whatsoever to a person who might destroy something of vital importance and incalculable value to future generations. It is important to keep this power in the court, knowing that courts will act with reason and justice in this matter. I urge the Senate to reject these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen's extremely lucid contribution covers the reservations that the Australian Labor Party has about Senator Harradine's amendments. We believe that the legislation should be serious legislation and legislation that is able to be enforced. Of course, the replacement of proper enforcement powers with a $100 fine would reduce the Bill to a totally ineffective state. For the reasons that Senator Missen has given, I inform the Senate that Senator Harradine's amendments are not acceptable to the Opposition.

—Minister for Social Security) (10.29)-I can understand the varied views which are held on this. But, on behalf of the Government, I express reservation on the quite unlimited powers of punishment which are effectively contained in clause 7 as it stands. For that reason, the Government would prefer to see a writing down of the penalties in a more specific inclusion. In conclusion, I think if this were a Government Bill we would probably be seeking a penalty rather higher than that which is put forward by Senator Harradine. But since it is not a Government Bill and since we have the reservation about using the full extent of Federal Court power to punish for contempt, the Government will support the amendment moved by Senator Harradine.

—The Australian Democrats oppose Senator Harradine's amendment. The amendment completely mistakes the intention of the Bill. There is no desire to impose penalties but to provide a deterrent to persons who offend against the Act. What Senator Harradine said about the power of contempt applies to all courts. There is nothing new or interesting in that. So we oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -I congratulate Senator Mason for again making an unusual contribution to this debate. I would like to take this opportunity to indicate that this sort of open-ended extraordinary use of the contempt provisions is consistent with the single-minded approach of those who have advanced it. I remind the committee that the suggestion came from the President of the Australian Conservation Foundation in evidence given by him to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. If honourable senators would only refer to my speech at the second reading stage they would see what the President of the Australian Conservation Foundation said was as I quoted him in my speech. Again we see that honourable senators are not interested in civil liberties, the civil rights of the ordinary person. They are single-minded in their approach to these questions. They are not even prepared to balance the viewpoints of the State concerned. Let me remind honourable senators that it is their view-their single minded view-that it is South West Tasmania today, the world tomorrow and probably Western Australia the day after.
—What about the Australian Capital Territory?

—I am afraid that they have already got the Australian Capital Territory. I must remind the Committee that this is a measure not specifically for South West Tasmania but a general measure. I believe time is now required for us to consider what we have done today. I intend to adopt a procedure which will allow that time to be given.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Question put:
That the clause, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 8 (Evidence).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) In any proceedings under this Act, a certificate signed by-
(a) the Minister; or
(b) the Secretary to the Committee, and stating that a specified property situated in Australia or any specified part of such property is a property--
For the purpose of this--
is evidence of the matters stated in the certificate.

I ask Senator Mason: What if the Minister and the Secretary to the Committee have a divergence of opinion? Would the signature by the Paris-based Secretary override that of the Australian Minister? That is a straight question and I think it deserves a yes or no response.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very plain. It offers that power to either the Minister or the Secretary to the Committee, and very properly so.
—But what if there is a divergence of opinion?
—That might be asked of almost any process of government anywhere in the world-any public service department. It is not a statement worth considering.

—Can I just take the answer a little further? It seems to me that if in fact there were such an extraordinary situation in which one person certified something and another person certified something else , other evidence would have to be produced. The clause states that such evidence is evidence of what is in the certificate. It does not say that it is conclusive evidence, or that it brings the matter to an end. It just means that if a case against someone is to be proven-and this is a very common clause found in a lot of other Bills-that evidence can be used as prima facie evidence of stated facts . If that curious situation of two lots of evidence saying the opposite were to arise, it would obviously have to be argued out and a court would have to decide finally what the truth of the matter was. It is a very fantastic possibility; that is all one could describe it as. Otherwise, it is the usual evidence clause .

—The optimism expressed by Senator Missen that it would be extraordinary that there should be a difference of view between the Minister and the Secretary to the Committee shows that Senator Missen has never had the joy of being a Minister. I do not find it at all peculiar to think that there might be such a discrepancy. I notice that Senator Chipp, who has been in the same position, is agreeing by smile if by nothing else and I suspect you, Mr Chairman, might have had experiences where by you would admit to that possibility. For that reason I express less optimism than did Senator Missen. I express concern about the very broad nature of this clause. I would have thought it is not in a common form. Senator Missen drew attention to the fact that it is merely evidence, not conclusive evidence. I think that the clause is rather carelessly drafted and I am rather surprised at how loose it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why, under the circumstances, is the evidence not signed by the Minister? Why import the Secretary to the World Heritage Committee?
—He has the records.

—Yes, but the nomination presumably has come from the State that is party to the convention. If that is the case, why not keep this within Australia and why not have the Minister as the responsible person sign the certificate?

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, under Standing Order 168, I would like my vote shown in the Journals as being in the negative.
—That will be recorded.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Hansard will record the Government's view and Senator Harradine's view of the clause.

INTERJECT.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I want to know from the honourable senator who introduced the Bill something which is quite important about the schedule, which contains the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. That schedule includes such provisions as Article 5 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: To ensure that effective and active measures are taken for the protection, conservation and presentation of the culturual and natural heritage situated on its territory, each State Party to this Convention shall endeavour, in so far as possible, and as appropriate for each country:

(a) to adopt a general policy which aims to give the cultural and natural heritage a function in the life of the community and to integrate the protection of that heritage into comprehensive planning programmes;

(b) to set up within its territories, where such services do not exist, one or more services for the protection, conservation and presentation of the cultural and natural heritage with an appropriate staff and possessing the means to discharge their functions;
What I want to know is: What is the purpose of putting the schedule in the Bill? Are we thereby enacting the Convention? If we are, we had better go through it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The schedule is purely to provide the framework for the Bill. We are not here, thank goodness, to debate the wording of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. That is not the purpose of this place. This schedule is a part of the Bill, the context within which the Bill operates and it is not a matter which is amendable by us or in any way subject to discussion. It is a schedule which provides the framework in which the Bill exists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason did not, with respect, answer my question.
—Well, it is all the answer you are going to get. It is a ridiculous point you are making.
—Senator Mason says that I am making a ridiculous point. He refuses to answer the question as to whether we are enacting this Convention by putting it into the schedule.
—We ratified it years ago.
—Well, are we enacting it now or are we not?
—No.
—Senator Mason says 'No'.
—No.
—No, I do not think we are.
—And the Minister says 'No' and Senator Missen says 'No.'
—They may have said it, but Senator Mason has just said 'No.' I read to him from his second reading speech, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to live up to the obligations we have imposed on ourselves as a nation , by ratifying the World Heritage Convention and nominating South-West Tasmania, we must enact the Convention.
He said: '. . . we must enact the Convention'. This shows that Senator Mason probably has not even read his second reading speech.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Mason

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move that the report of the Committee be adopted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Mason moving motions for the adoption of the Committee report and the third reading forthwith.

I do that under Standing Order 448. I will speak very briefly, out of courtesy to the Senate. I will not be acrimonious. I will simply give very briefly the reasons why I move this motion, conscious that Standing Order 448 requires that such a motion needs a component of urgency for the Senate to contemplate it. We have now completed about a 12-hour debate on this Bill-I am erring conservatively; I think it is probably more.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is 14.

—We have had about 14 hours of debate on a Bill of eight clauses. There is urgency for several reasons. The House of Representatives will sit, as I understand it, only on Tuesday and Wednesday of next week; maybe Thursday, but certainly not beyond next week. By virtue of the Standing Orders, if this Bill is not read a third time tonight on Tuesday we will get only as far as the report of the Committee being adopted and then we will have to wait another day- namely, until Wednesday-to have the third reading passed by the Senate.
—That is right.

—Senator Harradine accommodates me by saying 'That is right'. The Senate, by a democratic majority, has passed this Bill. The Senate has met in Committee and passed the Bill with amendments. A clear majority of senators favour the Bill in its present form. What possible purpose is there in holding it up for two more days?
—Why were the Standing Orders written that way?

—They may well have been written for the purpose of senators who wanted to delay a Bill being passed in this place for two days. That could well have been the very sound reasons why the Standing Orders were framed in that way . I concede that. I am trying to suspend those Standing Orders in this case. We need a number of Liberal senators to vote with us, on this because, under Standing Order 448, we need an absolute majority, not a simple majority. I ask senators such as Senator Rae, to whom I am already on record as apologising, Senator Bonner and other honourable senators who have expressed a desire for preservation of the Franklin River, to realise that the World Heritage Committee meets on Monday.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If we pass the Bill, it will not make a scrap of difference to the World Heritage Committee.
—Order! There is too much audible conversation. I ask that Senator Chipp be heard.
—I acknowledge the interjection of Senator Townley who said that it will not make a scrap of difference if it is passed.
—Don't you change my words.
—I am sorry. I yield, with your indulgence, Mr President. He said-
—You read it.

—The thrust of Senator Townley's remark was that it will not matter a scrap to the World Heritage Committee's consideration if it is not passed for two days, or words to that effect. Well, if it will not make any difference, I invite Senator Townley to come across this chamber, as the Bill has received the democratic majority of the Senate, and vote for its passage tonight. The only purpose of voting against my motion to suspend Standing Orders , the only possible reason, is to delay the passage of this Bill until Wednesday .
—You people ruined it by not knowing the Standing Orders. If you had known the Standing Orders you could have had the third reading. Why didn't you tell them, Senator Missen?
—Order!
—I have been in the Senate chamber all night, and these Johnny- come-latelys who have been God knows where-

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chipp, resume your seat. I ask honourable senators to come to order. I again call Senator Chipp and ask that he be heard in silence and with some respect in putting his case.

—I have been in the chamber all evening since 4.30 p.m., with an exception of 45 minutes when I had a quick bite to eat with my wife. I do not know that these people here have been in the chamber that long.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Before they came in, I said that I would deliver this speech briefly, without acrimony, without stirring up any passions and without scoring any points. I am simply appealing to those members of the Liberal Party opposite , who recently won the Flinders by-election on a 'no dams' vote, to give the opportunity to the House of Representatives, when it meets on Tuesday, of voting on this Bill, which has been passed by a majority of this Senate. I so appeal to senators.

—Like Senator Chipp, I will try not to arouse any passions in my response. But it is the view of the Government that in light of the facts that we have been on this Bill, for many hours, that there are very strong views on the Bill, and that we may well wind up in having a third reading debate the way we are going, it would be better if this matter was not dealt with in the way which is suggested, namely, by the suspension of Standing Orders and the immediate moving of the adoption of the Committee report. For that reason, the Government will not support the motion to suspend Standing Orders. It will be a matter to which we can return next week, when we will all be in a much more refreshed--
—Will you speak up, please; we can't hear.
—When we will all be in a more refreshed frame of mind. I whispered my speech so that I would not arouse any passions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this proposition. Senator Chipp indicated that there had been some hours of debate on this question.
—Mainly by you.

—Yes, that is right. There has been not a debate on the question; there has not been a meeting of minds at all. The very important issues that have been raised by senators in respect of this Bill, senators who have been seeking information about this Bill, by and large, have been totally ignored by the supporters of the Bill because they could not answer the questions. We have just heard Senator Mason make a statement about the enactment of the schedule. He said: 'No, we are not enacting the convention'. Yet I read to him where he said in his second reading speech that the convention must be enacted.
—He does not understand the Bill; let us face it.
—Or the Standing Orders.

—No; well, he probably did not read his second reading speech. I point out to you, Mr President, that we have had eight to 10 gags tonight. I think it is important for the Senate to settle down and to ensure that there is time for us to reconsider what we have done tonight. Obviously, Mr President, that is why the Standing Orders are written in the manner that they are. There are two hurdles to be overcome; and yes, we will be debating it on Tuesday, and yes, we will be debating it on Wednesday. Standing Order 448 states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'In cases of urgent necessity, any Standing or Sessional Order or Orders of the Senate may be suspended on Motion . . . without Notice'.
Senator Chipp has not made out a case for urgency in respect of this question.

I would like senators to bear in mind a scenario of next week. What if we did agree with Senator Chipp's motion and the third reading stage was completed tonight, the Bill went down to the House of Representatives passed the Bill on Tuesday? Is that not the day before the day on which the World Heritage Committee will meet to consider the listing of the area?

What if the World Heritage Committee refused to list the area? Then we would have a ludicrous situation where the area would be a World Heritage area according to this Bill, subject as is a property, according to this Bill, because it is submitted to the World Heritage Committee. If the Committee refused to accept it, what a ludicrous situation we would be in.

One thing is certain: The Australian Democrats have not shwon responsibility in respect of this Bill or any adequate knowledge of Standing Orders, much less the Constitution. As the Minister has often stated in this chamber, it is all very well for the Democrats to roll up this sort of political stunt legislation when they do not have the responsibility of carrying it forward, when they have refused to co-operate with the Government of Tasmania. It all boils down to a question of responsibility. When one takes responsibility on one's shoulders, there is very little room for chips.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chipp's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Ralkon Agricultural Co.-Retirement of Director of Australian War Memorial

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ralkon Agricultural Co.-Retirement of Director of Australian War Memorial
Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for keeping the Senate for about five minutes. My apologies are to the Hansard staff and to the staff of the Senate for having had to work now for over 13 hours. I was one of those who voted not to change the hours of the Senate's sittings. All the Hansard staff in particular have had to work from 10 o'clock this morning without a meal break. ( Quorum formed). I thank the honourable senators for returning to the chamber, because what I have to say is very important. I repeat, I was one who did not vote to change the sitting hours and I know that all of the people affected have suffered a lot of trauma today. I want to put the record straight on a matter to which I referred some days ago. During the consideration on 17 November of the proposed expenditure for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, as set out in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83, I complained about the long delay in the Aboriginal Development Commission providing answers to questions that I had asked in the Estimates Committee hearing dealing with that body. In the course of my remarks I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I get back to what I started on. Why cannot the answers be provided? Why have not the legal advisers to the ADC been able to come up with the answers? Why are they hiding behind a cover? I suggest that they are doing so because Ralkon's lawyers have been told that they need to be paid before any further cases proceed on behalf of the ADC. They will not go on forever and a day without being paid for the legal expenses that they incur in taking cases to court on behalf of the ADC.

On reflection, my words were ill chosen. I have recently received correspondence from the solicitors engaged by the ADC and now take this opportunity to correct the record. As I did not name the solicitors on 17 November, I will not do so now. The solicitors in question wrote to the firm of solicitors representing Ralkon on 25 November of this year making reference to a telephone conversation of the previous day and enclosing an extract of the Senate Hansard recording my remarks. A copy of the letter, which was forwarded to me, contains the following passage:

We were pleased to note that you have no knowledge of any such suggestion. The allegation is entirely unfounded. We confirm that you state that you know nothing about this whatsoever and you have not been told anything to this effect .

We will be informing the Commission that the allegation is entirely unfounded. We would like to be able to say that we have spoken to you. The terms in which we propose to advise the Commission to comment on the allegation are as follows:

The allegation made by Senator McLaren that ''Ralkon's lawyers have been told that they need to be paid before any further cases proceed on behalf of the ADC' ' is quite unfounded. The Commission's solicitors have informed the Commission that they have not made any such comment to Ralkon's solicitors. Furthermore, the Commission's solicitors have asked Ralkon's solicitors whether they have been told anything to this effect. Ralkon's solicitors have informed the Commission's solicitors that they know nothing about it whatsoever and have not been told anything to that effect. They also have told the Commission's solicitors that they may reply in these terms.
Would you please telephone Mr-
I have deleted the name-
and let him know whether you agree with the terms of the above paragraph. We would be grateful if you would then confirm your attitude in writing.
Ralkon's solicitors then replied to the ADC's solicitors in these terms:
We acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th November, 1982. We confirm that we have never received any information as suggested in Senator McLaren's allegations.
We confirm that we consent to your proposed reply.
I quote in part from a letter to me from the ADC solicitors, dated 29 November. It reads:

We write to assure you that those allegations are completely unfounded. We have not made any such request to the Aboriginal Development Commission. Nor indeed, have we informed Ralkon's solicitors to that effect. Indeed, Ralkon's solicitors have informed us that they have not said anything to the effect as alleged by you. We enclose a copy of a letter we have sent to the solicitors for Ralkon and a copy of their reply which confirms this to be so. The actual position is that we undertake such work as is handed to us by the Aboriginal Development Commission. For that work we charge what we believe to be fair and reasonable fees. Those fees are rendered from time to time in the course of the matter in respect of work which has already been done. We have not asked the Commission to pay fees on account before any work was undertaken.

We note that in the course of your remarks on this question in the Senate you said that you had a deep concern about the issues and went on to say that if you were wrong about any of the matters stated you would be prepared to apologise if you have offended or humiliated any person in any way: see page 2442.

We are not asking you to make a public apology or any public withdrawal of your allegations in relation to the conduct of this firm, unless you would prefer to do so. We only wish to convey to you our concern that the allegation was made, inform you that it is entirely unfounded, and to inform you of the true position .

That letter is signed by the ADC solicitors. I accept completely the explanation given by both firms of solicitors in the letters from which I have quoted. In keeping with my promise referred to on page 2442 of the Senate Hansard of 17 November, I now express my apology and sincere regrets to both firms of solicitors for my remarks about the payment of legal expenses incurred on behalf of the ADC.

There is one further matter I wish to correct. On 2935 of the Senate Hansard of 30 November 1982, I am recorded as saying that the administrator, Mr Probyn, had locked the community hall, et cetera. On checking my files I now find that it was Mr Ron Wilson, the then chairman of the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council, who had locked the hall, and that Mr Probyn did not arrive at Point McLeay until the second week in March 1981 to take up his duties as administrator at Point McLeay . I intend to forward a copy of my remarks tonight to the ADC lawyers and also to the lawyers who act on behalf of Ralkon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I had intended to speak this morning when the Australian War Memorial report came up, because one cannot help noting, when looking through that document, the impact of the Director, Mr Noel Flanagan, upon the activities of the War Memorial. The time for discussing the report this morning passed before I had the opportunity to refer to him. I wish to do so because of his impending retirement on 25 December this year. Mr Flanagan was born in Victoria on 25 December 1917, that happy occasion being, I understand, the reason for having the names Noel Joseph. He went to school and university in Victoria and commenced his working life in 1937 in the Postmaster-General's Department. A lot of notable Australians have done exactly that. He served in the Royal Australian Air Force during World War II and has had a number of distinguished positions in the Public Service during his working life. He worked, I believe, on one occasion at least, in the same department as our own now Acting Deputy Clerk, Mr Nicholls. The pair had some distinction as a doubles teams of tennis players at about that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1975 Mr Flanagan has been the Director of the War Memorial and the following years have been important and significant ones in the development of the War Memorial. Not only has Mr Flanagan managed it but also he has kept abreast of museum development, liaised with other institutions and given a lot of advice and assistance to museum institutions. He has been responsible for assessing the future needs of the War Memorial and is chief adviser to the 13- member council.

The War Memorial is a very important tourist part of the Australian Capital Territory and its tourist development has been significant in the last couple of years. When built some 40 years ago it was anticipated that there would be about 300,000 visitors a year, but at present it has about one million visitors a year . Significantly this growth has taken place during the time of Mr Flanagan's directorship. His enthusiasm, his energy and his ability to approach anybody with the matters that he wanted to deal have been significant. It has a budget now of $5.5m and extensions recently approved of $11.5m, which shows the planning that he has put into it. One could speak for some time listing his actual achievements. But I think they are well known and certainly well documented. One could say of Mr Flanagan, quite simply, that he has been an achiever, a very pleasant one at that, who has got on well with those with whom he has worked, particularly, with Sir Thomas Daly, who was Chairman of the Australian War Memorial Council for about seven years until April of this year- he is also, of course, a man who served the Memorial with great distinction-and now with Sir Anthony Synnot, the present Chairman.

All of us who know Mr Flanagan are sorry that he is leaving the War Memorial. Certainly, the people of Canberra will miss him in that position and it will be very hard to replace him. There is a great deal more that could be said, but in view of the late hour to simply say that he was an achiever in the position sums up his career. It will be for those of us who are interested to see that the War Memorial continues to obtain the funds to maintain the development that has occurred and see that the preservation of its treasures are maintained. I thank Noel Flanagan, for what he has done. I wish him well in his retirement and also his wife, Dell.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I join in supporting the remarks made by Senator Reid in expressing my appreciation and that of my colleagues for the services rendered to Australia and, particularly, for the services rendered to the Australian War Memorial, by Mr Noel Flanagan. When I was Special Minister of State in the Whitlam Government I was responsible to the Parliament for the Australian War Memorial and, naturally, in that respect I was closely associated with Mr Flanagan. Not only I but also former Senator Willessee and Mr Bowen-another Special Minister of State , now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-held him in the very highest regard. I , and all members of the Australian Labor Party, wish Mr Flanagan well in his retirement. He was a first class public servant. No one could have had a better officer to serve with than Mr Flanagan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McLaren for the remarks he made during the adjournment debate tonight. I think it was a very appropriate thing that he did. I would like to join the Government with the expressions made by the other two senators about Mr Flanagan .

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in the country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American school children and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of reports from the United States of unauthorised personnel gaining access to computer systems.

(2) My Department uses 'in-house' WANG micro-computers for first stage data collections and processing in State and regional offices. This equipment is not used to store comprehensive files and data collected is only held in memory temporarily until written to magnetic diskette storage. The Department does not have its own central data processing computers, but does make extensive use of CSIRO facilities in Canberra. Use is also made of a number of other time-sharing bureaus for the processing of particular systems for example library catalogues. Access to these bureau facilities is controlled by the need for special log-on account codes and passwords which are known only to authorised departmental officers and a limited number of bureau staff. Physical wire-tapping would be necessary by a person with a high level of technical knowledge and appropriate terminal equipment before such information could be obtained.

(3) Apart from the need for termimal equipment and a knowledge of the log-on account codes and passwords, access to particular files of data is limited to one account code and password combination. These are different for each group of files. No one officer would know all these codes, and in most cases knowledge of the actual account code and password is restricted to one or two officers. Account codes and passwords are changed periodically. In some situations equipment log-on account codes and passwords are generated automatically by terminal devices to prevent this information becoming known. In such cases the information available through the terminal is restricted and strict physical security controls exist which prevent unauthorised officers using the equipment.

(4) The possibility of access to an individual's data record occurring either accidently or deliberately by an unauthorised person is considered so remote, that no security risk is considered to exist.

(5) I am advised that the practical difficulties associated with 'plugging in' to computer systems used by the Department are very considerable. While not completely impossible to a determined individual with criminal intent and unlimited time to experiment, it is considered that computer based files offer greater security than paper-based systems, and the risk associated with their use is not unacceptable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: School of Aboriginal Education: Adelaide College

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 14 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Education aware that the Technical and Further Education section of the South Australian Education Department is contracting professional staff associated with the School of Aboriginal Education at the Adelaide College of Advanced Education for periods as short as two and three months.
(2) Does the Government endorse this apparent change in policy.

(3) Is the Minister aware of the additional cost, to Consolidated Revenue, involved in administration as students are forced to shift, sometimes more than twice a year, from Social Security benefits to Aboriginal education grants.
(4) What measures will the Minister take to rectify this situation and make the future of Aboriginal education in South Australia stable once more.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Both the Department of Further Education and the Education Department in South Australia have advised (a) they have not been contracting staff from the South Australian College of Advanced Education and (b) staff contracted from other areas are normally engaged for a minimum of six months.
(2) No change in policy has occurred.

(3) I assume that the Aboriginal education grants referred to are those provided by the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme (Abstudy). This Scheme supports Aboriginals who undertake study after leaving school. Grantholders must forego unemployment benefit if undertaking full time courses of longer that one week. I am unaware of any significant additional administrative costs involved when beneficiaries move from unemployment benefit to Abstudy or vice versa.
(4) No action is called for.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 10 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many times over the last 5 years have the MV Lumen and other vessels operated by the Navigational Aids Branch participated in marine pollution incidents.
(2) On each occasion, what was the cost of each vessel's service, and how does this relate to the cost charged to the parties involved.

(3) Has the Department of Transport and Construction used vessels other than those owned by the Department in oil pollution incidents, if so, how do these costs relate to costs of Navigational Aids Branch Vessels.
(4) Had the MV Lumen not been available, what action would have been taken for this work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Once. MV Lumen was used when the container ship Kyoten Maru grounded in Lihou Reef on 25 May 1982.

(2) The cost was $18,512.00 ($3,043.00 per day) which has been met by the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil. Action is in hand to recover this cost from the owners of the Kyoten Maru.
(3) Yes, in May 1979 the tug Carlock was chartered in response to the possibility of oil pollution from the Taiwanese fishing vessel Hui Ju Hup. The cost was $3,400 per day for six days.
In December 1981 the Department chartered a workboat Karraline in connection with the SS Co-op Marine which grounded off Port Hedland. The total cost was $1, 375.

The cost depends on the type of vessel used. Operating costs of the Navigational Aids vessels MV Lumen and Cape Moreton are $3,043.00 and $10,450.00 per day respectively. Operating costs of commercial vessels also vary according to type. The task to be performed would determine the type of vessel used.
(4) Had MV Lumen not been available and suitable the Department would have sought the charter of a commercially owned/operated vessel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Priority is given to the processing of sponsorship applications for the entry of spouses, dependent children and fiances.
