(2) What percentage change does each of these amounts represent over the previous 12 months.
(3) What proportion of the current retail price of petrol in Australia is attributable to the crude oil levy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The crude oil and liquid petroleum gas levy receipts are shown in Table 7, page 341, of the Budget Statements 1982-83. In summary, these are:
Percentage
$m increase
(3) The proportion of the current retail price of petrol in Australia attributable to the crude oil levy cannot be estimated precisely for a number of reasons, the most important of which are:
(i) there is no single retail price of petrol in Australia;
(ii) petroleum products are jointly produced from crude oil and it is not possible to precisely allocate costs to individual products; and
(iii) no crude oil levy is imposed on imported petrol or petrol refined from imported crude oil.

If, however, crude oil levy receipts are allocated to petrol sales in proportion to such sales in total sales of petroleum products, then the crude oil levy could be said to be roughly equivalent to about 24 per cent of the weighted average of the six State capital city retail prices for premium grade petrol in the September quarter of 1982.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Queensland Main Roads Department: Termination of Employment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 11 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Queensland Main Roads Department terminated the employment of a number of workers at Winton and Aramac; if so, how many workers in each location and has the termination of these employees been due to the Federal Government's policy of contracting main roads work to private contractors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of no reports that the Queensland Main Roads Department has terminated the employment of any of its employees in the Winton and Aramac areas of the State.

Some 90 per cent of all roads expenditure in Queensland involves roadworks not related to national roads construction, I therefore cannot accept the proposition that retrenchment of Main Roads Department employees in the State would be attributable to the tender requirements of the Roads Grants Act. Furthermore, it was established prior to the introduction of the tender and contract system that a significant proportion of national road construction works in Queensland were already being undertaken by private contractors.

The Senate will be aware of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development (ABRD) Program which I recently announced. The objective of ABRD, which will provide an additional $2,500m to the States and the Northern Territory for roadworks over the next 6 years, is to upgrade sections of Australia's road network to a high standard by 1988-our Bicentenary.

When combined with the funds already being provided under the existing five year roads grants program the total Commonwealth contribution for roads in 1982- 83 will be about $914m, an increase of about $229m (or 33.4 per cent) over the 1981-82 allocation. In 1983-84 an estimated additional $430m will be made available under ABRD for roads bringing the total to $1,208m. This is $523m or 76.4 per cent more than the 1981-82 level. Queensland's indicative share of ABRD funds in 1982-83 and 1983-84 will be $39.2m and $93.7m respectively.

In addition to the direct road-related benefits arising from ABRD, which will be directed toward all categories of roads, I estimate that, directly and indirectly, 20,000 new jobs will be created across Australia as a result of the program, including rural areas such as Winton and Aramac.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: New South Wales Adult Migrant Education Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs make a commitment to provide permanent teaching positions for all full time teachers in the New South Wales Adult Migrant Education Service.
(2) Is the Minister aware that at present two hundred and one teachers are employed on an hourly basis only, while carrying out the duties of full time staff.
(3) When will funding be provided to correct this exploitative anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are at present 103 permanent teachers employed in the New South Wales Adult Migrant Education Service. Funds are being provided in 1982-83 for an additional 30 permanencies and a further seven positions are being converted from casual to permanent by some rationalisation of the present arrangements.

(2) I understand that the New South Wales authorities estimate that at present some 150 casual teachers are employed for 20 hours per week and that these staff are referred to as full time casual staff.

(3) The Teachers Federation has expressed the view that the proportion of permanent staff should be somewhat higher than at present. I have undertaken to consider this further and have sought information from all States so that the issue can be considered on a national basis. I have also sought further information from the New South Wales Minister for Education about organisational arrangements to make the best use of permanent staff and the improvement in the service which would result from the increased use of permanent teachers. Provided these matters can be resolved quickly and the information requested from all States is forthcoming, it should be possible to indicate the additional permanent positions in New South Wales by mid-December.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 30 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Commonwealth funds have been made available to Queensland since the financial year 1980-81 for drought relief.
(2) What funds have been provided by the Queensland Government for drought relief during the same period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth provides financial assistance to the States for drought relief purposes under the natural disaster relief arrangements. Payments to Queensland for drought relief under the arrangements in 1980-81 and 1981-82 were $14.8m and $5.6m respectively. The Commonwealth has not yet received any claims for assistance under the arrangements from Queensland for 1982-83 but the State is expected to qualify for assistance during the course of the financial year.

(2) Information on Queensland's expenditure on drought relief in the relevant years is only made available to the Commonwealth in respect of the State's expenditure on measures eligible for Commonwealth assistance under the arrangements. Queensland may have made other expenditure on measures for drought relief which were not eligible for Commonwealth assistance and, accordingly, on which the Commonwealth has no information. Expenditure by Queensland on approved measures for drought relief under the arrangements in 1980-81 and 1981-82 was $ 22.8m and $9.6m respectively, of which the Commonwealth provided $14.8m and $5. 6m respectively.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1849) Senator Macklin asked me, as Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Government been kept informed of all developments in relation to the compromising of allied security in Britain. Given the exchange of information between Australian and British intelligence services, can the Government assure the Senate that every possible action has been taken to isolate from harm and, if necessary, resecure Australia's defence after such damaging disclosures?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Australian and British officials have held discussions on this matter, and remain in touch.

It is, I think relevant to note that, following Prime's conviction and sentence to a term of 35 years' imprisonment for offences under Section 1 of the Official Secrets Act 1911, Mrs Thatcher made the following remarks in the House of Commons on 11 November concerning possible damage to Britain's allies:

'It is not only British interests which have been damaged, the damage extends to the interests of the United States Government. And of course the damage to our own and United States interests is damage to the interests of the Atlantic Alliance as a whole.

There is, however, no evidence that Prime had access to any classified information about our own or allied military dispositions or intentions, or about nuclear weapons, or to any information which could have endangered the lives of agents'.

During this statement Mrs Thatcher announced to the House of Commons that, following consultations with Mr Foot, the Leader of the Opposition, she had referred matters arising from this case to the Security Commission. I am confident that the British Government will inform Australia of any matters concerning our security which may arise from that inquiry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October Senator Elstob (Hansard, page 1927) asked me a question without notice concerning my response to a question without notice from Senator Hill of 21 October (Hansard, pages 1689-90) which dealt with investment in South Australia during the period of the Tonkin Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to check on investment figures during this period and I now provide the following answer:

Senator Hill's question and my answer related to a reference by the South Australian Chamber of Commerce to the biannual Survey of Major Manufacturing and Mining Projects conducted by the Commonwealth Department of Industry and Commerce.

The most recent survey (June 1982) indicated that the aggregate estimated remaining cost of projects listed by developers as at the 'committed' or 'final feasibility' stages in South Australia increased from $3.48 billion in December 1981 to $4.03 billion in June 1982. According to the survey, proposed investment in the South Australian manufacturing sector comprised 19.5 per cent of the Australian total of manufacturing projects at the 'committed' or 'final feasibility' stages. While the survey is not intended to provide a forecast of investment expenditure in total or over time, it does provide an indication of investment intentions.

I am advised that a statement by the then Premier that investment in manufacturing in South Australia during the relevant period totalled some $1, 500m was based on a survey conducted by the South Australian Office of State Development. This survey provides estimates of actual investment in South Australia during the period. I have forwarded a copy of this survey to Senator Elstob.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1982, (Hansard, page 2206) Senator Walters asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, a question without notice concerning the establishment of a peak council of Australian shipowners and maritime unions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Industry Peak Council of shipowners and the six sea-going maritime unions is intended to provide a forum for the future planning of the shipping industry and to act as a focal point for contact with Government and related industry bodies. The Council is expected to review matters affecting operations, industrial relations, employment and important policy issues as they relate to the shipping industry. It is not expected to be directly concerned with land based disputes as more appropriate consultative arrangements already exist to consider waterfront issues.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2213) Senator Townley asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, a question without notice concerning the synchronisation of traffic lights in Australian cities and towns.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The honourable senator asked a similar question on 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 637) and I refer him to my reply of 14 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1254).

I am informed that Australia is a world leader in research and implementation of traffic-adaptive control systems. Australia has one of the two systems of this type currently operational anywhere. It is known as the Sydney Co- ordinated Adaptive Traffic System (SCAT). Variations of SCAT are operational or soon to be operational in the Australian Capital Territory and all States except Queensland. Versions have been exported to Malaysia and New Zealand.

The honourable senator mentioned Canberra and Hobart as alternative potential testing areas for traffic light synchronisation. Canberra and Hobart commenced traffic light synchronisation programs in late 1978 and 1980 respectively and major improvements to the Canberra system are exptected to be initiated during 1983.

Adequate forums already exist for the exchange of information in this field. For example, the Australian Road Research Board holds annual conferences at which papers are presented on traffic control systems.
